questions.text: In northern, southern and western blot tests respectively, the samples being tested are?
questions.solution:
The test samples in northern, southern, and western blot tests are RNA, DNA, and protein respectively. 

Blot transfer tests are of three types based on the sample being tested and the probes used. Here is a table summarizing the test samples and probes used in the blot transfer test.

  Northern blot Southern blot Western blot
Test sample RNA DNA Protein
Probe  cDNA cDNA Antibody

 

The common step between them is the transfer of the separated fragments onto a specific blotting paper after gel electrophoresis. The probe is then added and it binds to complementary fragments which are then detected by specific methods like X-ray imaging or autoradiography.

questions.text: An outbreak of Zika virus infection was reported by the WHO. Which patient group is most vulnerable to the severe complications of this virus?
questions.solution:
Pregnant women are most vulnerable to the severe complications of the Zika virus. 

Pregnant women are infected, particularly during the first trimester and via transplacental transmission they infect fetal neuronal tissue, leading to microcephaly, facial disproportion, seizures and neurologic abnormalities, known as congenital Zika syndrome. It can also lead to abortions, preterm births and stillbirths. 

Zika virus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus transmitted primarily by infected mosquitoes of the Aedes genus, mainly the Aedes aegypti.

Other modes of transmission include 

  • Materno-fetal or intrauterine transmission
  • Sexual intercourse, due to the exchange of body fluids
  • Blood/blood product transfusion
  • Organ transplantation is also a potential mode of transmission of Zika virus

The majority of the people infected with this virus are asymptomatic. Few develop mild symptoms like fever, conjunctivitis, rash, myalgia, arthralgia, malaise, and headache. It has been reported to trigger Guillain-Barre syndrome, myelitis, and encephalitis in older children and adults.

The image below shows various modes of transmission of the Zika virus.

 

There is no specific treatment available for this disease. Adequate hydration and rest are advised, along with analgesics and antipyretics for pain and fever.

questions.text: A middle-aged man who presented with malaise, fever, a cutaneous ulcer, and preauricular lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with tularemia. Which among the following is a vector that transmits the disease?
questions.solution:
The vector that transmits tularemia is a hard tick.

Hard ticks are ectoparasites of vertebrate animals. They mainly transmit tularemia, tick typhus, and Kyasanur forest disease.

The dorsal surface of a hard tick is covered by scutum which is made up of chitin. This is absent in soft ticks. The head of the hard tick is at the anterior end. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks are:

  • Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
  • Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)
  • Viral fevers (e.g. Colorado tick fever)
  • Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)
  • Tularemia
  • Tick paralysis
  • Human babesiosis

Tularemia is a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis. It is a gram-negative bacillus and a category A bioterrorism agent. It is a disease of rabbits and rodents. The most common mode of transmission is by direct contact with rodents or tick bites. They manifest as flu-like symptoms with cutaneous ulceration and preauricular lymphadenitis.

Other options:

Option A- Soft tick mainly transmits Q fever and relapsing fever.

Option C- Blackfly mainly transmits onchocerciasis.

Option D- Sandfly mainly transmits kala-azar and oriental sore.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient visits the sleep clinic with a history of episodic gasping during sleep. In his evaluation for obstructive sleep apnea, he is asked to fill out a questionnaire to assess his day-time sleepiness. What is the scale used?
questions.solution:
The Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) is used in the assessment of daytime sleepiness.

The Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) a self-administered questionnaire with 8 questions, mentioning 8 activities that are part of the common routine. Respondents are asked to score from 0-3, their usual chances of falling asleep while engaged in these activities. The ESS score (the sum of 8 item scores, 0-3) can range from 0 to 24. A higher score indicates higher daytime sleepiness. 


EPWORTH SLEEPINESS SCALE
How likely are you to doze off or fall asleep during the following situations?

0 = would never dose

1 = slight chance of dozing

2 = moderate chance of dozing

3 = high chance of dozing
Sitting and reading 0 1 2 3
Watching TV 0 1 2 3
Sitting, inactive in a public place 0 1 2 3
As a passenger in a car for an hour without a break 0 1 2 3
Lying down in the afternoon to rest when circumstances permit 0 1 2 3
Sitting and talking to someone 0 1 2 3
Sitting quietly after a lunch without alcohol 0 1 2 3
In a car, while stopped for a few minutes without traffic 0 1 2 3
  TOTAL: 

The scores are interpreted as follows:

  • 0-5 Lower Normal Daytime Sleepiness
  • 6-10 Higher Normal Daytime Sleepiness
  • 11-12 Mild Excessive Daytime Sleepiness
  • 13-15 Moderate Excessive Daytime Sleepiness
  • 16-24 Severe Excessive Daytime Sleepiness

Other Options:

Option A) The Visual Analogue Scale is used for rating the severity of pain.

Option B) The Hunt and Hess Scale is used in rating the severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage based on the patient's clinical condition.

Option C) The Bristol Scale is to describe the consistency of stool in gastroenterology.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with gross hematuria. He has had multiple visits to the ophthalmologist in the past. His renal biopsy is shown below. What other test will he require?
questions.solution:
This patient with complaints of gross hematuria and eye problems with electron microscopy showing splitting of the basement membrane most likely has Alport syndrome. These patient are also likely to have hearing deficits and so audiometry should be done for baseline evaluation. 

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is a genetic disease caused by mutations in the COL4A5 gene, which codes for the alpha chain of type IV collagen.

The majority of the patients have an X-linked inheritance. Clinical features include hematuria, proteinuria, and sensorineural hearing loss. Ocular manifestations include anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy appears normal during the first decade of life. Later glomeruli may have mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening. This may lead to progressive sclerosis of the glomerulus. Electron microscopy shows diffuse thickening and thinning along with splitting of glomerular and tubular basement membranes. It is seen as a characteristic basket weaving appearance of lamina densa as shown below.

No specific therapy is needed. Proteinuria can be treated with angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors or angiotensin 2 receptor blockers.

questions.text:
A male child presents with poor growth. Examination reveals bowing of legs, frontal bossing, and pectus carinatum. The X-ray is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal that the disease is due to decreased dietary intake. Which of the following would not be seen in this patient?

PTH - Parathyroid Hormone

ALP - Alkaline phosphatase
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of rickets and decreased serum PTH would not be seen in this patient. PTH is elevated in rickets.

The clinical vignette describing a child with bowing of legs, frontal bossing, poor growth, pectus carinatum, and x-ray findings showing cupping and fraying of the bilateral distal metaphysis of radius and ulna with growth plate widening are suggestive of rickets. The laboratory findings on rickets would be:

  • Normal/decreased serum calcium
  • Decreased phosphorous
  • Elevated PTH, and
  • Increased ALP levels

Rickets occurs due to a nutritional deficiency in vitamin D. Decreased vitamin D leads to decreased calcium and phosphate due to reduced absorption. The decreased calcium stimulates increased PTH production. ALP level is increased as it is involved in bone mineralization.

Clinical features of rickets include general features such as malnourishment, abdominal distension, proximal muscle weakness, etc.

Head-

  • Softening of the skull bones, called craniotabes. 
  • Delayed closure of fontanells.

Chest-

  • Typical rachitic rosary i.e. widening of the costochondral junctions that give the feeling of rosary beads on palpation.
  • Harrison's groove, a horizontal groove in the lower chest, may appear from the inward pull of the softened ribs by the diaphragm during respiration.

Other bony abnormalities-

  • Vertebral column abnormalities like scoliosis, kyphosis, and lordosis can also appear
  • In the distal extremities- widening of the wrists and ankles, varus/ valgus deformities, windswept deformity (valgus on the side and varus on the contralateral side), anterior tibial bowing, etc

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A patient with breast cancer is planned to be started on a oral drug that acts irreversibly on the below step. Which of the following is the drug she is going to be started on?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the simplified pathway of the metabolism of cholesterol into sex hormones. The enzyme indicated in the image is aromatase. Exemestane is an aromatase inhibitor.

Estrogen is locally produced from androgen by the action of the aromatase enzyme. Locally synthesized estrogens play an important role in the development of breast cancer because they are estrogen-dependent for proliferation.

Aromatase inhibitors decrease estrogen synthesis and are widely used now in the treatment of breast cancer in postmenopausal women.

Aromatase inhibitors are:

  • Letrozole
  • Anastrozole
  • Exemestane (Irreversible inhibitor)

The other options do not have the specific mechanism of action shown in the question.
1- Danazol is an androgenic hormone. 
2- Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator
4- Levonorgestrel is a progestin.

questions.text: A patient infected with Bacillus anthracis is administered the adsorbed toxoid vaccine. Which of the following is used to make this vaccine?
questions.solution:
The FDA-approved Anthrax Vaccine Adsorbed (AVA) BioThrax vaccine is obtained from the culture of B.anthracis having the protective antigen factor adsorbed to aluminium hydroxide.

Antibodies formed against the protective antigen neutralize it and thus prevent attachment of the toxin to the host cell. it is safe and effective for human use. The dose schedule is 0.5 mL administered intramuscularly at 0 and 4 weeks and then at 6, 12, and 18 months followed by annual boosters. 

  • Pre-exposure: Only high-risk patients who are likely to be exposed will receive five doses, followed by boosters.
  • Post-exposure: It is given after exposure to inhalation anthrax along with antibiotics.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It causes zoonotic infection in humans. It is capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of poly-γ-d-glutamic acid. 

Virulence factors of Bacillus anthracis include:

    • Polypeptide capsule which is anti-phagocytic.
    • Anthrax toxins are made of three proteins-
      • Protective antigen (PA)- Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell.
      • Edema factor (EF)- Is an adenylate cyclase and causes tissue edema.
      • Lethal factor (LF)- Causes tissue death.

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

  • Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porter’s disease)- Black eschar at the site of entry.
  • Pulmonary anthrax (Wool sorter’s disease)- Occurs due to the inhalation of spores from infected wool. It leads to hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • Intestinal anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

Important laboratory features of this organism are:

  • Microscopy of the smears shows bacilli arranged end to end in the form of long chains. This is called bamboo stick appearance.
  • M'Fadyean reaction- when these bacilli are stained with polychrome methylene blue, purplish capsules can be visualized around the bacilli.
  • Medusa head appearance on agar plates- The colonies appear as locks of matted hair.
  • Inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin stab culture
  • Frosted glass appearance on the agar plate

questions.text: A newborn presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was diagnosed to be cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: It is a severe form of mitochondrial disorder
Very-long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are increased
Most patients die in the first year of life

questions.solution:
A cerebrohepatorenal syndrome is a rare inherited absence of peroxisomes (not a mitochondrial disorder). It occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins called peroxins, involved in peroxisome biogenesis.

It is a form of leukodystrophy (white matter lesion). Such individuals accumulate C26-C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissues and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. It causes severe neurological symptoms and most patients die in the first year of life. Very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) levels are increased in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome belongs to the Zellweger spectrum. The other two conditions in this spectrum are Adrenoleukodystrophy and Infantile Refsum disease in decreasing order of severity.

Other options:

Most patients die in the first year of life. It is autosomal recessive in inheritance, patients might be asymptomatic carriers.

There is an accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormalities in bile acid synthesis, and a marked reduction of plasmalogens.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes with complaints of chronic cough. Her chest X-ray shows hilar lymphadenopathy. Blood tests show increased levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme(ACE). Which of the following additional findings is she likely to have?

choices.text: Raised levels of White blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough, hilar lymphadenopathy, and elevated ACE levels likely has sarcoidosis. Metastatic calcification can occur in sarcoidosis and this can include the vasculature and major organs in the body.

Metastatic calcification can also be seen in renal failure, and milk-alkali syndrome. Advanced Atheromatous plaque and Monckeberg medial sclerosis present with dystrophic calcification.

Pathologic calcification is the abnormal tissue deposition of calcium salts, together with smaller amounts of iron, magnesium, and other mineral salts. It is of two types namely metastatic and dystrophic calcification.

Metastatic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in otherwise normal tissues. Metastatic calcification can be seen in interstitial tissues of the gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins. It occurs in case of hypercalcemia secondary to some disturbance in calcium metabolism. The principal causes of hypercalcemia:

  • Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH)
  • Resorption of bone tissue in multiple myeloma, skeletal metastasis, and Paget's disease
  • Vitamin-D-related disorders such as Vitamin D toxicity and sarcoidosis 
  • Renal failure causes retention of phosphate which leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism
  • Aluminum intoxication
  • Milk-alkali syndrome due to excess ingestion of calcium and absorbable antacids (milk or calcium carbonate) 

Dystrophic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in dying tissues and areas of necrosis. It occurs even in the presence of normal calcium levels. It may be seen in atherosclerosis, aging/damaged heart valves, and tuberculous lymph nodes. Papillary thyroid cancer has dystrophic calcification in the form of psammoma bodies.

questions.text: The mechanism of normal labour with the fetus in the occipito-lateral position involves internal rotation of the occiput anteriorly to 2/8th of a circle with simultaneous shoulder rotation to 1/8th of a circle. Which of the following movements takes place during restitution?

choices.text: 1/8th rotation in the opposite direction of internal rotation
2/8th rotation in the same direction as internal rotation
1/8th rotation in the same direction as internal rotation
2/8th rotation in the opposite direction of internal rotation

questions.solution:
During normal labour, movement of restitution occurs by rotating the head through 1/8th of a circle in the direction opposite to that of internal rotation.

The most common position of the fetus is the left occipito-lateral position where the vertex occupies the left anterior quadrant of the mother's pelvis.

During internal rotation, there will be anterior rotation of the occiput by 2/8th of a circle, placing the occiput behind the symphysis pubis. There is always an accompanying movement of descent with internal rotation.

Torsion of the neck is an inevitable phenomenon during internal rotation of the head. The neck cannot withstand such a high degree of torsion, so the shoulders will rotate in the same direction to the extent of 1/8th of a circle, placing the shoulders in the oblique diameter with one-eighth of the torsion still left behind.

Restitution is the passive movement of the head due to the untwisting of the neck that occurred in internal rotation.

The specific cardinal movements of labour are:

  • Engagement is the mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (in occiput presentation) passes through the pelvic inlet.
  • Descent is a continuous process that is completed with the expulsion of the fetus.
  • Flexion of the head occurs as soon as the descending head meets resistance from the pelvic floor/pelvic walls/cervix.
  • Internal rotation is the mechanism by which the occiput gradually turns away from the transverse axis. Crowning occurs after internal rotation.
  • Crowning occurs when the vulval outlet is stretched by the maximum diameter of the head and there is non-recession of the head after the contraction is over.
  • Extension occurs when the flexed head reaches the vulva.
  • Restitution is the passive movement of the head due to the untwisting of the neck that occurred in internal rotation.
  • External rotation is the visible movement of the delivered head occurring due to internal rotation of the shoulders.
  • Expulsion is the process by which the anterior shoulder comes under the pubic symphysis to be delivered and is followed by the posterior shoulder and the rest of the fetal body.

questions.text: Which of the following cells originate from Monocytes?
questions.solution:
Microglial cells are possibly derived from the circulating monocytes which migrate into the CNS during the late fetal and early postnatal life.

The cells derived from the circulating monocytes are: alveolar macrophages in the lungs, phagocytic cells in the lymph nodes, spleen and bone marrow, Kupffer cells in liver sinusoids, and microglial cells in the CNS.

Neuroglial cells found in the parenchyma of the brain and spinal cord are broadly classified as follows:

  • Macroglia cells of ectodermal origin (neuroectoderm) and include the astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and glioblasts.
  • Microglia cells of mesodermal origin.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with the following condition of toenails. The discoloration  spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later the entire nail was affected. Gradually, the entire nail became brittle and separated from the nailbed. What can be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the image of the affected nail, points to a diagnosis of Tinea unguium.

Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many other fungi may be causative.

Clinically, yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

Six distinct patterns of tinea unguium have been described:

  • Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) - Most common form
  • Superficial onychomycosis (SO)
  • Proximal subungual onychomycosis
  • Endonyx onychomycosis
  • Totally dystrophic onychomycosis
  • Mixed onychomycosis

Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curettings that include dystrophic subungual debris.

Mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis are treated topically with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine 

Oral terbinafine is the treatment of choice for Tinea unguium or onychomycosis. Oral Terbinafine at 250 mg/day is given for a duration of 6 weeks for fingernail infection and 3 months (12 weeks)  for toenail infection.

           FIRST LINE DRUG                   DURATION
 Oral Terbinafine - 250mg/day

Fingernails - 6 weeks.

Toenails - 12 weeks
Oral Itraconazole- 400mg/day for 1week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months

Oral griseofulvin dose of 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is the second-line drug.

Other options:

Option A: In psoriasis, irregular pitting of nails with subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis is seen:

Option C: Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discolouration of the nail. It is a prominent feature of hypoalbuminemic states such as renal failure:

 

Option D: In chronic arsenic poisoning, nails become irregularly thick and develop transverse white lines called Aldrich-Mees lines:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man came with complaints of fever, scrotal swelling and passage of milky white urine. He first observed the scrotal swelling 2 days ago. A night sample of blood was taken which revealed the infective agent as given below. What is the time interval from the period of entry of the infective agent to the development of scrotal swelling called?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, fever, scrotal swelling and passage of milky white urine indicate the presence of hydrocele in this patient and the peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. 

The clinical incubation period is the time between the entry of infective larvae and the development of the first clinical symptom. It usually takes 8-16 months but can be longer. 

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial nematode that causes lymphatic filariasis. The adult worms reside in the lymphatics and mechanical obstruction by the adult worms or allergic inflammatory reaction to worm antigens is responsible for the clinical manifestations of lymphatic filariasis. 

The lymphatic vessels of the male genitalia are most commonly affected in bancroftian filariasis, producing episodic funiculitis, epididymitis, and orchitis. Hydrocele is the most common sign of chronic bancroftian filariasis, followed by lymphedema, elephantiasis, and chyluria.

The infective form of Wuchereria bancrofti to humans is the third-stage filariform larva and is transmitted by the bite of the Culex mosquito. Culex quinquefasciatus is the major vector in India and most of Asia. Aedes and Anopheles have also been implicated in various regions of the world.

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

Demonstration of the microfilaria in peripheral blood, chylous urine, hydrocele fluid, etc is done. Night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am are preferred as microfilaria show nocturnal periodicity.

DEC provocation test: In this test, a small dose of DEC is given 20-50 minutes before sample collection so that the microfilaria appears in the blood even during the daytime. 

Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is the drug of choice.

The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.

Other options:

The biological incubation period (option D)/ Prepatent period (option A) is the interval between the entry of the infective third-stage larvae into the human host and the first appearance of microfilariae in circulation. It usually takes 8-12 months.

The extrinsic incubation period (option C) typically lasts 10–12 days, from the time the microfilaria enters the mosquito until the formation of the infective third-stage larva in the mosquito's proboscis sheath.

questions.text: The aim of the Montreal protocol is ______.

choices.text: To promote clean water and sanitation
To mitigate emisssions of greenhouse gases
To regulate the production of substances that deplete the ozone
To promote proper bio-medical waste disposal

questions.solution:
The aim of the Montreal protocol is to regulate the production and consumption of substances that deplete the ozone (ozone depleting substances).

The aim of Montreal protocol is to reduce the production and consumption of chemicals that deplete the stratospheric ozone layer. Substances controlled by the treaty are CFCs, halons, other fully halogenated CFCs, carbon tetrachloride, methyl chloroform, Hydrochlorofluorocarbons, methyl bromide, and Hydrofluorocarbons.

The Montreal Protocol also makes important contributions to the realization of the UN Sustainable Development goals. 

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

Greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs) are gases in the atmosphere that absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after they have left the Earth’s surface. They then emit the radiation in all directions, some of it back towards the Earth’s surface. This raises the earth's temperature.

In this entire process, the earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as the greenhouse effect. The greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.

The most important natural GHGs are:

  • Water vapor
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Methane
  • Tropospheric ozone (Stratospheric ozone is not harmful)
  • Nitrous oxide

Non-natural GHGs include chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

International protocols on climate change:

  • Kyoto Protocol:
    • Linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
    • Set internationally binding emission reduction targets for the concerned parties
    • Parties aimed to reduce GHGs by 18% from 2013-2020.
  • Paris Agreement:
    • Aims to strengthen the global response to climate change
    • Aims to maintain the global temperature rise in this century < 2°C above pre-industrial levels
    • Aims to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5°C.
    • It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, adaptation, and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • Montreal Protocol:
    • Related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of the drugs given for post-operative nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
H2 receptor antagonists are used to reduce the risk of aspiration pneumonia, not postoperative nausea and vomiting.

The drugs given for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) act by 

  • 5-HT3 antagonism
  • NK-1 antagonism
  • D2 antagonism

The 5- HT3 receptor mediates vomiting and is found in the gastrointestinal tract and the brain (area postrema). 5-HT3 antagonists like ondansetron and granisetron selectively block the serotonin 5-HT3 receptors, with little or no effect on dopamine receptors.

Substance P is a neuropeptide that interacts with neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors. NK1 antagonists inhibit substance P at central and peripheral receptors. Aprepitant, an NK1 antagonist, has been found to reduce PONV perioperatively and is additive with ondansetron for this indication. 

Dopamine receptors, particularly D2 and D3 receptors when activated cause nausea and vomiting. Dopamine antagonists like metoclopramide and droperidol block the dopamine receptors at the chemo-receptor trigger zone, thereby reducing PONV.

Risk factors for PONV:

  • Patient-specific: Female gender, non-smoking status, history of motion sickness/PONV
  • Anesthetic-specific: Nitrous oxide, volatile anesthetics, opioids
  • Surgery-specific: Increased duration of surgery, type of surgery

Drugs used in the prophylaxis and treatment of PONV:

  • 5-HT 3 antagonists - ondansetron, palonosetron
  • Butyrophenones- droperidol
  • Dexamethasone
  • Transdermal scopolamine
  • Aprepitant

Note: Propofol has antiemetic property and thus reduces the risk of PONV.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male in kidney failure with a serum creatinine of 2.1 mg/dl is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following muscle relaxants cannot be used?
  1. Succinylcholine
  2. Atracurium
  3. D-tubocurarine
  4. Cis-atracurium
  5. Pancuronium
questions.solution:
Pancuronium and d-tubocurarine cannot be administered in patients with renal failure because they are primarily excreted via the kidney and also have prolonged half lives.

Pancuronium is almost entirely dependent on the kidney for excretion (60–90%). Pancuronium has a prolonged elimination half-life in renal failure patients and thus should be used very cautiously.

40-60% of d-tubocurarine is excreted via the kidney and so prolonged effects are seen with renal insufficiency

Succinylcholine, atracurium and cis-atracurium can be used in this patient who has a renal failure with elevated serum creatinine(normal value- 0.8–1.3 mg/dL in men and 0.6–1 mg/dL in women).

Succinylcholine can be safely administered to patients with diminished or absent kidney function provided serum potassium levels are normal. If the serum potassium is increased, then a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant like atracurium or cisatracurium which is non-dependent on renal excretion is to be used. Atracurium or cisatracurium undergo Hofmann elimination which is non-enzymatic spontaneous degradation.

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text: A primigravida who contracted a parasitic infection during her 1st trimester gives birth to a baby who presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus and intracranial calcification. Transplacental transmission is suspected. The sexual form of the parasite involved develops in which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a primigravida contracting a parasitic infection during her 1st trimester, leading to the birth of her baby with the classical triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus and intracranial calcification is suggestive of Toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondi. The oocyst formed by sexual reproduction, develops in the intestines of cats and other felines.

Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular coccidian parasite that is transmitted by:

  • A newly infected pregnant woman passing the infection to her unborn fetus
  • Ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked infected meat
  • Ingestion of oocysts through exposure to cat litter or soil
  • Blood transfusion or organ transplantation 

It comes under TORCH infections which consist of toxoplasmosis, others (syphilis, hepatitis B), rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex

Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs when a pregnant woman transmits the infection to the fetus transplacentally or at the time of vaginal delivery. The severity of the disease in the neonate is greater if the woman gets infected early in her pregnancy.

The classical triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications can be seen in infected neonates. Other possible features include small size for gestational age, prematurity, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hydrops fetalis, and perinatal death.

Toxoplasma gondii which has two types of life cycles:

  • Enteric cycle
  • Exoenteric cycle

The enteric cycle occurs in definitive hosts such as cats and other felines. The exoenteric cycle occurs in intermediate hosts such as humans, mice, rats, etc.

Both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur within the mucosal epithelial cells of the small intestine of the cat. The tachyzoites and tissue cysts represent stages in asexual multiplication, while the oocyst is formed by sexual reproduction.

Oocysts containing sporozoites or tissue cysts containing bradyzoites are ingested by intermediate hosts like humans, sheep, etc. Bradyzoites and sporozoites are released in the intestinal epithelium and form tachyzoites, which divide rapidly and replicate in all mammalian cells except for red blood cells.

Tissue cysts are then formed which can occur in various organs but principally persist in the central nervous system. Tachyzoites continue to multiply and spread locally by the lymphatic system and blood, while the bradyzoites multiply slowly inside the tissue cyst.

The diagnosis can be made by real-time PCR which provides quantitative results. Sabin-Feldman dye test, IgG indirect fluorescent antibody test and agglutination test are the serological tests used.

Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine are used in the treatment. Spiramycin is administered during pregnancy to reduce the severity of the baby's symptoms.

questions.text: A microbiologist carries out a milk ring test which gives a blue ring at the top and leaves the milk unstained. Which of the following option is true regarding the most likely organism responsible for this test?
questions.solution:
The appearance of the blue ring at the top and unstained milk is indicative of A positive Milk Ring Test (MRT). The most likely organism giving positive MRT is Brucella species. They are Non-motile and aerobic.

Features of Brucellae:

  • They are non-motile, non-capsulated, and non-sporing. They are Gram-negative and non-acid fast.
  • They are strict aerobes
  • They are catalase-positive, oxidase-positive (except for B.neotomae and B.ovis which are negative) and urease positive. Nitrates are reduced to nitrites. MR and VP tests are negative

Milk Ring Test:

  •  It is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy, farms, etc. 
  • A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min.
  • If antibodies are present in the milk the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the milk remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text: A 16 year old has been​ diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 12-year-old brother, who lives in the same house has received his last booster against diphtheria at the age of 6. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the younger sibling (12-year-old) has received last booster more than 5 years ago, so a repeat booster of diphtheria toxoid along with erythromycin must be provided.

Management of Contacts 

Case Management
Complete vaccine within 5 years  No vaccine *
Complete vaccine (3 doses) with booster more than 5 years  One booster *
Less than 3 doses or status unknown  Complete primary dose + Booster *
*Erythromycin or Benzathine penicillin is give to all close contacts regardless of their immunisation status

All household contacts with diphtheria patients should be closely monitored for 7 days. Culture should be taken from both the throat and nose. All contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin), regardless of immunization status. 

Children who have not received a booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid vaccine within 5 years should be given the vaccine in an age-appropriate form. Children who have not yet received their 4th dose should be vaccinated accordingly. 

If fewer than three doses of diphtheria toxoid have been given, or vaccination history is unknown, an immediate dose of diphtheria toxoid should be given and the primary series completed according to the current schedule. 

Asymptomatic carriers of diphtheria are treated with antimicrobial prophylaxis for a period of 10-14 days. If an individual has not received a booster dose of diphtheria toxoid within 1 year, an age-appropriate preparation of the vaccine should be administered promptly. 

Droplet precautions (respiratory colonization) or contact precautions (cutaneous colonization) of cases and carriers are maintained until two consecutive negative cultures (collected 24 hours apart) are obtained after cessation of therapy.

questions.text:
An HIV patient came to the clinic with a history of diarrhoea. The stool sample subjected to Kinyoun staining revealed 4-6 µm structures as shown below. Which of the following statements are true with regard to the causative organism?
  1. The sporulated oocyst is round and contains four sporozoites.
  2. Unsporulated cyst is the diagnostic form.
  3. It has a monoxenous life cycle.
  4. Sporulation of the oocyst occurs in the soil.
  5. Nitazoxanide is used for the treatment.
questions.solution:
Statements 1,3,5 (Option C) are correct.

In the given clinical scenario, the presence of diarrhoea in an immunocompromised patient with stool sample showing Kinyoun stain-positive oocysts of size 4-6 µm is suggestive of cryptosporidiosis.

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite implicated in causing traveller's diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. The two cryptosporidium species responsible are C. hominis and C. parvum. The parasite has a monoxenous life cycle where it completes both sexual and asexual phases in a single host which is a man.

Both the infective and diagnostic forms are sporulated oocysts. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell and each sporulated oocyst is round and contains four sporozoites. The oocyst excreted in the patient's feces, can be acquired through drinking water or recreational water activities. The oocysts are immediately infectious (unlike isospora oocysts, which require maturation), and may cause autoinfection.

Once ingested, the 4 sporozoites are released from each cyst and attach to the small intestinal mucosa. It causes crampy abdominal pain and non-inflammatory watery diarrhea.

Because of their small size, they are difficult to see using routine staining and hence, acid-fast staining is done.

Treatment is mainly supportive, though nitazoxanide has been approved for use in cryptosporidium infection.

Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil

The below image shows oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis in the modified acid-fast stain.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the amino acid that would get added in the translation process shown below?

choices.text: It is formed by post-translational modification.
Its deficiency can lead to atherosclerosis and cardiomyopathy
It is coded by a stop codon.
Helps in the function of glutathione peroxidase and deiodinase.

questions.solution:
The image shows a UGA codon with a selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA which would result in the insertion of Selenocysteine. Selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid, is coded by the UGA codon, which is normally a stop codon. It is formed by co-translational modification. The protein synthetic apparatus can identify a selenocysteine-encoding UGA by the presence of the selenocysteine insertion sequence (SECIS) in the untranslated region of mRNA.

Selenocysteine is present at the active site of several human enzymes that catalyze redox reactions such as thioredoxin reductase, glutathione peroxidase, and deiodinase.

Impairment in human selenoproteins have been implicated in tumorigenesis and atherosclerosis and are associated with selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease).

Hydroxylysine and hydroxyproline  are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues which are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibres. 

Related Pearl: Start and stop codons

Start codon: AUG - Methionine

Stop codons:

  • UGA- Selenocysteine (21st Amino acid )
  • UAG- Pyrrolysine (22nd Amino acid)
  • UAA

questions.text: A patient with bilateral abductor paralysis is admitted to the intensive care unit. In order to relieve the respiratory obstruction, a tracheostomy is being performed. Which of the following is not an immediate complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Tracheal stenosis, due to tracheal ulceration and infection, is a late complication of tracheostomy and does not occur immediately.

A tracheostomy is a procedure where an opening is made in the anterior wall of the trachea and it is converted into a stoma on the skin surface. It is primarily indicated when there is respiratory obstruction, secretions, or respiratory insufficiency. It is also indicated in an intubated patient after 2-3 weeks to avoid subglottic stenosis.

Complications of tracheostomy:

Immediate

(at the time of operation)

Intermediate

(during first few hours or days)

Late

(after chronic use for weeks or months)
  1. Primary hemorrhage
  2. Apnoea due to sudden washout of CO2
  3. Pneumothorax due to injury to apical pleura
  4. Injury to recurrent laryngeal nerves
  5. Aspiration of blood
  6. Injury to esopgahus
  1. Reactionary or secondary hemorrhage.
  2. Displacement of the tube.
  3. Blocking of the tube.
  4. Subcutaneous emphysema.
  5. Tracheitis and tracheobronchitis.
  6. Atelectasis and lung abscess.
  7. Local wound infection and granulations.
  1. Laryngeal stenosis.
  2. Tracheal stenosis
  3. Tracheo-oesophageal fistula
  4. Problems of decannulation.
  5. Persistent tracheocutaneous fistula.
  6. Keloid or unsightly scar.
  7. Aspiration of tracheostomy tube fragments into the tracheobronchial tree

 

 

Mentioned below are some instruments used during the procedure. 

Cuffed tracheostomy tube:

  • It has an outer tube, an inner tube, and an obturator.
  • Presence of cuff prevents aspiration of pharyngeal secretions into the trachea and also prevents air-leak. 
  • Cuff should be deflated every 2 h for 5 min to prevent ischaemia and damage to the trachea and cartilage necrosis.

Uses:

  • Tracheostomy in an unconscious patient or in a patient on a respirator.

 

Tracheal dilator is used to keep the tracheal edges open after incision in the trachea so that tracheostomy tube can be easily inserted. 

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text:
A 65-year-old lady comes to you with a DEXA report showing T-score of -2.8 SD. Which of the following sets of serum parameters is most likely seen in this patient ?
S.No. Calcium Phosphorus Alkaline Phosphatase Parathyroid hormone
1 Decreased Decreased Increased Increased
2 Decreased Increased Increased Increased
3 Normal Normal Increased Normal
4 Normal Normal Normal Normal
questions.solution:
The DEXA report showing a T-score of -2.8 SD is suggestive of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is characterized by normal calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone levels.

T-score of -2.5 SD or lower is suggestive of osteoporosis. In this condition,the degree of mineralization remains the same. It is characterised by increased bone resorption, decreased bone formation or both. There is also a loss of structural connectivity in the trabecular bones.

Patients with osteoporosis most commonly presents with chronic back pain or pathological fractures. They present with fractures that occur without any trauma or as a result of low-impact trauma. The commonly associated fractures are of the distal part of the radius (Colle's fracture), fractures of the hip, and fractures of the vertebrae. In severe cases, the fracture of vertebrae can cause kyphosis.

DEXA scan is performed to measure bone mineral density. It helps in the diagnosis of osteoporosis and fracture risk assessment. It is used to measure the T-score.  T-score is the comparison of the bone mineral density of a patient to that of a 30-year-old healthy individual.

  • T-score greater than or equal to -1.0: normal bone density
  • T-score less than -1.0 to greater than -2.5: osteopenia
  • T-score less than or equal to -2.5: osteoporosis
  • T-score less than or equal to -2.5 plus fragility fracture: severe osteoporosis

Radiographic findings include loss of trabecular definition, thinning of the cortices, and fractures. In postmenopausal osteoporosis, wedging of the vertebra may be seen due to compression of vertebral bodies.

Treatment options include bisphosphonates, denosumab, parathyroid hormones (Preottact and teriparatide), selective estrogen receptor modulator, and romosozumab.

Other options 

Option A : These parameters are seen in Vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D aids in the reabsorption of calcium and phosphate in the small intestine. Defects in the mucosal lining of the small intestine or inadequate exposure to sunlight can lead to Vitamin D deficiency.

Option C : An increase in ALP with normal calcium, phosphorus and parathyroid hormone is seen in Paget's disease. X - ray of the affected site would show osteolytic and sclerotic regions.

Option D : These parameters are seen in chronic kidney disease. Severe CKD can lead to hyperphosphatemia due to reduced phosphate excretion and reduced ability of the compromised kidney to activate renal vitamin D.

 

 

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for osteoporosis:

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
Family history of osteoporosis
Old age
Previous fragility fracture
Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient comes to the hospital with left lower abdominal pain which radiates to the back. He also complains of increased bowel movements, nausea, fever on and off for 2 weeks, and bloody stool occasionally. On examination, the abdomen is tender and rigid. A barium enema was performed and showed a partial filling of the lumen which has a sawtooth appearance. The classification used to describe the severity of the condition is ______.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an elderly male patient with left lower abdominal pain radiating to the back, increased bowel movements, on-and-off fever occasional bloody stools, and sawtooth appearance on barium enema is likely to have diverticular disease. The tender and rigid abdomen suggest a perforation. The classification system used to describe the severity of such a condition is the Hinchey classification.

The Hinchey classification system is commonly used to describe the severity of diverticular disease complicated by perforation and is an additional tool that may be used to guide overall management. It consists of:

  • Stage I: Small, confined pericolic or mesenteric abscess
  • Stage II: Larger, walled-off pelvic abscess
  • Stage III: Generalized purulent peritonitis
  • Stage IV: Generalized fecal peritonitis

Diverticulosis refers to the condition where multiple outpouchings occur along the gastrointestinal tract without any inflammation. Colonic diverticulosis is primarily false diverticula as only the mucosa and muscularis mucosa have herniated. They occur due to increased intraluminal pressure and thus are a pulsion type of diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common location.

The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic or present with distension, flatulence, and a sensation of heaviness in the lower abdomen.

The diagnosis is confirmed by a colonoscopy or an X-ray barium enema. The barium enema radiograph shows multiple barium-coated outpouchings from the colonic wall and gives the appearance of a saw-tooth (image below). In cases of severe abdominal pain, a CT scan is preferred to avoid the risk of intestinal perforation.

A high-fiber diet reduces the incidence of diverticulosis. Antispasmodics can be prescribed to reduce intestinal spasms. Most cases of bleeding are self-limiting. If persistent bleeding is present, surgical, endoscopic, or radiological interventions can be done to reduce the bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Shimada classification describes neuroblastoma as either favorable or unfavorable histology based on the degree of differentiation, the mitosis–karyorrhexis index, and the presence or absence of Schwannian stroma.

Option C: Forrest classification is used for endoscopic findings and rebleeding risks in peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Bismuth-Corlette classification is used for bile duct tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a WHO criterion for the selection of an essential drug?

choices.text: These drugs should have efficacy and safety established
These are drugs that  satisfy the priority health needs of the population
These are drugs needed to treat emergency conditions
Single drugs are preferred over fixed dose combinations

questions.solution:
Essential medicines are not necessarily drugs used to treat emergency conditions. 

They are selected with due regard to: 

  • Public health relevance
  • Evidence on efficacy and safety
  • Comparative cost-effectiveness
  • Preference to single drugs rather than fixed drug combinations

WHO publishes a model list of essential medicines that provides a framework for individual nations to draw their own national list. The 21st Essential Medicines List, published in April 2019 brings the total to 460 drugs deemed essential for addressing the most important public health needs globally.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilious vomiting. An abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the presence of a double bubble sign which is a feature of the duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is associated with prematurity, Down’s syndrome, and polyhydramnios.

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. This is because the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases. Abdominal radiographs also show the double-bubble sign if done before orogastric tube decompression. It is treated by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis will show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble /single bubble. It is seen at 2-8 weeks of life, more commonly in boys. It presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting which can lead to hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Visible gastric peristalsis can also be observed.

Option B: Jejunal atresia on an abdominal radiograph shows the triple bubble sign. It is the most common type of gastrointestinal atresia. Presenting features include bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium.

Option D:  Colonic atresia is the least common type of intestinal atresia. A plain radiograph shows multiple dilated bowel loops, but differentiation between small and large bowel is not possible in neonates. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis. The contrast does not pass proximally to the sigmoid colon as seen in the image.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A 49 year old diabetic comes to you with severe pain and swelling over his left leg which developed following a thorn prick sustained over the same leg 5 days ago. Swelling has gradually progressed to present stage as depicted in the image below. He has a past history of penicillin allergy. Which medication would be the most suitable to administer to him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of cellulitis. It is most commonly caused by  beta-haemolytic
Streptococci, Staphylococci, and Clostridium perfringens. The point of entry may be a traumatic or surgical wound. The patient should get treatment with a penicillin-based medication; however, due to a documented penicillin allergy, administration of Clarithromycin is recommended.

Patients with cellulitis can be treated with penicillin group of drugs one of such being Flucoxacillin which possess bactericidal activity against both Streptococci and Staphylococci as a monotherapy dosed at 500mg four times a day. In patients with documented allergy to penicillin group of drugs Clarithromycin 500mg twice a day can be substituted.

Cellulitis

Definition

Painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue.

Lower limb (m/c)

Face (2nd m/c)
Etiology Hemophilus influenzae (<6years, facial cellulitis) , Staphylococcus aureus, Group B Streptococci, Vibrio vulnficus, Fungi (immunocompromised), insects bites, plant toxins,etc.
Investigations
  • Specimens obtained from fluid leaking from compromised skin and not intact skin (no yield/false positive). 
  • Serological studies
  • Doppler or plethysmography (to rule out alternative diagnosis of venous insuffuciency in the lower limb)
Treatment 

First Line 

  • Penicillin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Clindamycin

Second line

  • Roxithromycin or prophylactic penicillin/erythromycin

 Important differentials to be kept in mind while diagnosing cellulitis include :

  • Deep venous thrombosis of the leg
  • Necrotizing fascitis 
  • Acute contact dermatitis

Another entity called recurrent cellulitis is present and has been defined as 3–4 episodes of cellulitis per year despite attempts to treat or control predisposing factors. Long-term penicillin therapy, 500 mg to 2 g daily, can effectively treat repeated attacks of cellulitis. However, any preventive benefit from recurrent episodes is lost if the secondary penicillin prophylaxis is discontinued within a year. 

 

Other options :

Option A - Many centers do use Vancomycin as a treatment option for cellulitis but only if refractory to other forms of treatment. 

Option B - Cefaclor is a second generation cephalosporin which has the same structure as that of penicillin thus making patients prone to allergy to this drug as well.

Option C - Flucoxacillin is a penicillin derivative, hence cannot be used in this patient with penicillin allergy. Although, answer to this questions would have been Flucoxacillin if the patient was not allergic to penicillin.

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas-

  • Infection of the superficial epidermis.
    • It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin.
      • The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Staphylococcus

Staphylococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Furuncle/boil- Infection of the hair follicle.

The given image shows a furuncle:

 

b. Carbuncle: A cluster of several furuncles:

The given image shows a carbuncle:

 

c. Bullous impetigo: Results in large blisters called bullae, usually seen in areas with skin folds such as armpits, groin, buttocks, etc.

The given image shows ruptured bullous impetigo:

 

d. Cellulitis: It is a rapidly spreading infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, usually associated with wounds, incisions, burns, etc.

The given image shows cellulitis following an abrasion. The red streaks indicate the involvement of the lymphatics:

 

e. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliating toxin that causes peeling of the skin.

The given image shows SSSS:

 

Note: The conditions shown above are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus. It is important to remember that they may also be caused by other bacteria. Cellulitis is more commonly caused by Streptococcus.

questions.text: A patient presents with breathlessness and chest pain for 3 weeks. He had a URTI 4 weeks ago. ECG shows ST elevations and Troponin I is elevated. A biopsy of his heart is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with complaints of breathlessness and chest pain, and a biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

The inflammatory process of the myocardium is termed myocarditis. Patients mostly present with fatigue, chest pain, cardiogenic shock, and even cardiac arrest. Viruses are the most common among the infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis, and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration, as shown below.

Myocarditis begins with the direct invasion of an infectious agent(Most likely an enterovirus in this case from his URTI). It subsequently replicates within and around the myocardium, causing myonecrosis. This infiltration and replication of the infectious agent lead to the destruction of cardiac tissue. 

Myocarditis can also cause ST elevations and elevated troponins but should be distinguished from a myocardial infarction based on the duration of symptoms and past medical history. 

They are treated with supportive management. 

Other Options:

Option : Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections, and Aschoff's bodies are seen in the image below.

Option B: The myocarditis of Chagas disease has distinctive features of the parasitization of scattered myofibers by trypanosomes accompanied by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, macrophages, and occasional eosinophils. The clusters of amastigotes cause swelling of individual myocardial fibers and create intracellular pseudocysts. There is focal myocardial cell necrosis accompanied by extensive, dense, acute interstitial inflammatory infiltration throughout the heart.

The image below shows the amastigotes within a myocyte (arrow) and the surrounding inflammatory response.

Option C- Myocardial infarction presents more acutely and not with symptoms occurring over 3 weeks. Additionally the history of URTI adds support to a diagnosis of myocarditis, rather than a MI

questions.text: During a hearing assessment of a patient, he is able to tell the direction from which the sound is heard. Which of the following is responsible for the detection of the direction of sound?
questions.solution:
The lateral superior olivary nucleus is responsible for the detection of the direction of the sound. It is the starting point for the localisation of sound.

The mechanism by which it detects the direction of the sound is by comparison of the difference in intensities of the sound reaching the two ears and sending the signals to the auditory cortex that can detect the direction.

Other options:

Option B: Lateral geniculate body is seen in the visual pathway. It has two principal functions:

  • It relays visual information from the optic tract to the visual cortex by way of optic radiation
  • To gate the transmission of signals to the visual cortex. It controls how much of the signal is allowed to pass to the cortex.

Option C: The nerve fibres stimulated by the hair cells lead to the spiral ganglion of Corti, which lies in the centre of the cochlea. The spiral ganglion neuronal cells send axons into the cochlear nerve. 

Option D: Nerve fibres from the spiral ganglion of Corti enter the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei located in the upper part of the medulla. At this point, all the fibres synapse, and second-order neurons pass mainly to the opposite side of the brain stem to terminate in the superior olivary nucleus.

Related Pearl: Central Auditory Pathway

E.Coli - MA (mnemonic)

Eighth nerve 

Cochlear nuclei 

Olivary complex 

Lateral lemniscus 

Inferior colliculus 

Medial geniculate body 

Auditory cortex

Most of the primary auditory cortex is in the temporal lobe, but the association cortices extend over much of the insular lobe and even onto the lateral portion of the parietal lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen?
questions.solution:
The area marked on the visceral surface of the spleen is related to the left kidney.

The visceral surface of the spleen as shown here faces inferomedially. It has three important surface impressions i.e. the gastric impression, the renal impression, and the colic impression.  The superolateral surface is in relation to the diaphragm, and this area is separated from the gastric impression by the anterosuperior border as shown in the above diagram. The anterosuperior surface has 1-2 notches, which are thought to be remnants of the lobulated form of the spleen during embryological development. The renal impression is the area that is related to the left kidney. This impression is separated from the diaphragmatic surface by the posteroinferior border of the spleen. It is separated from the gastric impression by the splenic hilum and a small ridge of tissue. 

The spleen has two poles. The superior pole is more angulated than the inferior pole, which is broader. The superior pole is the poster-most part of the spleen, close to the vertebral column. The inferior pole is related to the colic impression, which is close to the splenic flexure of the large colon, as well as the phrenicocolic ligament (the ligament connecting the diaphragm and the colon). The inferior pole is also most likely to be injured during blunt abdominal trauma. 

The hilum of the spleen in the middle of the visceral surface is the part of the spleen where the splenic vessels, nerves, and lymphatics penetrate the splenic tissue. The tail of the pancreas has its visceral impression between the hilum and colic impression.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man who is a known case of DVT presents with sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. His ECG shows the characteristic S1Q3T3 changes. A chest X-ray was done which showed the following finding. Which of the following statements is true with respect to the V/Q mismatch in this patient?

V/Q- Ventilation/perfusion ratio.

choices.text: pO2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air
V/Q ratio of the alveolus equals to zero
Increased PCO2 in the pulmonary capillary blood

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of sudden onset pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea in a DVT patient, with ECG showing the characteristic S1Q3T3 changes and chest X-ray showing a hyper-lucent area with decreased vascularity (Westermark sign) are suggestive of pulmonary embolism. Due to the presence of dead space in pulmonary embolism (V/Q = ∞), the pO2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air.

In normal individuals, the V/Q ratio is around 0.8. The ventilated alveoli are close to perfused capillaries, which allows for optimal gas exchange. A V/Q mismatch/defect can be induced by ventilation of non-perfused lung regions (dead space), where the V/Q= ∞.

Pulmonary embolism is an example of dead space, in which blood flow to a section of the lung (or even the entire lung) is obstructed. Because no gas exchange occurs in dead space, PO2 of the alveolus will be equal to that in the inspired air. PaO2 is 150 mm Hg and PaCO2 is 0.

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system. Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

ECG changes in acute PE (shown below) are characterized by the classic S1Q3T3 changes, due to right ventricular strain and ischemia:

  • A prominent S wave in lead I (blue arrow)
  • Q wave in lead III (red arrow)
  • An inverted T wave in lead III (green arrow)

Other options:

Option A: Increased shunting in the lungs is associated with V/Q= 0(Option C). A right-to-left shunt is the perfusion of non-ventilated lung areas. As there is no ventilation to provide O2 to the blood or remove CO2 from the blood in shunt areas, pulmonary capillary blood from these regions has the same composition as mixed venous blood: PaCO2 is 40mmHg and PaO2 is 40mmHg.

Option D: Increased PCO2 in the pulmonary capillary blood is associated with a low V/Q ratio. Low V/Q areas have some ventilation, as opposed to shunts, which have none. Because ventilation is limited relative to perfusion in these locations, pulmonary capillary blood has a low PO2 and a high PCO2. 

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: A patient with recurrent attacks of gout was started on a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. His symptoms were reduced after therapy. Which of the following best defines the mechanism of action of the therapy provided?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol which inhibits uric acid synthesis is the likely drug that was added to the regimen and the mechanism by which it inhibits xanthine oxidase is via suicide inhibition.

Allopurinol inhibits the enzyme xanthine oxidase by itself getting oxidized by the enzyme xanthine oxidase and forming a metabolite known as alloxanthine which is a more potent inhibitor of the enzyme xanthine oxidase, thereby preventing the formation of uric acid and thus efficacious in chronic gout.

A suicidal enzyme is one that undergoes self-destruction in order to terminate its own activity.  

Examples of suicide inhibition are : 

  • Low dose aspirin exerts its action by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme activity in platelets, which is an example of suicide inhibition. Following irreversible inhibition by aspirin, platelet cyclooxygenase loses its ability to synthesize thromboxane. Unless new platelets are formed, this cyclooxygenase activity cannot be reverted back.
  • Inhibitors of ornithine decarboxylase which is present in the parasite Trypanosoma like difluoromethylornithine (DFMO) has been proven effective in trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).

 

Related Pearl: Some Examples of Suicidal Inhibitors

Suicidal Inhibitors

Enzyme

Allopurinol

Xanthine oxidase

Aspirin

Cyclooxygenase

5-Flurouracil

Thymidylate synthase

Penicillin

Transpeptidase

questions.text: A patient is prescribed dextromethorphan for cough. Which of the following is mechanism by which it exerts its actions and its adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Dextromethorphan is a centrally-acting NMDA receptor antagonist that is used as an antitussive. One of its major side effects is hallucinations at high doses.

Antitussives are a group of drugs that acts centrally to raise the threshold of the cough center or peripherally on the respiratory tract to reduce the tussal impulse or both.

The antitussive action of dextromethorphan is due to the d-isomer form. It is used in children above the age of 6 and in adults for cough suppression. It also antagonizes opioid receptors. (Option A and C)

Hallucinations at higher doses as well as abuse potential are its side effects. It has very little associated constipation.

questions.text: In which of the following situations should the surgeon leave a drain in the wound following a splenectomy?

choices.text: Injury to the tail of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Injury to the tail of the pancreas during splenectomy is an indication to place a drain. 

During a splenectomy, the lienorenal ligament which transmits the splenic vessels is ligated and divided. As the tail of the pancreas is also present within the lienorenal ligament, it may be injured, leading to the risk of pancreatitis, abscess formation or pancreatic fistula and further development of peritonitis. Intra-operative injury is to the tail of the pancreas is hence an indication to place a drain, whereas otherwise, regardless of the indication (elective/emergency) for surgery or type (open/laparoscopic/robotic) of operation undertaken, drains are not routinely indicated after a splenectomy.

Major Steps of Open Splenectomy:

  • Midline or Left Subcostal Incision
  • Gastrosplenic ligament opened and short gastric vessels ligated and divided.
  • Posterior leaf of the lienorenal ligament divided and spleen rotated.
  • Splenic vessels separated from tail of pancreas and ligated at the hilum.
  • Division of the phrenico-colic ligament.
  • Inspection for accessory splenic tissue.
  • Hemostasis ensured and would closed.

Complications:

  • Hemorrhage (immediate complication - requires re-exploration)
  • Left basal atelectasis
  • Subphrenic collection
  • Pancreatitis
  • Thrombocytosis
  • Opportunist Post-Splenectomy Infections : caused by capsulated organisms S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae, N. meningitidis; preventabl by vaccination.
