questions.text: A 7-year-old girl has undergone brain surgery for a suprasellar tumor that was causing her headaches and visual impairment. Histopathological examination revealed a large and heterogeneous tumor with solid and cystic components containing a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid comparable to machine oil. All of the following are true about this type of tumor, except?

choices.text: They have a high recurrence rate

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a lesion in the suprasellar lesion in a child,  with solid and cystic components and a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid described as similar to machine oil, is suggestive of craniopharyngioma which is a benign tumor. 

Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumors derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). 

Patients present with features of raised intracranial pressure, including headache that is a continuous dull-aching type and papilledema, visual impairment in the form of bitemporal hemianopia (Option B), and endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, diabetes insipidus, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypo-function.

MRI is the imaging modality of choice and they appear as calcified cystic masses in the supra-sellar region.

These tumors are usually large and heterogeneous and have solid and cystic components and a cholesterol-rich, thick, brownish-yellow fluid comparable to machine oil.

Treatment is usually by trans-cranial or trans-sphenoidal surgical resection. However, as these tumors have a high recurrence rate (Option C), surgery alone is not curative, and postoperative radiation (Option D) is always indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following tests recent memory?

choices.text: Asking the patient to name the months in reverse order
Asking the patient what they had for dinner yesterday
Asking the patient to repeat a set of numbers after some time
Asking the patient when they got married

questions.solution:
Asking the patient what they had for dinner the previous day would be a suitable test to gauge their recent memory.

Other Options:

Option A: Asking the patient to recite the months in reverse order tests their concentration. 

Option C: Asking the patient to repeat a set of numbers after some time tests their immediate memory.

Option D: Asking the patient when they got married checks their remote memory. 

Related Pearl: Tests for evaluating attention, concentration and memory

Memory:

Memory is of 3 types:

  • Immediate memory and recall are usually tested by digit span/ digit repetition test.
    • Digit span test: Digits spelled at the rate of 1 digit per second. It is of two types: Digit forward and Digit backward.
    • Digit forward: Reproduction of increasingly longer digits. E.g., Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat in the same order 2 – 4 – 8 –1 –5 –7 –9.
    • Digit backward: Reproduction of longer digits in the backward direction. Eg: Examiner says 2 - 4 –8 –1 –5 –7 - 9. The person has to repeat it backward. 9 -7 -5 -1 -8- 4- 2.
    • The above tests should be stopped when there are 2 successive failures. Hence 2 skips are not allowed.
  • Recent memory: Ask them how they reached the hospital or what they ate for breakfast.
  • Remote memory: Relevant questions from the past like close relative's birth dates. 

Attention:

  • Is the patient's attention easily aroused and sustained?
  • Digit span test.

Concentration:

  • Is the patient easily distractable or can they concentrate?
  • Serial subtraction test: Minimum of five subtractions done serially is taken into account
  • Count backward from 20.
  • Enumerate the months in reverse order.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of a constant leakage of urine and dysuria even after undergoing fistula repair surgery for vesicovaginal fistula. You decide to attempt a second fistula repair surgery. In order to perform the second surgery, you would counsel the patient to wait for at least
questions.solution:
In order to perform the second surgery, you should counsel the patient to wait for at least 3 months.

The given scenario is suggestive of failed surgery. If the fistula repair fails, one should wait for at least 3 months before attempting a second repair.

Patients usually present with constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence). The constant leakage of urine may lead to excoriation of genital regions. The fistula located at the vaginal vault post-hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

  • Latzko procedure
  • Chasser Moir technique
  • Ureteric implantation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with HIV comes with complaints of frothy urine and facial swelling. He has a past history of IV heroin use. His BP is 150/98 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a past history of heroin abuse and current HIV status, his current symptoms of frothy urine and edema of the face make focal segmental glomerulosclerosis(FSGS) the likely diagnosis.

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS is classified as follows:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy
  • Inherited
    • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6

These patients present with hypertension, edema, and nephrotic range proteinuria. 

Treatment: Prednisone, immunosuppressants to reduce the kidney injury. ACEis and ARBs to control the hypertension.

questions.text: A patient with migraine comes with complaints of recent difficulty with memory including word finding. He has also had a 4 kg weight loss without any changes in activity or diet. He has a past history of asthma. Which of the following drugs was he prescribed?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of migraine who now presents with memory deficits and weight loss most likely was prescribed topiramate. 

Topiramate is an anti-epileptic that can be used as initial mono-drug therapy for 

  • Focal seizures
  • GTCS
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in patients ≥ 2 years 
  • Chronic migraine prophylaxis when Beta blockers are contraindicated or not effective. 

Mechanism of action: Topiramate acts by

  • Reducing voltage-gated Na+ currents 
  • Activating a hyperpolarizing K+ current
  • Enhancing postsynaptic GABAA receptor currents
  • Limiting the activation of glutamate receptors. 

The drug is also a weak inhibitor of renal carbonic anhydrase and can lead to metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis causes hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria that increase urinary saturation and predispose to the formation of renal calculi.

Other adverse effects include sedation, ataxia, paresthesias, and memory deficits.

Other options:

Phenytoin is not prescribed for migraine prophylaxis, and is not associated with weight loss. 

Valproic acid is associated with weight gain and not weight loss.

Propranolol would be contraindicated in this patient as he has a history of asthma.

questions.text: As an epidemiologist, you are interested in studying largely subclinical diseases. Which of the following diseases would be appropriate to study?
questions.solution:
Rubella shows the iceberg phenomenon of disease and thus has a pre-symptomatic phase. So, it would be appropiate to study rubella as a vast majority of cases go unrecognized in the community.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

Iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B
  • Tuberculosis
  • Diabetes
  • Malnutrition
  • Hypertension

questions.text: While working in a family planning center, you have been advising couples regarding contraceptive methods. The curious interns ask you to explain the pearl index mentioned in a learning poster in the clinic. Which of the following points related to this would be incorrect?

choices.text: It is a method to measure the contraceptive efficacy
Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions
Four months are deducted from total months of exposure for abortion
The number 1200 indicates the number of months in 100 years

questions.solution:
The option stating "Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions" is the incorrect statement.

Total accidental pregnancies include every form of conception, like live births, stillbirths, or abortions, or the pregnancy that has not yet been terminated.

Pearl index:

It is defined as the number of "failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY)." It is a method used to measure contraceptive efficacy. This rate is given by the formula - 

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure.

Other options:

Total months of exposure in the denominator is calculated after deducting 10 months for a full-term pregnancy, and 4 months for an abortion.

The number 1200 in the formula indicates the number of months in 100 years.

There is a decline in failure rates with increasing duration of use with most methods of contraception but the Pearl index is usually based on a specific exposure (usually one year) and, therefore, fails to accurately compare methods at various durations of exposure.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: A  female patient presented to the OPD with a history of progressive breathlessness and cough for 3 months. A chest X-ray showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the right lung and the cut section of the infective agent is given below. Which part of the infective agent is used while performing Casoni's intradermal test?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of progressive breathlessness, cough and cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the right lung along with the image showing the cross-section of a hydatid cyst, points towards the diagnosis of hydatid disease of the lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus. Casoni's intradermal test is done to diagnose this condition which uses fresh sterilised hydatid fluid (G) from hydatid cysts. 

Casoni’s intradermal test is a type I hypersensitivity test . It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts on the forearm. An equal volume of saline is injected into the other forearm as a control. It is observed for the next 30 minutes and again after 1-2 days. A wheal response at the injection site occurring within 20 minutes is considered positive. It is followed by a secondary reaction 8 hours later.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of dog (optimal host) and wolf as the definitive hosts, sheep and cattle as intermediate hosts. Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

The larval stage of the parasite is passed in intermediate hosts, including man, giving rise to hydatid cyst which usually develops three weeks after the infection.

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

  • Pericyst (A)- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
  • Ectocyst (B)- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
  • Endocyst (F)- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

The brood capsules (C) are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces (D). In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk (E). 

The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts (I), which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand(H).

Hydatid disease most commonly occurs in the liver, the second most common being the lungs. The clinical features of hydatid disease of the lung include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and even pneumothorax. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole. Pre and postoperative chemotherapy with albendazole is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery.

The below image shows the histology of the hydatid cyst of the lung.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst which shows the characteristic water lily sign.

The water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall giving the appearance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a water lily.

Related Pearl: Skin tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Skin tests are performed by injecting parasitic antigen intradermally and observing the reaction. In immediate hypersensitivity reaction, wheal and flare response is seen within 30 minutes of injection, whereas in delayed type of hypersensitivity, erythema and induration are seen after 48 hours of injection.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency room where a neurosurgeon was available. Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) dropped by 4 points from the time of injury to hospitalization. CT scan reveals the following findings. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a CT scan shows a concavo-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of a subdural hematoma (SDH). The best treatment option for this patient with a subdural hematoma and who has a drop in GCS by 4 points is open craniotomy.

Subdural Hematoma (SDH):

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH. Elderly and alcoholic patients due to brain atrophy are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma. On head CT scan, SDH appears as a bright or mixed-density, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion (as seen in the question)

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm
  3. GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Note: Conservative management can be done in patients with a midline shift of <10 mm on a CT scan and a GCS score of 15 initially, reserving urgent craniotomy and evacuation of the hematoma in deteriorating neurological symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements describe the similarities between Foley's and Malecot's catheters?

1. Both are self-retaining
2. Both are color-coded for size
3. Both are introduced per-urethra
4. Both have a double lumen
5. Both are sized in the ‘French’ scale
questions.solution:
Both Foley's and Malecot's catheters are self-retaining (Option 1) and sized in the ‘French’ scale (Option 5).

However, a Foley's catheter is color coded for size (Option 2), can be introduced per-urethra (Option 3) and may have a double lumen (Option 4), none of which are true for a Malecot catheter.

A Foley catheter is a self-retaining sterile, latex tube with a straight tip that is used to drain urine and may be introduced per urethra. The key feature is the presence of a balloon at the tip which is inflatable, making the catheter retained at the neck of the bladder. The size of the Foley catheter is based on the outer diameter in mm according to the ‘French’ scale (1 Fr = 0.3mm) according to which the catheter is color coded. Foley catheters have one lumen for draining urine, and one for instilling sterile water for bladder inflation in the case of two-way Foley, while a three-way Foley also has another lumen for irrigation.


A Malecot's catheter on the other hand is made of red rubber and is self-retaining because of its characteristic flower/umbrella tip. It has a single lumen for drainage. It is also sized according to the French scale but has no color coding. It cannot be introduced per-urethra but may be used in suprapubic cystostomy or other urinary diversion procedures, and also for drainage of pus from abscess cavities.

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: A 69-year-old male patient with end-stage renal disease is being evaluated for low platelets 3 days after he was started on an anticoagulant for a procedure. On admission, his platelet count was 250000/mm3 and now it is 40000/mm3. Serotonin release assay is positive. What drug can be used in him for anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient developed a rapid decrease in his platelet count after he was started on an anticoagulant. He was most likely treated with heparin as he had a positive serotonin release assay. The patient requires direct thrombin inhibitors for the treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia(HIT). Argatroban is safe in renal disease.

The serotonin release assay is a test that measures serotonin release in response to heparin in patient serum and is a very sensitive and specific test for Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. 

The parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors are:

  • Argatroban - hepatic clearance, approved for the treatment of HIT
  • Lepirudin - renal clearance, contraindicated in renal disease
  • Bivalirudin- renal clearance, contraindicated in renal disease, shortest half-life

Other options:

Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin will be contraindicated in this patient due to his diagnosis of HIT

Fondaparinux is a factor Xa inhibitor. It is contraindicated in renal disease because it has renal clearance.

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants

2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors

4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a tibial fracture in a cast presented to the emergency room in a rural clinic with complaints of intense pain. Passive extension of the foot elicited pain. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were present and there was a loss of sensation over the first web space. What is the best-suited management?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of this patient with a history of tibial fracture complaining of intense pain, with painful passive extension and loss of sensation of the first web space , is suggestive of acute compartment syndrome. The next step would be to remove the cast so as to relieve the pressure on the underlying vessels.

Acute compartment syndrome refers to the rise in intra-compartmental pressure leading to tissue ischemia and necrosis. The injuries at high risk of developing acute compartment syndrome are fractures of the proximal one-third of the tibia, soft tissue injury, distal radius fracture, and diaphyseal fracture of the forearm. Other high-risk injuries are crush injuries and circumferential burns.

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps:

  • Pain: is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. On passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. 
  • Paresthesia: paresthesia and hypoesthesia are the first signs of nerve ischemia.
  • Paralysis: paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness: usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 
  • Pallor: may not always be seen as ischemia occurs at the capillary level.

The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as differential pressure (ΔP). If the differential pressure (ΔP) is less than 30 mm Hg, immediate compartment decompression is indicated.

Treatment:

  • Prompt decompression of the affected compartment is done.
  • All the dressings, bandages, and cast on the affected limb are removed and the limb is nursed flat.
  • Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mm Hg (Option A)
  • Fasciotomy wounds are left open and observed after 2 days. If there is necrosis, debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy, they can be sutured without tension or skin grafting can be done.

 

Other options :

Option A : Fasciotomy need not be done at the moment as his limb is clearly not going into grave ischemia. Fasciotomy is indicated in patients with differential pressure less than 30mmHg and in those patients in whom there is no improvement in symptoms inspite of removal of cast or dressings for a period of two hours.

Option B : Measurement of intracompartmental pressure is the gold standard for diagnosis but prime importance must be to relieve this patient's pain. All facilities may not have the facility to measure this parameter, so even a clinical suspicion deems immediate management.

Option D : Analgesics can be provided in this patient but would not aid in treating the root of his pain and i.e the ischemia to his muscles. Prompt decompression is always performed first as a ischemia time of 4-6 hours would make the muscle nonviable.

 

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a suspected brain tumour is subjected to a non-invasive test based on the principle of magnetic resonance to analyse the metabolite distribution within the brain tissue. In this test, which of the following components will show a significant rise?
questions.solution:
Magnetic Resonance (MR) spectroscopy is a non-invasive test based on the principle of magnetic resonance used to analyse the metabolite distribution within the brain tissue. The most typical pattern seen in brain tumours includes an elevation in choline accompanied by a decrease in N-acetylaspartate (NAA) and creatine, without the presence of lactate, or lipids.

Elevated choline levels reflect the rapid turnover of cell membranes (due to rapid synthesis and breakdown) and are enhanced in tumour regions with high mitotic activity. 

The below image shows magnetic resonance (MR) spectroscopy showing a choline peak and decreased creatinine levels is diagnostic of glioma.

The image below shows a normal MR spectroscopy.

It contains N-acetylaspartate (NAA), a neuronal viability signal; choline (a component of cell membranes and a marker of cellular turnover); creatine (present in metabolically active tissues); lipids (released with cell membrane disruption); and lactate (a hallmark of anaerobic metabolism).

questions.text:
What is the action of the muscle of mastication which is in close relation to the tonsillar bed?
  1. Depresses mandible
  2. Jaw protrusion
  3. Elevates mandible
  4. Jaw retraction
  5. Grinding movements
questions.solution:
The tonsilar bed is related to the medial pterygoid muscle which is a muscle of mastication. Its actions include elevation of the mandible, jaw protrusion and grinding(side to side) movements.

The tonsillar bed is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles. Outside the superior constrictor, the tonsil is related to the facial artery, submandibular salivary gland, posterior belly of digastric muscle, medial pterygoid muscle and the angle of mandible

The medial pterygoid is a thick, quadrilateral muscle with two heads. The deep head arises from the medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the superficial head arises from the maxillary tuberosity and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone. It is inserted into the posteroinferior part of the medial surface of the ramus and the angle of the mandible.

It derives its main arterial supply from the pterygoid branches of the maxillary artery and it is innervated by the medial pterygoid branch of the mandibular nerve.

The medial pterygoids assist in elevating the mandible. Acting with the lateral pterygoids, they protrude it. When the medial and lateral pterygoids of one side act together, the corresponding side of the mandible is rotated both forward and to the opposite side. Alternating activity in the left and right sets of muscles produces side ­to ­side movements, which are used to grind food.

questions.text: A patient with endometrial cancer comes with pain in her right calf which is confirmed to be a thrombus by USG. Which of the following is preferred to be used in her to prevent propagation of the clot and why?

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin, short half life
Low molecular weight heparin, more bioavailability

questions.solution:
The anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism is low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). It is the preferred agent because of more bioavailability, lack of need for anticoagulant monitoring, and a long t1/2. 

Venous thromboembolism (including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and splanchnic vein thrombosis), is a frequent complication of cancer and is the second-leading cause of death in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.

Based on the results from the Comparison of Low-molecular-weight heparin vs. Oral anticoagulants for long-term anticoagulation in cancer patients with venous Thromboembolism (CLOT) Trial, all recent guidelines now advise LMWH for cancer-associated thromboembolism. 

However, unfractionated heparin (UFH) can be used in patients with renal failure, and fondaparinux can be considered in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

Tinzaparin (LMWH) is used for maintenance treatment in patients with cancer-associated venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man comes in with symptoms of increasing pain in his forehead, swollen right eyelids, photophobia, and vesicles around his right eye, as shown in the picture below.  What treatment is most appropriate for him?
questions.solution:
This patient's growing pain around his left eye, together with the formation of several vesicles or pustules, suggests herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which is treatable with oral acylovir. Steroids are generally avoided in patients with herpes zoster because of the risk of further immunosuppression unless there is progressive ptosis, third nerve palsy or optic neuritis.

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus describes the reactivation of the varciella zoster virsus in the area supplied by the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and accounts for around 10% of cases of shingles. It can be adequately treated with the help of oral acyclovir at a dose of 800mg for a period of 7 to 10 days.

Features of herpes zoster ophtalmicus incude a vesicular rash around the eye which may or may not include the eye itself as well as hutchinson's sign which is rash developed on the side of the nose and indicates nasociliary involvement. Patients with with involvement of the nasociliary nerve have a stronger risk of developing herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

Guidelines to be kept in mind while treating patients with herpes zoster ophtalmicus include :

  • Treatment initiation within 4 days of onset of rash.
  • Intravenous antivirals may be tried in case of severe infection or if patient is immunocompromised.
  • Pain can be addressed with NSAIDs and if uncontrolled opioid analgesics may prove beneficial.
  • Systemic steroid can be tried in patients with progressive ptosis, occulomotor nerve palsy and optic neuritis as a means to retard secondary inflammation.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about summons is false?

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

choices.text: Conduct money is offered to the witness irrespective of type of case
It is a document compelling the attendance of  witness in the court
Criminal courts have priority over civil courts
208 BNS deals with punishment for non-attendance

questions.solution:
Conduct money is provided only in civil cases.

Conduct money is the fee paid to the witness at the time of serving summons. This is provided in civil cases to meet the expenses for attending the court. In criminal cases, no fee is paid to the witness at the time of serving the summons. However, in criminal cases, conveyance charges and daily allowance can be claimed by the doctor according to Government rules. 

Summons

A summons is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time, and for the purpose of giving evidence. (Option B)

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are derived from the 4th aortic arch?
  1. Arch of aorta
  2. Pulmonary artery
  3. Brachiocephalic artery
  4. Right Subclavian artery
  5. Left Subclavian artery
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1 and 4 only.

The 4th aortic arch persists on both sides and forms different structures on either side:

  • Left side: Part of the arch of aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries
  • Right side: Proximal segment of the right subclavian artery

The proximal part of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th aortic arch. The distal segment of the right subclavian artery is derived from the right dorsal aorta and the 7th intersegmental artery. 

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Various Aortic Arches

The aortic arches or pharyngeal arch arteries are a series of six paired embryological vascular structures which give rise to the great arteries of the neck and head. They are ventral to the dorsal aorta and arise from the aortic sac.

questions.text: A patient with Parkinson's disease is brought by his wife because of recent changes in behaviour. A new medication was started 4 weeks ago. He has been spending money irresponsibly over the last two weeks and recently bought a boat when they don't live near a beach. Which of the following explains his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Therapy with a D2 agonist explains his symptoms.

This patient with Parkinson's disease(PD) is now presenting with impulsivity and behavioural changes 2 weeks after he was started on a new medication, making medication-induced adverse effects the likely aetiology. Ropinirole is a selective D2/D3 receptor agonist. It is used for the treatment of PD in early disease as a monotherapy and as an add-on for Levodopa-Carbidopa. 

Ropinirole can cause multiple behavioral-related adverse effects, including gambling, impulsive shopping, and sexual proclivity. It can also cause increased daytime sleepiness and hallucinations, so these medications should be avoided in the elderly. 

Other Options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is a diagnosis of exclusion made when symptoms are not explained by any other cause. This patient's symptoms are consistent with D2 agonist side effects.

Option B: Mania is diagnosed when patients have at least 4 of the DIGFAST criteria(Distractibility, Irresponsibility, Grandiosity, Flight of thoughts, Increased Activity, Sleeplessness, Talkativeness) for at least 1 week. He doesn't meet the criteria for a manic episode. 

Option D: Parkinson-induced psychosis can cause hallucinations and delusions, which is not seen in this patient.

questions.text:
As a microbiologist, you perform a PCR test on the sputum sample of a patient who came with complaints of cough and breathlessness since 1 week. The Taq polymerase enzyme used in this test is obtained from the bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus which grows best at temperatures ranging from 55–80°C. Bacteria capable of growing at these temperatures are called _________________.

PCR- Polymerase chain reaction
questions.solution:
Taq polymerase used in the PCR test is obtained from the thermophilic bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus. Thermophilic bacteria grow best at high temperatures (55 °C - 80 °C).

It is widely distributed in soil, hot springs, and ocean sediment and is a cause of spoilage in food products. It also forms spores, which can survive extremely high temperatures. 

The optimum temperature of most pathogenic bacteria is 37 °C. Based on temperatures at which bacteria can grow, they can be classified as: 

  • Mesophilic bacteria: Bacteria which grow best at temperatures of 25–40 °C. Many pathogenic bacteria fall under this category. 
  • Psychrophilic bacteria: Bacteria that grow best at temperatures below 20°C. They are soil and water saprophytes and may cause spoilage of refrigerated food. 
  • Thermophilic bacteria: Bacteria that grow best at high temperatures of 55–80°C. They may cause spoilage of underprocessed canned food.

Halophilic bacteria like Vibrio parahaemolyticus require high salt (NaCl) conditions to grow.

questions.text: In the manoeuvre shown below, all of the following will be included in the clamp, except?
questions.solution:
The image shows the Pringle manoeuvre, wherein the structures forming the portal triad, ie, hepatic artery, hepatic portal vein and common bile duct, are clamped at the edge of the hepatoduodenal ligament. The hepatic vein is not clamped.

The Pringle manoeuvre is performed in surgery when there is excessive bleeding from the liver, to temporarily arrest the bleeding and identify the source of the bleed, and is especially helpful in traumatic liver injury. With the occlusion of the portal triad, the inflow from the hepatic artery and portal vein are controlled, but backflow from the IVC and hepatic vein persists, hence it is also useful in differentiating an arterial and venous bleed.  

It is one of the 4 P's in the management of liver injuries, which include: 

  • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug- the defects with silicon tubes
  • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

Ischemia and portal hypertension are complications that result from either prolonged clamping time during the Pringle maneuver or normal clamping time in patients with compromised liver function (eg, from cirrhosis).

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text: The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is mainly formed by __________.
questions.solution:
The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is mainly formed by the choroid plexus which is marked as 'B' in the above image.

Formation of CSF:

  • Major contributor: choroid plexuses of the lateral, third and fourth ventricles.
  • Minor contributors: Ependymal cells lining the ventricles, brain substance through the perivascular spaces.

Choroid plexus if the best answer as it is the main source of CSF formation.

questions.text: As a pathologist, you receive a brain biopsy of the frontal cortex of a patient. There are neurofibrillary tangles and contain cytoplasmic swellings that stain with silver stain. The patient's case sheet shows memory impairment as the chief complaint. Which of the following conditions is this patient likely to have and the early feature of the disease?

choices.text: Pick's disease, Loss of daily function
Dementia of Lewy bodies, Loss of daily function
Dementia of Lewy bodies, Personality changes

questions.solution:
The given histopathological sample from the frontal cortex, a characteristic swelling containing cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous Pick bodies are inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods which are found in Pick's disease which falls under the Frontotemporal dementias. One of the early features seen in this form of dementia differentiating from other dementias is early personality changes due to involvement of the Frontal lobe. 

Pick's disease is a form of Frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLDs) - tau where the affected cortical regions demonstrate progressive neuronal loss and reactive gliosis, along with the presence of cytoplasmic tau inclusions in neurons. Smooth contoured inclusions (Pick bodies) are seen in Pick's disease.

Like most neurodegenerative diseases, FTLD is associated with cellular inclusions comprised of specific proteins; the two most common patterns are those with tau inclusions (FTLD-tau) and those with TDP-43 inclusions (FTLD-TDP)

Dementia is defined as a disease process marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. Depending on the site of the cerebral lesions, the dementias are classified as cortical or subcortical.

Subcortical dementias are associated with movement disorders, gait apraxia, psychomotor retardation, apathy, and akinetic mutism. They include:

  • Huntington's disease
  • Parkinson's disease
  • Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Vascular dementia
  • Wilson's disease

Cortical dementias are associated with aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia. They include:

  • Alzheimer's type of dementia
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)
  • Pick's disease

Other options :

Dementia of Lewy Bodies : It is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies, which is an eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion that contains both neurofilaments and alpha-synuclein. In addition to dementia, a patient with probable DLB must have at least two "core clinical features" of DLB: cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder (RBD), and parkinsonism.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady who was a victim of rape was brought by the lady constable to the gynecologist for examination. The doctor examined the victim and obtained a sample in and around the vagina. Which among the following statements is false regarding this situation?

choices.text: Seminal stains can be detected by ultraviolet light
Acid phosphatase test can be used to detect seminal stain
Absence of spermatozoa in the sample collected excludes rape
Vaginal and cervical cells can be identified from the penis of the accused using papanicolaou's stain

questions.solution:
Absence of spermatozoa in the sample obtained does not exclude rape.

The seminal fluid may have been removed by washing, or discharges or there may not have been an emission, or it may have been aspermic, or ejaculation occured outside.

Other options:

  • Seminal stains can be detected by ultraviolet light
  • An acid phosphatase test is used to identify seminal stains: The prostatic secretion contains acid phosphatase. Semen recovered from the vagina retains acid phosphatase concentrations upto 36 hours after it's deposition. It is expressed in Bodansky units. Acid phosphatase test is conclusive in case the absence of demonstrable sperms or Aspermia. The absolute proof of semen is finding at least one unbroken spermatozoon or electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme detection of sperms.
  • The suspect's penis is washed with saline and the material is stained with papanicolao's stain. Vaginal and cervical cells and barrbody identification suggest recent intercourse.

Tests for blood stains

  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test

questions.text: The cervical mucous of a young female patient undergoing infertility evaluation exhibits the characteristic spinnbarkeit phenomenon. Which of the following properties is the cervical mucus associated with?
questions.solution:
At the time of ovulation, due to the estrogen effect, the cervical mucous is thin and profuse with great elasticity and can withstand stretching up to 10 cm. This phenomenon is called spinnbarkeit or the thread test for estrogen activity.

When viewed under the low-power microscope, it shows the characteristic ferning pattern due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucous secreted under estrogen effect.

During the secretory phase, due to the progesterone effect, the cervical mucous becomes tenacious and its viscosity increases so that it loses the property of spinnbarkeit and fractures when put under tension. This property is called tack.

questions.text: A patient with a 30-pack-year smoking history presents with breathlessness for 1 month. He has a past history of rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed 3 months ago for which he takes methotrexate.  A chest x-ray done 6 months ago was normal. PFT shows a FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.8 and reduced total lung capacity. What is the likely etiology of his breathlessness?

choices.text: Hypersensitivity secondary to exposure to dust
Small cell lung cancer in the mediastinum

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with complaints of breathlessness with an FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.8 (restrictive pattern) 3 months after starting methotrexate most likely has developed methotrexate-induced pulmonary fibrosis.

Methotrexate-induced pulmonary toxicity presents similar to a restrictive lung disease with an FEV1/FVC ratio of >0.7 and a decreased total lung capacity. The mechanism is hypothesized to be due to chemical pneumonitis which leads to fibrosis in a select subset of patients. The drug should be stopped immediately after diagnosis. 

Methotrexate is the disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drug (DMARD) of choice and the standard treatment for most patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Also used in cases of juvenile RA. It is a dihydrofolate reductase inhibitor. 

Adverse effects of methotrexate include hepatotoxicity, myelosuppression, and interstitial pneumonitis which can lead to fibrosis. Other side effects include nausea, loose stools, punctate cutaneous eruptions, and alopecia. Probenecid and aspirin can increase the levels of the drug and its toxicity. It is contraindicated in pregnancy, breastfeeding, leucopenia, liver disease, and peptic ulcer.

Other Options:

Occupational exposure to dust and Long term smoking can lead to an obstructive pattern on PFTs. This patient has a restrictive pattern. 

Small cell lung cancer is unlikely considering how he had a normal X Ray 6 months ago. 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: On a renal biopsy, a tumor is found to have a mixture of vessels, fat, and smooth muscles and is positive for TSC 1 mutation. Which other organ should be screened for tumors in this condition?
questions.solution:
A mixture of vessels, fat, and muscle in the presence of a positive TSC1 mutation should raise suspicion for Angiomyolipoma, a tumor seen in 50% of patients with tuberous sclerosis. These patients are at increased risk of developing cardiac tumours such as rhabdomyomas and so the heart should be screened. 

Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. It is commonly seen in adults between 30 and 50 years of age, with a female predilection. The patient can present with flank pain, palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. They can occur in the following sites: 

  • Commonly - liver and kidney
  • Less commonly - ovary, fallopian tube, spermatic cord, palate, and colon

Angiomyolipomas consist of perivascular epitheloid cells. They are composed of varying proportions of vascular, immature smooth muscle cells, and fat cells. It can present as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, especially with larger tumors, and present with sudden pain, nausea, vomiting, and hypotension.

Everolimus is used for the treatment of angiomyolipomas. Treatment should be considered for asymptomatic, growing AMLs measuring >3 cm in diameter. Angiomyolipomas do not normally require surgery unless life-threatening bleeding is present.

Note: Renal cysts appear as hypodense lesions (greyish in color) with a thin wall, with or without septations.

Imaging in renal angiomyolipoma: Demonstration of macroscopic fat is the main part of making a diagnosis. USG may show hyperechoic lesions in the cortex with posterior acoustic shadowing. In patients with tuberous sclerosis, the entire kidney is affected, producing an echogenic appearance with loss of normal corticomedullary junction.

 

 

Bosniak classification:

It classifies the renal cystic lesions mainly into four classes based on the CT characteristics.

Class I and II are benign and do not require follow-up imaging or surgery.

Class IIF requires follow-up for about 5 years to exclude malignancy.

Class III needs to be biopsied or surgically explored due to a higher risk of malignancy.

Class IV lesions are clearly malignant and need appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl with influenza is brought to the casualty with complaints of disorientation and right upper quadrant pain. Her parents had given her some over-the-counter medications for her fever. Her liver enzymes are elevated. Which of the following pathologic findings is likely in this patient?

choices.text: Schistocytes on peripheral smear of the blood
Marked microvesicular steatosis of the liver
Neutrophilic infiltrate of the gall bladder mucosa

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of influenza and over-the-counter medication use which was probably aspirin now presents with confusion and right upper quadrant pain. This should raise concerns for Reye's syndrome. The liver biopsy in Reye's syndrome will show marked microvesicular steatosis.

Reye's syndrome is an acute illness, encountered exclusively in children <15 years. Its onset usually follows upper respiratory tract infections. The actual cause is unknown, although viral agents and salicylates (aspirin) have been implicated.

Pathogenesis behind this condition is generalized mitochondrial dysfunction with structural and functional alterations of mitochondria in the liver, brain, and muscle. Liver is enlarged but jaundice is absent or minimum. It is characterized by clinical features such as:

  • Vomiting
  • Signs of progressive CNS damage
  • Signs of hepatic injury
  • Hypoglycemia

Extensive accumulation of fat droplets within hepatocytes (microvesicular steatosis) can be seen in histopathology. Extra-hepatic changes include fatty changes of renal tubular cells, cerebral edema, and neuronal degeneration of the brain.

The image given below shows microvesicular steatosis of liver.

Note: Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. 

 

Other options:

Schistocytes on the peripheral smear can be seen in Hemolytic uremic syndrome due to shearing effect of platelet thrombi on RBCs.

Diffuse axonal injury is seen after traumatic head injury and not in Reye's syndrome.

Neutrophilic infiltrate in the gall bladder can be seen in acute cholecystitis. However, this condition is not usually seen in children, and the presence of confusion with raised liver enzymes in a setting of a known influenza infection should raise concerns for Reye's syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic female in the hospital has a blackish necrotic material filling the nasal cavity. Histopathology shows broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae with hyphal elements branching at right angles. The patient is initiated on the drug of choice for the condition. Which of the following parameters should be most closely monitored?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of rhino-orbital Mucormycosis. The drug of choice used in the treatment of this condition is Amphotericin B which is a nephrotoxic drug requiring close monitoring of renal function.

Mucormycosis is a fungal infection of the nose and sinuses caused by Mucor. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID-19 patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia or uncontrolled diabetes and those immunosuppressed or on steroids.

The fungus has a strong affinity to invade arteries causing endothelial damage and thrombosis, which also favors easy spread to to involve the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain, making rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis the most common form. Clinically it is characterised by ocular and retro-orbital pain and difficulty of breathing with black necrotic material in the nasal cavity that may erode the septum. Other forms include pulmonary, cutaneous, gastrointestinal and disseminated mucormycosis.

Diagnosis by biopsy is the most sensitive. It reveals characteristic broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae with hyphal elements branching at right angles.

 

The drug of choice is the antifungal Amphotericin, administered either as Amphotericin B 0.6-1 mg/kg/day or Liposomal Amphotericin B 5 mg/kg/day which has higher CNS penetration. Nephrotoxicity is the most serious adverse effect hence regular RFT monitoring is indicated specifically with respect to the medication. The alternate drug of choice is Posaconazole. Treatment of the inciting cause or underlying predisposing factor (diabetes/COVID) and surgical debridement of necrotic tissue is indicated. In severe cases, orbital exenteration or partial maxillectomy may be required.

questions.text: An elderly woman came to the OPD with a bulge protruding from the vagina that increases in size on coughing and sneezing. Which of the following is not an origin of the muscle whose weakness has caused the above condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, an elderly woman with a protruding vaginal bulge that expands with coughing and sneezing, points to the diagnosis of pelvic organ prolapse. Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of the supports of the uterus mainly the levator ani muscle. 

Levator Ani Muscle is not attached to the pelvic brim. It takes its origin from the body of the pubis, the arcus tendinous of the levator ani (a thickened part of the obturator fascia), and the ischial spine.

Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor that maintain a constant state of contraction, thus providing a stable floor, which supports the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intraabdominal forces. 

Weakening of levator ani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra. It consists of 3 muscle components namely:

  • Pubococcygeus (anterior fibers)
    • Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
    • Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
    • Puboanalis - elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
  • Puborectalis (intermediate fibers)
  • Iliococcygeus (posterior fibers)

Nerve supply: 

  • Perineal branch of 4th sacral nerve (S4) from its pelvic surface.
  • Perineal branch of the pudendal nerve (S2, S3) from its perineal surface.

Vascular supply: Levator ani is supplied by branches of the inferior gluteal artery, the inferior vesical artery and the pudendal artery. 

Actions: 

  • The levator ani muscles of two sides together support the pelvic viscera and resist the intra-abdominal pressure during straining and expulsive efforts of the anterior abdominal wall muscles.
  • They also subserve a sphincteric action on the anorectal junction to maintain the continence of faeces in both sexes and vagina in females.
  • In the pregnant female, the shape of the pelvic floor may help to direct the fetal head into the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic outlet. 

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

  • Muscular or active support of the uterus:
    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body
    • Urogenital diaphragm
  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: A woman visits you with complaints of gritty sensation in her eyes. She is a known case of hyperthyroidism. Her ophthalmic examination shows the following finding. Her eye disease developed primarily as a result of autoantibodies acting against ?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of grittiness in the eyes (due to ocular dryness), hyperthyroidism and the image showing exophthalmos are suggestive of Graves ophthalmopathy and the main role in the development of her condition is the action of thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) on the orbital fibroblast.

Orbital fibroblasts play a key part in the development of TAO. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors have been found in the orbit's connective tissues and fibroblasts. TSH stimulates the production of inflammatory cytokines. TAO is also linked to increased glycosaminoglycan synthesis, which results in restrictive myopathy. Fat accumulation is caused by orbital fibroblast proliferation and differentiation into adipocytes.

Graves ophthalmopathy, also known as dysthyroid eye illness or thyroid-associated ophthalmopathy (TAO), is one of the most serious ocular manifestations of Graves disease. Between the ages of 25 and 50, it's the leading cause of unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults. Proptosis, eyelid retraction, restricted myopathy, and perhaps compressive optic neuropathy are clinical manifestations that could potentially be used for diagnosis.

Treatment of thyroid ophthalmopathy:

Non-surgical management Surgical management

Systemic steroids

Orbital decompression

Radiotherapy

Extraocular muscle surgery

Teprotumumab (IGF-1R inhibitor)

 Eyelid surgery

 

Other options 

Option A - The main role of the development of TAO is autoantibody or thyroid stimulating immunoglobulin against the fibroblast. Lymphocytic infilitration and edema of the extraocular muscles can play a part in the development of proptosis.

Optioc B - Tarsal plate is a component of the strutural framework of the eyelid and is made of dense connective tissue. It is not associated with the development of proptosis in Grave's disease.

Option D - Sympathetic stimulation of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle can cause the sclera to appear more exposed.

questions.text: A primigravida in her 1st trimester presents with genital prolapse. On examination, the cervix visible outside the introitus is replaced into the vagina and held in place by a ring pessary. What is the ideal time to remove the pessary?

choices.text: At the end of her 1st trimester

questions.solution:
Genital prolapse in pregnancy is treated with the application of a ring pessary which should be kept in place until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy, when the body of the uterus is sufficiently enlarged to sit on the brim of the pelvis.

Patients may present with copious vaginal discharge and a decubitus ulcer may develop if the cervix remains outside the introitus. If the uterus does not rise above the pelvis by the 16th week of pregnancy, there is a chance of incarceration of the uterus.

The symptoms are mostly pronounced in early pregnancy.

There is an increased chance of miscarriage, premature rupture of membranes and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy.

Treatment involves the application of a ring pessary to keep the cervix in place. A ring pessary is also used to treat prolapse in very elderly women who cannot be surgically managed. It is used as an adjunct to pelvic floor physiotherapy. It is also used in puerperium to facilitate involution.

The image below shows a ring pessary.

If the pelvic floor is too lax, the patient is advised to lie in bed with the foot end elevated, and the prolapsed mass is covered with a gauze soaked in glycerine and acriflavine. This is continued until the 18th–20th week of pregnancy till the prolapsed mass is reduced in size and replaced inside the vagina.

  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation

  • Pelvic floor exercises

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: Your professor in the department of anatomy comes to you with complaints of heel pain. She jogs 1km daily and teaches students throughout the day. The pain is prominent when she takes the first step out of her bed in the morning. On examination, localized tenderness was present over the medial aspect beneath the heel. What is the most appropiate next step in management ?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pain and tenderness in the sole which worsens on standing or walking after rest is suggestive of plantar fasciitis which can be best managed initially with rest, NSAIDs, ice packs and stretching exercises.

Plantar fasciitis is a painful condition of the sole of the foot that limits normal functions. The plantar fascia or aponeurosis is seen to be thickened, stiff, and may have micro-tears. Typically, the pain worsens while patients stand or walk from a resting position, often when waking up in the morning.

They have a localized tenderness at the medial aspect beneath the heel. An X-ray often shows a calcaneal spur which is associated with plantar fasciitis but is not causative.

It is managed with proper rest and NSAIDs. Night splints can be used for the prevention of stiffening of the plantar fascia.

Other options:

Option A : Imaging of the heel is not required as reproducibility of pain on palpation of the medial aspect of the heel is sufficient for diagnosis. USG due to its lower cost has been increasingly been used to aid in the diagnosis, with >4mm thickness of the plantar fascia providing high sensitivity and specificity. However, utility is low becasue of the high clinical accuracy on examination of the affected heel.

Option C : MRI may help distinguish between plantar fasciitis and stress fractures. MRI can also be used to confirm the diagnosis of plantar fasciitis but due to excellent remission with conservative management the need to perform MRI is not relevant. 

Option D : Some patients may get anxious about the idea of injecting steroid into the lesion. Also, injecting steroids may temporarily help in relieving the pain but has been found to lead to rupture of the plantar fascia.

questions.text: In the examination of an ulcer, which of the following is best assessed by palpation?
questions.solution:
The base of an ulcer is better felt than seen and hence should be assessed by palpation.

An ulcer is defined as a break in the continuity of the epithelium or mucous membrane with molecular death. Classically an ulcer is described to have four parts which are: margin, edge, floor and base.

 

The margin is defined as the junction between the normal epithelium and the ulcer.

The edge is defined as the part between the margin and the floor. Five types of ulcer edges are commonly described as follows:

The floor is defined as the exposed surface of the ulcer. It is better seen than felt, and may contain granulation tissue, discharge or slough. Trophic ulcers have bone as the floor due to their depth.

The base is defined as the structure on which the ulcer rests, eg, bone or soft tissue. It is better felt than seen.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man diagnosed with type-2 diabetes mellitus is being treated with metformin. Failing to supplement with vitamins may result in a deficiency manifestation that would correspond to which specific regions of the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
A vitamin  B12 deficiency is most likely in this patient and the green areas of the spinal cord most likely affected is correctly represented in Image D which shows involvement of the dorsal columns and the lateral corticospinal tract as depicted in the the histological section below.

 

 

Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels as well as the lateral corticospinal tracts and the cerebral cortex.

Required daily allowance of B12 1–2 mcg/day. Pregnant and lactating mothers require to consume 2mg/day. 

Patients with SACD present with the following features:

  • Loss of vibration sense and proprioception 
  • Paresthesia - upper limb paresthesias occur before lower limbs are affected.
  • Unsteady gait - due to sensory ataxia 
  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Optic neuropathy - can present as blurring of vision 
  • Psychiatric manifestations such as:
    • Irritated behavior
    • Severe dementia 
    • Frank psychosis

MRI spine shows myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Myelopathy of SACD tends to be diffuse rather than focal. Image showing the same is as follows.

Treatment is replacement therapy with 1000 μg of intramuscular vitamin  B12 repeated at regular intervals or by oral vitamin  B12.

Regimen is 1000 μg of intramuscular  B12 daily for 1 week , then weekly for one month and monthly for the remainder of the patient's life. 

Oral  B12 is not given to patients with neurological disease.

 

Image A: The anterior horn of the spinal cord is highlighted in green in this image. Spinal muscular atrophy is a genetic disease characterized by progressive degeneration of anterior horn cells, which results in weakness. 

Image B : Image B correctly represents the areas of the spinal cord affected by amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). The pathologic hallmark of ALS is the death of the affected lower motor neurons (LMN) consisting of the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord and their homologues in the brainstem, upper motor neurons (UMN) consisting of the corticospinal tract and corticobulbar tract originating in the motor cortex. Image B has the anterior horn of the spinal cord and the corticospinal tracts highlighted in green.

Image C: The dorsal column and dorsal root of the spinal cord are highlighted in green in this image. Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts seen in tertiary syphilis, primarily involving the dorsal columns of the spinal cord, dorsal roots, and dorsal root ganglia.

questions.text: A patient with a prosthetic heart valve comes with complaints of bloody stools. His INR is found to be 5. Which of the following drugs was he also likely taking?
questions.solution:
This patient who takes warfarin for anticoagulation now presents with bleeding in the GI tract, most likely due to the increased concentration of warfarin in his blood. This is evidenced by his raised INR. Warfarin is metabolized by Cyp 450 enzymes and out of the given options, only ciprofloxacin is a inhibitor of CYP 450. 

Fluoroquinolones inhibit topoisomerase IV in gram-positive bacteria.

Fluoroquinolones are used in the treatment of urinary tract infections, prostatitis, and gastrointestinal, respiratory infections, and as a second-line drug in anti-tubercular therapy. They are avoided in children and pregnant women.

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones are arthralgia, tendon rupture, Clostridium difficile colitis, dysglycemia, prolonged QT interval, rashes, hallucinations, delirium, and seizures. 

NSAIDs can lead to CNS toxicity when co-administered.

Plasma concentrations of theophylline, caffeine and warfarin can all increase with concurrent fluoroquinolone administration due to inhibition of CYP 450. 

Other options:

Phenytoin, Griseofulvin and Rifampicin are all inducers of cytochrome.

questions.text: Which of the following neurodegenerative disease has superoxide dismutase 1 inclusions?
questions.solution:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has superoxide dismutase type 1 (SOD1) inclusions.

It is a form of motor neuron disease that includes upper and lower motor neuron pathology. It is a progressive disease occurring due to the accumulation of mutated SOD1 proteins causing increased free radicals followed by cellular injury of neurons and apoptosis. The disease is characterized by asymmetrical weakness and spasticity of arms and legs.

questions.text: As a resident in the emergency department, you are asked to follow the  BLUES and FALLS protocols while performing an ultrasound on a patient. Which of the following organs are you examining in this condition?
questions.solution:
The bedside lung ultrasound in emergency (BLUE)-protocol for the immediate diagnosis of acute respiratory failure and the fluid administration limited by lung sonography (FALLS)-protocol for the management of acute circulatory failure are two protocols adopted from lung ultrasonography.

Point of care ultrasonography (POCUS) is advanced diagnostic ultrasonography performed and interpreted at the bedside by the attending physician. POCUS has been widely utilised as a quick diagnostic technique in various areas, particularly emergency medicine.

Profiles for illnesses such as pneumonia, congestive heart failure, COPD, asthma, pulmonary embolism and pneumothorax have been created with an accuracy of 90% in the BLUE protocol.

The FALLS approach sequentially eliminates obstructive, cardiogenic, and hypovolemic shock in order to speed up the identification of distributive (septic) shock.

These applications are performed with inexpensive grayscale machines with a single microconvex probe suitable for the whole body. Lung ultrasonography is a powerful tool also useful for decreasing radiation doses (particularly in newborns) from ARDS to trauma treatment, and from ICUs to points of care.

questions.text: A 1-month-old child who is being exclusively breastfed develops bluish discoloration of skin, breathing difficulty, and a soft cry. On evaluation, cardiomegaly is detected. The mother, who is accustomed to consuming polished rice, has no symptoms of illness. Which of the following vitamins may be deficient in the mother?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of cyanosis, dyspnea, and aphonia, seen here as bluish discoloration of skin, breathing difficulty, and a soft or weak cry, associated with cardiomegaly in a breastfed infant of a mother accustomed to consuming polished-rice, is suggestive of Infantile Beriberi, due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency in the mother.

Infantile beriberi occurs in breastfed infants of thiamine-deficient mothers, wherein the mother may be asymptomatic but the child presents with the symptoms and signs of cyanosis, dyspnea, aphonia and cardiomegaly. Untreated infantile beriberi may be fatal within a few weeks. Thiamine deficiency causes beriberi, commonly seen in low socio-economic status where polished rice which is thiamine deficient, is consumed. The condition may present in three varieties:

1. Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability. Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults.

2. Wet beriberi results due to cardiac and renal dysfunction which leads to fluid accumulation. It is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema.

3. Infantile beriberi, as described above.

Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Treatment with thiamine leads to resolution of neurologic and cardiac symptoms within 24-48 hours. Treatment of patients with mild beriberi with thiamine (5 mg/day) is satisfactory. Severely ill children should receive 10 mg intravenously twice daily. 

Other options:

Option A: Riboflavin deficiency can present with cheilosis, but it does not typically cause pedal edema and cardiomegaly.

Option C: Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, anemia, and dermatitis but is not associated with pedal edema, cardiomegaly, and cheilosis.

Option D: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency leads to pellagra, characterized by the triad of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It is not associated with pedal edema, cardiomegaly, and cheilosis.
