questions.text:
In response to an increase in the GFR, the area marked 4 demonstrates an increase in the rate of Na+ reabsorption. This phenomenon is called _____________.

GFR- Glomerular filtration rate
questions.solution:
In the given image, the area marked 4 is the cells of the proximal convoluted tubule which are involved in sustaining glomerulotubular balance, a mechanism by which the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes is maintained at constant levels. This is achieved by increasing the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule in response to increased GFR.

For example, if the GFR increases from 125 to 150 ml/min, the absolute rate of proximal tubular reabsorption also increases from about 81 ml/min (65% of GFR) to approximately 97.5 ml/min (65% of GFR). Therefore, even when the total rate of reabsorption and filtered load rise, the proportion of GFR reabsorbed in the proximal tubule stays relatively constant, at around 65%.

The given illustration shows:

1- Macula densa: These are specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule form the macula densa. 

2- Granular cells/JG cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole; these are mechanoreceptors that secrete renin in response to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn, increases the blood pressure. 

3- Lacis cells: These are extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. 

Other options: 

Option A: Renal splay is the deviation in the actual renal threshold from the calculated renal threshold. If all the tubules in the nephron worked at a given time, then the renal threshold would be 300mg/dL, that is, 375 mg/min (TmG-transport maximum) divided by 125 mL/min (GFR). However, the actual renal threshold is 200mg/dL. This is because, at a given time, not all tubules are reabsorbing the glucose. 

Option B: Renal autoregulation maintains the renal blood flow to almost a constant level irrespective of arterial perfusion pressure within physiological limits. It is due to the action of vascular smooth muscles in renal afferent arteriole, which respond to stretch caused by blood pressure. This relative constancy of GFR and renal blood flow is referred to as autoregulation. 

Option C: Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) changes the rate of filtration and tubular flow by reflex vasoconstriction or dilatation of the afferent arteriole. It is mediated by specialized cells in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle called the macula densa that act as sensors of solute concentration and tubular flow rate.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient who presented with anovulatory cycles was diagnosed with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Which of the following categories under the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification represents this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of anovulatory cycles in a patient with polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is represented by the letter 'O' which stands for ovulatory dysfunction according to the FIGO PALM-COEIN classification for abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).

It is represented as P0A0L0M0–C0O1E0I0N0.

PALM-COEIN classification of AUB:

  • Polyp (AUB-P):
    • Endometrial polyps
    • Endocervical polyps
  • Adenomyosis (AUB-A)
  • Leiomyoma (AUB-L). Fibroids are further classified as:
    • Submucosal (SM)
    • Other (O)
  • Malignancy and hyperplasia (AUB-M):
    • Endometrial hyperplasia
    • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Coagulopathy (AUB-C)
    • von Willebrand's disease
    • Hemophilias
  • Ovulatory dysfunction (AUB-O)
    • PCOS
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Hyperprolactinemia.  
  • Endometrial causes (AUB-E)Tubercular or chlamydial endometritis
  • Iatrogenic causes (AUB-I)
    • Intrauterine contraceptive devices
    • Anticoagulants
    • Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Not yet classified (AUB-N) includes rare causes such as
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Myometrial hypertrophy

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is safest to use in a patient with a history of osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Out of the drugs listed above, fondaparinux has the least incidence of osteoporosis after prolonged use. 

Fondaparinux is an antithrombin activator.

It is a synthetic analog of the pentasaccharide unit of heparin that binds and activates antithrombin. Activation of antithrombin causes the inactivation of factor Xa. So it is also described as an indirect factor Xa inhibitor.

It has similar efficacy to Low molecular weight heparins(LMWH) and Unfractionated heparin with the additional benefit of not causing osteoporosis. It does not require lab monitoring. 

Indications for fondaparinux:

  • Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism treatment and prophylaxis.
  • Acute coronary syndrome when no immediate intervention is planned

Other options:

Unfractionated heparin has the biggest association with osteoporosis, LMWH can also cause osteoporosis but the incidence is lesser compared to UFH.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is taken up for emergency surgical exploration due to a suspected left sided testicular torsion. On table, the testis is deemed viable. What would be the suitable surgical decision in this case?
questions.solution:
Detorsion of the cord within 6 hours in a case of testicular torsion may salvage testis. If the affected testis is viable after the cord is untwisted, both the affected and the contra-lateral testes are fixed to the scrotum using non-absorbable sutures, as the anatomical predisposition would most likely be bilateral and use of absorbable sutures may lead to recurrence of torsion.

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised. It is a surgical emergency and if left untreated, the testes may become gangrenous. Early surgery undertaken to untwist the testis gives a better outcome .

The following are anatomical predispositions to testicular torsion:

  • High investment of the tunica vaginalis causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality
  • Inversion of the testis. The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.
  • Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis. This allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.
 

Males in the age group of 10-25 years present with acute scrotal or groin pain with associated nausea and vomiting. On examination, the scrotum appears swollen and tender. The affected testis may be seen to be positioned higher (Deming's sign) while the contralateral testis may be seen to be position horizontally (Angell's sign).  

A doppler ultrasound may be taken to assess the blood supply but surgical exploration is still indicated as a clinical decision. If the testis is infarcted after the cord is untwisted, an orchidectomy must be undertaken and the opposite testis must be fixed to the scrotum to preserve fertility and prevent torsion. If the affected testis is viable after the cord is untwisted, both the affected and the contra-lateral testes are fixed to the scrotum (bilateral orchiopexy) using non-absorbable sutures.

questions.text: A primigravida during her first antenatal visit expressed her concern that most women in her family had experienced difficulty during delivery due to the characteristic shape of their pelvis. You diagnose her to have the same pelvic anatomy by estimating the sacral angle. According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification, which of the following types of pelvis is most likely associated with this patient?
questions.solution:
According to Caldwell and Moloy's classification of the pelvis, difficult delivery is commonly associated with the android pelvis and it is the only pelvis with a sacral angle of less than 90° while all others have a sacral angle of more than 90°. Therefore in the above scenario, you are able to diagnose this patient with an android pelvis by just calculating the sacral angle which would be <90°.

The female pelvis can be divided into 4 types based on the pelvic inlet's shape as follows:

  • Gynecoid
  • Anthropoid
  • Android
  • Platypelloid

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal care clinic at 30 weeks of gestation. You are asked to perform a detailed physical examination on her and document the findings in the case sheet. Which of the following cardiovascular findings would be specific to a pathological cardiac condition, if documented?
questions.solution:
Grade 4 early diastolic murmur documented is specific to a pathologic cardiac condition in a pregnant female. Any diastolic murmur is never a part of the physiological change in pregnancy. 

Physiological changes in pregnancy

Cardiac output remains elevated throughout (maximum in the immediate postpartum period)

Clinical examination

  • Pulse rate: Increases
  • Pedal edema: although it can be a sign of cardiac disease, it is also a normal physiological change in pregnancy. (Option A)
  • The resting pulse rate increases by 10 beats/min
  • Diastolic BP: Decreases
  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • The heart is displaced upwards and to the left
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • S1 M increased and widely split
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • Occasional but prominent S3 at mitral area (Option D)
  • Murmurs
    • Ejection systolic murmur at the left sternal border. (Option B)
    • Continuous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)

ECG changes

  • Left axis deviation (due to elevation of the diaphragm)
  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement.
  • Mild ST changes in the inferior leads.
  • Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is a left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension 
  • Increased left ventricular mass

X-ray:

X-ray shows a larger cardiac silhouette (due to benign pericardial effusion and shifted apex).

Clinical indicators of heart disease during the pregnancy

Symptoms:

  • Progressive dyspnea or orthopnea
  • Nocturnal cough
  • Hemoptysis
  • Syncope
  • Chest pain 

Clinical signs:

  • Cyanosis
  • Clubbing of fingers
  • Persistent neck vein distention
  • Systolic murmur grade 3/6 or greater
  • Diastolic murmur
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Persistent tachycardia and/or arrhythmia
  • Persistently split S2
  • Fourth heart sound (S4)
  • Features of pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: As a PHC officer, you received blue color tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid under the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme. These tablets can be given to which of the following beneficiaries under this programme?
questions.solution:
Among the given beneficiaries, blue color tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid can be given to  adolescent boys of age 10-19 years according to the Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme.

Blue color tablets containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid can be given to school-going adolescent girls and boys of 10-19 years and out-of-school adolescent girls of age 10-19 years. Out-of-school adolescent boys are not beneficiaries of the scheme.

The Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It focuses on six target beneficiary groups, through six interventions and six institutional mechanisms to achieve their target by 2022. (6x6x6 strategy)

 

Interventions include:

  • Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation.
  • Deworming.
  • Intensified year-round Behaviour Change Communication Campaign (Solid Body, Smart Mind) including ensuring delayed cord clamping in newborns.
  • Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment.
  • Mandatory provision of Iron and Folic Acid fortified foods in government-funded health programs.
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis.

Other options :

Option A : Children between 5-9 years of age are given pink color sugar-coated tablets containing 45 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid tablets once a week.

Option C : Children of age 6-59 months are given bi-weekly syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron + 100 mcg of folic acid. 

Option D : Lactating mothers of 0-6 month-old children are given a daily dose of 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid. These tablets are sugar-coated and red in color.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

questions.text: A 20-month-old child is noted to have weight-for-height <3SD, MUAC < 11.5cm, and bipedal edema. In the management of this child, which of the following is not supplemented in the stabilization phase?
questions.solution:
A child with weight-for-height <3SD, MUAC < 11.5cm, and bipedal edema, satisfies the WHO criteria for being diagnosed with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) and requires hospital management. In the management of this child, micronutrients are supplemented in the stabilization phase, but iron is not supplemented during this phase.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

  1. Initial stabilization phase (Week 1): It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.
  2. Rehabilitation phase (Weeks 2-6): It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks.

Micronutrient deficiency correction begins in the stabilization phase, but iron supplementation begins in the rehabilitation phase as excess iron leads to free radical injury.

The 10 steps in SAM management are outlined below:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14. (Option A)
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1) (Option B)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day) (Option C)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL.  After 3 days, transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

questions.text: Which among the following is the active principle present in the dried fruit shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the seeds of Semecarpus anacardium, and its active principles are semicarpol and bhilawanol.

Common names are marking nut, bhilwan, bibva, bhela, and oriental cashew.

The juice when applied locally to the skin produces irritation, painful blisters, itching, and eczematous eruption. The seeds are used to produce an artificial bruise. Symptoms such as pain, fever, and painful passage of brownish urine may be seen.

A large dose taken orally can produce blisters in the mouth and throat, with gastroenteritis. It also produces dyspnea, cyanosis, tachycardia, coma, and death. The fatal period is 12 to 24 hours.

Medicolegal importance is the use of the juice by malingerers to fabricate wounds. Instilled in the eyes it can cause conjunctivitis or ophthalmia due to its local irritant effect.

Other options

Option A: Calotropin is one of the active principles of Calotropis.

Option C: Abrin is the active principle of Abrus precatorius

Option D:  Ricin is the active principle of Ricinus communis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs will not be used in his management?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation followed by CPR and amiodarone, adrenaline, and lidocaine given alternatively as per the ACLS guidelines. Verapamil is not a part of the ACLS algorithm for the management of VF. (Option A)

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

Along with defibrillation, CPR should be given for 2 minutes and alternated with Epinephrine 1mg or Lidocaine/Amiodarone. At the same time, any reversible causes of Vfib should be treated. 

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

The adult cardiac arrest algorithm is based on the AHA guidelines as shown below.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient who previously underwent surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm, now complains of severe abdominal pain with bloody diarrhoea. On examination, his BP is 90/60 and guarding is noted. Ischemia of the large bowel is suspected. Which of the following signs is likely to be seen on an abdominal radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with an acute abdomen, bloody diarrhoea and hypotension in the background of abdominal aortic aneurysm repair, is suggestive of ischemic colitis. Thumbprinting sign, which occurs due to mucosal edema and submucosal hemorrhage, is characteristic on plain abdominal radiograph.

Ischemic colitis occurs due to interruption or decrease in colonic blood flow. It may occur with many different conditions, including embolism from cardiac disease, low-flow states such as congestive heart failure, sepsis, and vasopressor use. Major vascular surgery (both open and endovascular repair), especially involving the abdominal aorta, is a well-known risk factor for developing ischemic colitis, due to possible compromise of the inferior mesenteric artery.

Although any area of the colon may be affected, the watershed areas of the splenic flexure (Griffith’s point) and the rectosigmoid (Sudeck’s point) are the most prone to ischemia because of the often incomplete anastomoses of the marginal artery which connect the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) and the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) in these locations. 

Other options:

Option A: Cupola sign is a sign of pneumoperitoneum wherein accumulation of air under the central tendon of the diaphragm is noted on plain x-ray.

Option B: Coffee-bean sign or omega sign on plain x-ray is seen in sigmoid volvulus when the sigmoid colon is twisted about its axis.

Option D: Stepladder sign is seen in small bowel obstruction due to the presence of air in the bowel causing the valvulae conniventes of the jejunum to be seen clearly, appearing to show a laddering effect.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count <300/μL presents with complaints of pain on swallowing and retrosternal chest pain for which esophagitis is suspected. Which of the following type of findings is most likely to be seen on UGI scopy?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an HIV +ve patient with dysphagia and retrosternal chest pain is suggestive of Candida Esophagitis.  On UGI endoscopy Candida esophagitis is likely to show yellowish-white adherent pseudomembranes composed of densely matted fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells covering the esophageal mucosa. 

Oropharyngeal and GI diseases due to secondary infection are common in HIV patients with CD4 count <300/μL. Patients with esophagitis present with complaints of odynophagia, achlorhydria, and retrosternal chest pain. In case of HIV positive patients with suspected esophagitis, oral fluconazole may be started empirically, with endoscopy being indicated to rule out other possible causes in the absence of improvement.

Image B shows the presence of series of rings, strictures and linear furrows described as feline esophagus seen in eosinophilic esophagitis.

Image C shows serpiginous ulcers seen in CMV esophagitis which commonly occurs in transplant recipients on immunosuppresants.

Image D shows vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers) seen in HSV esophagitis.

Related Pearl: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.

questions.text: A study was conducted in a group to study the association between consumption of alcohol and esophageal cancer, with smoking being noted as a plausible confounding factor. Which of the subsequent characteristics of smoking is essential for it to be deemed a confounding variable?

choices.text: Its high prevalence in a society
Its equal distribution among alcoholics and non alcoholics

questions.solution:
In this scenario, cigarette smoking is related to both the outcome of esophageal cancer and consumption of alcohol. Thus, this is an example of a confounding factor and in order for it to be deemed so smoking must have properties common with the exposure and the outcome of interest.

A confounding factor is defined as one which is associated with both exposure and outcome and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. In this study to determine the role of alcohol in the etiology of esophageal cancer, smoking is considered as a confounding factor because:

  • It is associated with the consumption of alcohol (exposure).
  • It is an independent risk factor for oesophageal cancer (outcome).

In these conditions, the effects of alcohol consumption can be determined only if the influence of smoking is neutralized by matching.

Other options :

Option B : Smoking must be related to the exposure ie those consuming alcohol as well as the outcome ie esophageal cancer. 

Option C : A confounder need not be considered if its present in a highly prevalent population. Smoking can still be considered a confounder if its present in populations with lower prevalence.

Option D : Smoking can be present in either the alcholic or non alcoholic group but is not evenly distributed among both groups.

questions.text: A patient presents with elbow deformity and forearm shortening after a fall. An X-ray was done and given below. What is the most common complication associated with this condition ?
questions.solution:
The lateral X-Ray of the elbow shows the coronoid process of the ulna lying posterior to the condyles of the humerus, which along with the clinical history points to this being a case of posterior dislocation of the elbow. The most common complication associated with elbow dislocation is stiffness at the elbow or restricted movement (extension) of the elbow joint.

Other rare complications of elbow dislocation include

  • Myositis ossificans (Option B)
  • Neurovascular injury
  • Recurrent dislocation or redislocation (Option C)
  • Open fractures (Option D)

Elbow dislocation is the most common dislocation in the pediatric age group and the second most common dislocation after the shoulder in adults.

Posterior dislocation is the commonest type of elbow dislocation. It frequently occurs due to a fall on the outstretched hands with the elbow slightly flexed. Other dislocations are postero-medial, postero-lateral, and divergent.

Anterior dislocation occurs when the elbow is flexed and there is a direct blow on the posterior aspect of the elbow joint.

Clinical features

  • The forearm appears shortened.
  • Crepitus is absent.
  • The three-point bony relationship is disrupted.
  • Olecranon is above the intercondylar line

Elbow dislocation is an emergency and has to be reduced immediately. Closed reduction under general anaesthesia(GA) is attempted first. An above elbow POP slab is applied with 90º elbow flexion and mid-pronation for a period of 3 weeks after closed reduction under GA.

Stimson’s 2 step principles for closed reduction

  • step 1 - traction along the long axis of the humerus to counteract the contraction of biceps, triceps and brachialis
  • step 2 - traction along the long axis of the forearm to bring radius and ulna back into position

2 techniques in closed reduction

  • Prone technique- Grab the wrist of the injured arm. Apply traction and slight supination to the forearm. Using the other hand, apply pressure to the posterior aspect of the olecranon while the arm is pronated
  • supine technique- a helper stabilizes the humerus against the stretcher with both hands. Grasp the wrist, and apply slow, steady, inline traction, keeping the elbow slightly flexed and the wrist supinated

Early complications include neurovascular injury. Vascular injuries are rare and involve the brachial artery in open fractures associated with elbow dislocation.

Late complications include myositis ossificans, recurrent dislocations, proximal radioulnar translocation, and ectopic calcifications

The terrible triad of elbow (also known as Hotchkiss triad) includes

  • Posterior dislocation of the elbow
  • Radial head fracture
  • Fracture coronoid process of ulna

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a history of ear pain and diminished hearing, associated with fever. On otoscopy, the following finding is noted. Which of the following stages of the disease is the patient presently in?
questions.solution:
The image shows a perforated tympanic membrane with draining pus. In Acute Suppurative Otitis Media (ASOM), rupture of the tympanic membrane occurs in the stage of resolution. 

The stage of resolution comes after the stage of suppuration. Pus collection reaches enough pressure and causes the TM to rupture, usually in the antero-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa. The child's ear pain gets relieved and the fever comes down. A blood-tinged mucopurulent discharge is seen in the external auditory canal. If proper treatment is initiated during suppuration or the infection is mild, resolution may occur without tympanic perforation.

questions.text: You see a patient receive the treatment shown in the image for severe depression. Which of the following medications should be stopped prior to the procedure?
questions.solution:
Clozapine should be stopped prior to the procedure.

The image shows a patient receiving Electroconvulsive therapy. Clozapine is contraindicated prior to Electroconvulsive therapy as it causes the development of late-appearing seizures. 

ECT was introduced as a treatment modality for schizophrenia by Ugo Cerletti. ECT is useful in the treatment of:

  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Catatonia
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Delirium
  • Episodic psychoses, atypical psychoses
  • Medical conditions such as: 
    • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
    • Hypopituitarism
    • Intractable seizure disorders
    • The on-off phenomenon of Parkinson's disease.

Other medications to be withdrawn before ECT:

  • Benzodiazepines 
  • Clozapine 
  • Buproprion 
  • Theophylline 
  • Reserpine  

Note: Tardive seizure is a rare complication of ECT. These are seizures that occur after the completion of treatment once the patient has regained consciousness. β-lactam antibiotics and ciprofloxacin have been associated with tardive seizures.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: Which of the following conditions in a child would not be associated with a head circumference <3 SD below the mean for age and sex?
questions.solution:
Of the listed conditions, achondroplasia is associated with macrocephaly, whereas the others are all associated with microcephaly.

Head circumference in a child is measured as the maximum circumference from the external occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges and is one of the important anthropometric measurements in the assessment of growth and development. Based on this:

  • Microcephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference <3 SD below the mean for age and sex.
  • Macrocephaly is defined as an occipitofrontal circumference >2 SD above the mean for age and sex.

Important causes of microcephaly include:

  • Syndromic: Trisomies 21, 18, 13, Monosomy 1p36 deletion
  • Neural tube defects
  • Perinatal Insult: Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, hypoglycemia
  • Metabolic disorders: Phenylketonuria, methylmalonic aciduria, citrullinemia 
  • Maternal Infections: congenital CMV, varicella, toxoplasmosis, HIV, syphilis
  • Maternal teratogens like alcohol, tobacco, marijuana, cocine, antiepileptics
  • Endocrine causes: Hypothyroidism, hypopituitarism, adrenal insufficiency
  • Craniosynostosis
 
 
 
 

Important causes of macrocephaly include:

  • Familial syndromes: Neurofibromatosis, Tuberous Sclerosis, Sturge-Weber, Fragile X
  • Lysosomal storage diseases: Tay-Sachs disease, mucopolysaccharidosis, gangliosidosis, 
  • Hydrocephalus 
  • Intracranial haemorrhage (subdural, extradural, intraventricular) and AVMs
  • Intracranial mass lesions like cyst, abscess or tumor
  • Bone disease like achondroplasia, osteogenesis imperfecta, osteopetrosis
  • Bone marrow expansion: Thalassemia 
  • Raised intracranial pressure: Idiopathic pseudotumor cerebri, lead poisoning, hypervitaminosis A, galactosemia

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady at 38 weeks of gestation, with a past history of cesarean section,  presents with labor pain. After further evaluation, you plan on vaginal delivery for this lady. Which of the following is unlikely to have been the indication of the cesarean section in her previous delivery?
questions.solution:
Vaginal birth after a previous cesarean (VBAC) can be performed in cases where the previous cesarean section is done for some nonrecurrent indication like breech presentation, fetal distress or placenta previa. Contracted pelvis being a recurring indication, is unlikely the indication of cesarean section in this patient.

Selection criteria for VBAC:

  1. One or two previous lower-segment transverse scars.
  2. Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section 
  3. Pelvis adequate for the fetus
  4. Continuous monitoring of labour.
  5. Informed consent of the woman
  6. Sufficient personnel and equipment

Contraindications for VBAC include:

  • Previous classical or inverted T-shaped uterine incision
  • >2 previous lower segment cesarean section
  • Contracted pelvis or cephalo-pelvic disproportion
  • Other obstetric or medical complications
  • Prior uterine rupture

questions.text: A patient with refractory gout is being considered for treatment with a recombinant agent that requires administration only in the presence of a healthcare professional because of the high risk of anaphylaxis. Which of the following is the drug?
questions.solution:
This patient with refractory gout is most likely being considered for treatment with pegloticase. Because the drug is highly immunogenic, its administration is carried out only in a setting where anaphylaxis can be adequately managed. 

Pegloticase is a recombinant urate oxidase which converts uric acid into soluble and inactive allantoin. It is used in cases of refractory gout. 

Recombinant uric acid oxidase is available as rasburicase and pegloticase. It is produced by genetically modified Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain. They are indicated in gout only for chronic refractory gout. It is primarily indicated for hyperuricemia associated with tumor lysis syndrome.

Pegloticase is a recombinant pegylated uric acid oxidase that is indicated for the treatment of severe, refractory, chronic gout and also prophylaxis of gout. Treatment is given as an infusion every 2 weeks.

Other options:

Allopurinol, febuxostat and probenecid are first line agents for gout, additionally anaphylaxis is not common with this agents as it is with Pegloticase.

questions.text: The baby in the image below was born at 37 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 4.9 kg to a mother diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Which of the following complications is likely to be seen in this neonate?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the baby born to a mother with gestational diabetes has macrosomia i.e. the baby is large for gestational age. The neonate is likely to develop polycythemia as a complication.

Polycy­themia occurs as a fetal response to relative hypoxia. Fetal hypoxia is due to a hyperglycemia-mediated increase in maternal affinity for oxy­gen and fetal oxygen consumption. Along with insulin-like growth factors, this hypoxia leads to increased fetal erythropoi­etin levels and red cell production.

Other neonatal complications of gestational diabetes include:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome 
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Cardiac malformations - ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels, truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Neural tube defects, sacral agenesis, caudal regression syndrome, microcephaly, anencephaly
  • Renal agenesis, duodenal atresia, single umbilical artery

Later complications include childhood obesity, diabetes and neuropsychological effects.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a section of the gut wall under the microscope and observes long, cylindrical, unbranched multinucleated fibres with light and dark bands in the muscularis externa layer of this specimen. Which part of the gut wall is being examined in this case?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the presence of long, cylindrical, unbranched multinucleated fibres with light and dark bands in the muscularis externa layer is suggestive of striated muscle fibres that are present only in the upper third of the esophagus. All other layers of the gut wall contain smooth muscles in the muscularis externa layer.

The oesophagus consists of the following layers:

  • Mucosa - consists of a non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, lamina propria, and muscularis mucosae
  • Submucosa - A special feature of the submucosa is the presence of compound tubuloalveolar mucous glands
  • Muscularis externa - with the usual circular and longitudinal layers
    • Upper 1/3rd - Only skeletal muscle fibres are present
    • Middle 1/3rd - Both skeletal and smooth muscle fibres are present
    • Lower 1/3rd - Only smooth muscle fibres are present
  • Adventitia - Most of the oesophagus has a dense fibrous tissue covering called the adventitia. Only a short length of the oesophagus in the lower part has a peritoneal covering (serosa).

questions.text: Analysis expressing results of health care benefits in terms of results achieved, like the number of lives saved, instead of monetary benefit is called ______________
questions.solution:
Cost-effective analysis: The benefits of the health care system are expressed in terms of results achieved (Eg: the number of lives saved or the number of days free from disease). This is a more promising tool in the health field than cost-benefit analysis. But in many cases, it is not possible to use cost-effective analysis.

Other options:

Cost-benefit analysis: Here the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in monetary terms to identify whether it is economically sound and to select the best one from several alternate programs. The main drawback of this technique is that the benefits of a particular program in the health field cannot always be expressed in monetary terms. Usually, the benefits are expressed in terms of births or deaths prevented, or illness avoided or overcome.

Input-output analysis: How much input is needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, the term "input" refers to all health-related activities which consume resources, and "output" refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated or lives saved.

Network analysis: A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities that should be completed in order to reach an end objective.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings would most likely favour early detection glottic carcinoma in a patient with suspected laryngeal malignancy?
questions.solution:
Hoarseness of voice is an early sign of glottic malignancy as the vibratory capacity of the cords is affected, which favors early detection.

Laryngeal malignancies are classified based on their location as supraglottic, glottic, and subglottic, with glottic cancers being the most frequent. The free edge and anterior and middle third of the upper surface of the vocal cords are the most frequent sites for the occurrence of glottic cancer. As there are few lymphatics in the vocal cords, nodal metastases are not commonly seen, unless there is spread beyond the membranous cords, which is a late finding. Local spread to neighboring parts of the supraglottic and subglottic region may occur and fixation of the vocal cord indicates the spread of disease to thyroarytenoid muscle and is a bad prognostic sign.

Laryngeal cancers are usually squamous cell carcinomas. They require thorough evaluation for accurate staging and appropriate treatment. Visualization is carried out by indirect and direct laryngoscopy, and flexible fibreoptic/video laryngoscopy to examine hidden areas and for biopsy. Glottic lesions may appear as nodules, ulcers or thickening.

Treatment depends on the site and extent of the lesion and the nodal metastases status. Treatment options include radiotherapy, surgery, or both. Surgery could be either conservation laryngeal surgery (tracheostomy avoided and voice preserved) or total laryngectomy depending on the disease status. Endoscopic resection with CO2 laser is applicable to carcinoma in situ and T1 lesions of the glottis.

questions.text: In order to correctly perform a deep ring occlusion test, where must the examiner place the thumb?

choices.text: Two-thirds  of line joining umbilicus and ASIS
Half an inch superior to midpoint between pubic tubercle and ASIS
One and half inches inferolateral to pubic tubercle
Half an inch superior to midpoint between pubic symphysis and ASIS

questions.solution:
In the deep ring occlusion test, the examiner must place the thumb half an inch superior to the mid-inguinal point which is the halfway between pubic symphysis and ASIS, which is the landmark for the deep inguinal ring.

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia. An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel. The deep ring occlusion test is one of the tests performed to differentiate between a direct and indirect reducible inguinal hernia. The patient either lies down or is asked to reduce the hernia by taxis, following which the examiner occludes the deep inguinal ring half an inch superior to the mid-inguinal point and asks the patient to stand and cough.

If a swelling appears medial to the thumb, it is likely to be a direct hernia.

If no swelling appears and instead, the examiner feels an impulse against the thumb and a swelling appears after the thumb is removed, it is likely to be an indirect hernia.

Other options:

Option A: The point which is at two-thirds of the imaginary line joining the umbilicus and the ASIS on the right side is called McBurney’s point and is the landmark for palpating for tenderness in acute appendicitis. 

Option B: The midpoint between the pubic tubercle and ASIS is the mid-point of the inguinal ligament. It is the landmark for palpating the femoral artery.

Option C: The point at one and a half inches inferolateral to pubic tubercle is the landmark for palpating a femoral hernia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient presents with neurologic symptoms and visual disturbances. He has a history of a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved on its own 15 years ago. What other symptoms are likely to be concomitantly present?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has acquired syphilis due to unprotected sex and has developed neurological and visual disturbances secondarily as a complication of neurosyphilis, which can be complicated by the concomitant presence of saccular aortic aneurysms.

Neurosyphilis is the third stage of syphilis and also has other features like cardiovascular syphilis, which occurs due to inflammation and occlusion of the vasa vasorum of the aorta, leading to the characteristic tree bark aortitis and aneurysms. These foci of inflammation are triggered by the spirochetes in the blood vessel walls. 
Stages of syphilis:

  • Primary chancre: Painless, indurated, button-like ulcer with painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Secondary syphilis is the stage when generalised manifestations of syphilis appear on the skin and mucous membranes. A macular rash is commonly seen, and this stage may be preceded by constitutional symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and malaise.
  • Latent syphilis is the stage when there are no clinical features of the active disease, but serological testing for the disease is positive.  
  • Late syphilis (tertiary syphilis) commonly presents as superficial or nodular punched-out ulcers or gummas (granulomas appearing as cutaneous plaques or nodules with central ulceration) that appear 3-10 years after infection. It may also present as red nodules (nodular syphilides), neurosyphilis, and cardiovascular syphilis. 

Serological testing is done using standard non-treponemal antibody tests like VDRL and rapid plasma reagin (RPR). Specific treponemal antibody tests like Treponema pallidum hemagglutination assay (TPHA) and fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) are further required. Microscopically, T. palladium is identified with characteristic corkscrew morphology and motility on darkfield microscopy. Parenteral penicillin G is the drug of choice for all stages of syphilis. Treatment of recent sexual contacts is recommended. 

Other Options:

Option A: Maculopapular rash is a manifestation of secondary syphilis.

Option C: Painless lymphadenopathy is seen in the inguinal region in primary syphilis and not in tertiary syphilis

Option D: Petechial haemorrhages are not known manifestations of syphilis.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.

  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text:
Which of the following tumors are wrongly matched with their response to radiotherapy?

RCC-Renal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Dysgerminoma is highly radiosensitive. All other options are correctly matched.

Dysgerminoma is the counterpart of testicular seminoma. It may occur in childhood, but 75% occur in the second and third decades. 80 to 90% of tumors are unilateral. Some appear in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. 

Mostly dysgerminomas are malignant with variable degrees of histologic atypia and one-third of lesions are aggressive. 

Radiotherapy is not preferred despite the fact that they are radiosensitive due to the risk of radiation injury to the bowel. These neoplasms are responsive to chemotherapy, which is preferred over radiotherapy.

Other options:

Option B: Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors and adjuvant radiotherapy was the mainstay of treatment in Stage 1 tumors previously.

Option C: Spinal metastasis from renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is radioresistant. Spinal metastasis from gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma, metastatic melanoma, and thyroid are also radioresistant. Lymphoma, lung, breast, and prostate metastasis are radiosensitive.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is a radiosensitive tumor.

  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma

  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: What is the most appropriate way to discard an expired cytotoxic drug?
questions.solution:
Expired cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs are to be returned to the manufacturer or supplier for incineration. They need to be subjected to incineration or encapsulation or plasma pyrolysis at a temperature of 1200 degrees Celsius.

In incineration, the biomedical waste material is exposed to a very high temperature inside the incinerator, converting the material into ash. This method is used to dispose of human and animal anatomical waste, soiled waste (contaminated dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs), expired or discarded medicines, microbiological and clinical laboratory waste, etc. It is expensive and is generally used only by very large establishments. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator. Image of an incinerator is shown below.

Other options : 

Option A : Autoclaving is a method of heat sterilization. The autoclave is a device that uses steam under pressure to sterilize linen, instruments, laboratory ware, media, pharmaceutical products, aqueous solutions, surgical instruments, cardiac catheters, and implants.

Option B : Disinfection with sodium hypochlorite is performed for broken or discarded glass, including medicine vials and ampoules, unless tainted with cytotoxic wastes.

Option C : Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas which lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. Permission from the concerned authority is needed and guidelines issued by the central pollution control board should be followed. It is primarily used for the disposal of human and animal waste as well as soiled waste.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient with neurocysticercosis develops generalized peeling of skin (except palms and soles) and severe oral and genital involvement starting 1 month after taking seizure medication. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Generalized skin involvement (which indicates > 30%), severe oral and genital involvement are features of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

TEN usually starts between 4 days to 4 weeks after initiation of drugs such as phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine. Palms and soles involvement is a feature that is classically seen in erythema multiforme and not in TEN (which has more truncal involvement).

SJS/TEN is primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs - oxicam group
  • Anti-epileptics - phenobarbital, phenytoin, carbamazepine, lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - penicillins, cephalosporins, sulfamethoxazole, sulfasalazine, nevirapine

In 15% of the cases, where the drug cannot be identified, especially in children, appear to be triggered by infections, most notably by Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Note: FDA recommends genotyping before starting carbamazepine, as HLA B1502 allele which is seen in increased frequencies among Asians is implicated in carbamazepine induced SJS/TEN.

SJS/TEN is classified based on severity and involvement of body surface area (BSA)

SJS Epidermal detachment of less than 10% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
SJS/TEN overlap Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN with spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN without spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with loss of large epidermal sheets without widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

Complications of SJS/TEN involve loss of thermoregulatory control, severe dehydration, and septicemia. Dehydration can cause acute kidney injury due to hypoperfusion. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and be monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.

Other options :

Option A : Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. But SJS has <10% involvement of skin and not a generalized involvement as seen in this patient.

Option B : Fixed drug eruptions present up to 8 hours of drug intake. These are erythematous lesions that heal with hyperpigmentation. Mucosal involvement is rare.

Option D - Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease due to antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins. Patients usually present with oral lesions which are the predominant feature. There are flaccid blisters which rupture. The following image shows the multiple ruptured and flaccid blisters.

questions.text: A young school-going boy with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness visits your clinic. While walking towards the reception, he suddenly falls down with no control over his muscle tone. Which part of the brain is affected in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a young boy with excessive daytime sleep and sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone (cataplexy) is suggestive of narcolepsy. It is associated with the loss of orexin from the lateral hypothalamus.

Narcolepsy is a chronic neurological disorder caused by the brain’s inability to regulate sleep-wake cycles normally. The affected individual experiences a sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone (cataplexy), an eventual irresistible urge to sleep during daytime, and possibly brief episodes of total paralysis at the beginning or end of sleep. It is also characterized by a sudden onset of REM sleep, unlike normal sleep that begins with NREM, slow-wave sleep.

It has a familial incidence strongly associated with a class II antigen of the major histocompatibility complex on chromosome 6 at the HLA-DR2 or HLA-DQW1 locus, implying a genetic susceptibility.

Orexins (Previously known as hypocretins) are neuropeptides synthesized by hypothalamic neurons and involved in the regulation of food intake and energy expenditure and also in sleep regulation.

The hypothalamus and several non-specific nuclei in the ascending reticular activating system (ARAS) located in the midbrain are involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle.

Sleep Centres

Stimulation of the midbrain reticular formation (RAS) produces the EEG alerting response and promotes the waking state. 

The nucleus coeruleus (locus coeruleus) is rich in norepinephrine and the raphe nuclei of ARAS are rich in serotonin. These regions when stimulated induce wakefulness.

The cholinergic neurons in the pontine reticular formation, on stimulation, induce sleep.

Stimulation of the histaminergic neurons of the posterior hypothalamus produces arousal. 

Electrical stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus and the adjacent basal forebrain region rapidly induces sleep. This sleep-inducing effect is thought to be mediated by GABA-ergic inhibitory neurons.

Summary of hormones/mediators of the sleep-wakefulness cycle:

Wakeful state  Sleep 
Norepinephrine  Acetylcholine 
Serotonin  GABA 
Histamine

questions.text: A 47-year-old male is brought to the casualty with massive hemoptysis. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The first step in management would be to secure his airway and intubate him to prevent aspiration of the blood. 

Any hemoptysis that can cause airway compromise or lead to hemodynamic collapse is called massive hemoptysis.  Common causes include tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and cancer. It is a medical emergency. Bleeding can either be from the bronchial artery circulation (most common) or from the pulmonary artery circulation. Bleeding from cavitary lesions is due to pulmonary artery erosion. The chest X-ray is the first investigation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy.

The cause of death in massive hemoptysis is usually due to asphyxiation (rather than blood loss itself). This is why airway stabilization by intubating into the non-bleeding lung is the priority. After ventilation is achieved, the bleeding site should be identified using bronchoscopy. Bleeding is controlled by laser, bronchial occlusion, or arterial embolization. Surgical resection of the involved area is also done in some cases.

Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis:

  • Presence of a fungus ball
  • Presence of a lung abscess
  • Presence of significant cavitary disease
  • Failure to control the bleeding.

questions.text: A patient who was recently started on ACE inhibitors comes with complaints of sudden painful swelling of the lips and difficulty in breathing. What should you do next in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop the ACE inhibitor and switch to losartan
Prescribe antihistamines and review the next day
Stop the ACE inhibitor and reassure
Airway evaluation and intubation if necessary

questions.solution:
This patient presents with swelling over the lips and difficulty in breathing and its occurrence following intake of an ACE inhibitor is suggestive of drug-induced angioedema. Patients presenting with symptoms of the face and airway should be emergently evaluated and intubation should be done if needed to ensure patency of the airway, following which the patient should be stopped on all ACE inhibitors and switched to a different class of drug.

ACE inhibitors prevent the breakdown of bradykinin which is the main mediator of angioedema. ACE inhibitors cause rapid swelling in the nose, throat, mouth, glottis, larynx, lips, or tongue. Once the drug is stopped symptoms improve drastically over hours. However, patients need to be monitored for 24-48 hours to ensure that there is no respiratory compromise.

This is a class-related effect and a positive reaction to a drug makes the patient ineligible to receive any other ACE inhibitors

Other adverse effects of ACE inhibitors:

  • Hypotension - A sudden fall in blood pressure can occur following the first dose of ACE inhibitors.
  • Cough - It can produce a bothersome dry cough due to the accumulation of bradykinin, substance P, or prostaglandins in the lungs. The cough usually disappears within 4 days of the stoppage of the drug.
  • Hyperkalemia due to K+ retention can occur.
  • Acute renal failure can occur with ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, stenosis of the artery to a single remaining kidney, heart failure, or volume depletion due to diarrhea or diuretics.
  • It should be discontinued in pregnant women as it can cause developmental defects.

Other options:

Options A: Switching to losartan is done in all patients who develop angioedema after taking an ACE inhibitor. However, in this patient presenting with breathing difficulties, maintaining the airway takes priority. 

Option B: Antihistamines are useful for idiopathic angioedema but have limited efficacy in angioedema secondary to ACE inhibitors. 

Option C: Stopping the drug alone is not enough in drug-induced angioedema as the patients can rapidly progress to respiratory compromise.

questions.text: A patient comes 9 months after a kidney transplant for routine evaluation. She receives tacrolimus with mycophenolate mofetil. The creatinine is found to be 3 mg/dl. Her previous value 2 months ago was 1.6mg/dl. Which of the following is the cause of her lab findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting 9 months after a kidney transplant with elevated creatinine has likely developed Tacrolimus-induced kidney injury. The mechanism of this is believed to be due to hypertension-induced in the renal tubules. 

Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor that blocks FKBP 12. This is an immunophilin that ultimately inhibits calcineurin phosphatase and exerts its actions. 

Tacrolimus is administered orally for long-term maintenance. There are also IV formulations for patients unable to tolerate oral feeds. It is used in the management of solid organ transplant rejection including heart, kidney, and liver transplants. 

Tacrolimus has a very narrow therapeutic index and should be monitored intensively after initiating therapy till the patient stabilizes. It is associated with nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, hypertension, hyperglycemia. Nephrotoxicity is a significant risk when coadministered with cyclosporine, so most regimens of tacrolimus are now combined with mycofenolate which allows for dose reduction to a certain extent. However, it should still be monitored routinely.

Other Options:

Option A: Acute transplant reaction occurs within weeks to months after a transplant, usually within 6 months.

Option B: Mycophenolate causes leukopenia, pure red cell aplasia, and GI upset. It does not cause nephrotoxicity.

Option D: Ischemic injury can occur in chronic transplant rejection after years due to narrowed tubules. It does not cause creatinine to rise this soon.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and breathlessness for the past 2 years. On examination, a holosystolic murmur is heard on the left 5th ICS on the mid axillary line. Which of the following would also be likely in this patient?

ICS: intercostal space
questions.solution:
This patient has developed a murmur in the 5th ICS on the left side which is the mitral area. A holosystolic murmur is likely to be mitral regurgitation. Mitral regurgitation increases on squatting. 

This occurs because squatting(and handgrip) increases the afterload and this blood flows with more force across the valve thus increasing the murmur. A valsalva maneuver on the other hand causes reduced preload and leads to reduced blood flow across the valve leading to reduced intensity of the murmur. 

Other options:

Right-sided murmurs increase on inspiration

  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady came to your OPD with complaints of non-foul-smelling curdy white vaginal discharge with itching and burning. On examination, the vaginal pH is found to be <4.5. 	When the causative organism is incubated in human serum at 37°C, germ tubes are formed. How would you treat her partner in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, symptoms of non-foul smelling curdy white vaginal discharge and the formation of germ tubes when the causative organism is incubated in human serum at 37°C  are highly suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis caused by Candida albicans. It is not a sexually transmitted disease and the partner does not require treatment.

Candida species are yeast-like fungi, which normally inhabit the skin and mucosa. Vulvovaginal candidiasis occurs in conditions which decrease the normal genital microbiota(e.g., long-term antibiotic use), allowing the yeasts to proliferate and produce symptoms. 

Candida albicans is an ovoid or spherical budding cell, which produces pseudohyphae both in tissues and in culture. Unlike other species of candida, yeast cells of Candida albicans will begin to form germ tubes after incubation in serum maintained at 37°C for about 90 minutes. This is known as the Reynolds-Braude phenomenon.

Diagnosis includes:

  • Wet smear with 10% KOH solution- shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae 
  • Gram staining - Gram-positive budding cells with pseudohyphae 
  • Sabouraud agar culture - Creamy white smooth colonies with yeasty odour.
  • Corn meal agar culture - Candida albicans form chlamydospores.
  • CHROMagar - Candida albicans colonies appear green.

The clinical symptoms of vulvovaginal candidiasis include curdy white vaginal discharge, dysuria, and intense itching with vaginal pH <4.5. 

Treatment involves oral fluconazole 150 mg single dose or local intravaginal application of antifungal agents such as imidazole miconazole, clotrimazole, vaginal pessaries or creams used for 3-6 days is effective.  

Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, only topical azoles are recommended during pregnancy. 

Other Options: 

Option A: Metronidazole 200mg orally for 1 week is the recommended treatment for Trichomonas vaginitis, caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, a pear-shaped unicellular flagellate anaerobic protozoa. On examination, vaginal discharge is thin, grey, greenish-yellow, frothy and offensive. It is a highly contagious sexually transmitted disease(STD) where the male harbours the infection in the urethra and prostate. The partner is given the same treatment schedule for 1 week.

Option C: Azithromycin - 1 g orally single dose is the recommended treatment for Chlamydial infections caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (of D-K serotypes), an obligatory intracellular gram-negative bacteria. The sexual partner should also be treated with the same drug regimen.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
A pregnant lady has a BP of 150/100mm Hg. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage her blood pressure?
  1. Labetalol
  2. Alpha methyl dopa
  3. Hydralazine
  4. Ramipril
  5. Nifedipine
  6. Clonidine
questions.solution:
Antihypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors, ARBS
  • Diuretics
  • Nonselective beta-blockers
  • Nitroprusside

Antihypertensives found to be safe in pregnancy:

  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs: should be stopped before labor as they weaken the uterine contractions
  • Cardioselective beta-blockers and those with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity: may be used as a last choice

Clonidine is classified as a Class C drug and has no evidence yet on use in pregnancy and should not be used.

questions.text: A G3P2L0 presents with 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She has a history of conization being done one year ago and is currently on follow-up, with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has the history of preterm labor at 30 and 32 weeks. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The next step of management in this patient, is to do USG to measure the cervical length.

In the given clinical scenario the patient has undergone conization which is a risk factor for cervical incompetence. Hence, it is important to measure the cervical length to diagnose cervical incompetence in this patient. If the cervical length is ≤2.5 cm then a cervical cerclage can be performed.

Cervical cerclage (Option B) is performed as the next step in management when the patient presents with ≥2 second trimester pregnancy losses (History based diagnosis of cervical incompetence). Since, the history in this patient is of preterm labour, the first step would still be to do a TVS to measure the cervical length for diagnosing. Cerclage only comes after diagnosis.

Cervical incompetence is one of the important causes second trimester (mid trimester) abortions.

Risk factors for the incompetence include: 

  • Past h/o surgery on cervix such as conization, loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP)
  • Cervical trauma during labour, instrumental delivery

Diagnosis of cervical incompetence in a pregnant female:

  • H/O ≥2 second trimester abortions (history based diagnosis)→ management is by cervical cerclege+progesterone
  • H/O 1 second trimester abortion→ TVS done between 18-24 weeks to measure the cervical length→USG based diagnosis of cervical incompetence is made if there is h/o 1 or more second trimester abortions with TVS showing cervical length ≤2.5 cm.

TVS findings in cervical incompetence include:

  • Cervical length ≤2.5 cm (Normal:3-4cm)
  • Shape of cervix becomes U shaped
  • Diameter of internal os ≥ 2cm

questions.text: A 73-year-old male patient diagnosed with a history of asymptomatic chronic lymphocytic leukemia presents with episodes of night sweats, diffuse cervical lymphadenopathy, and weight loss for 3 weeks. Chest X-ray is clear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of asymptomatic chronic lymphocytic leukemia now has new onset symptoms of night sweats, lymphadenopathy, and weight loss. This is most likely a result of the transformation of the CLL to Diffuse large B cell lymphoma (Richter Transformation).

Richter's syndrome is the transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) to aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). It has a poor prognosis. Patients develop the following features:

  • Fever and weight loss
  • Rapidly enlarging lymph nodes 
  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase 

DLBCL is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is characteristic of large cell types and shows a diffuse pattern of growth. The most frequent pathological abnormality seen is dysregulation of BCL6.

Mature B-cell tumours express CD19 and CD20 markers. Special subtypes of DLBCL include immunodeficiency-associated large B-cell lymphoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

Other options:

Option A: Reactivated tuberculosis can present with night sweats, weight loss, and cough. However, there is no finding on the chest X-ray. In this patient with a known history of CLL, DLBCL is more likely.

Option C: Follicular lymphoma presents in middle age with no sex predilection. The most common presenting symptom is painless generalised lymphadenopathy, which has a slow progression. This patient's symptoms are more suggestive of a more rapidly progressive condition like DLBCL.

Option D: Burkitt’s lymphoma is an aggressive type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) that mainly occurs in children and young adults. It usually presents with a mass involving the mandible and abdominal viscera. This patient with a history of CLL most likely has DLBCL.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is diagnosed with viral hemorrhagic fever. You suspect the Zaire strain of the virus to be responsible for the infection. The virus involved is highly virulent and morphologically appears as long filamentous threads. After further evaluation, you start him on Inmazeb. What family does the virus implicated in this condition belong to?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the presence of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by Zaire strain of a highly virulent virus which, morphologically appears as long filamentous threads is highly suggestive of Ebola Virus which belongs to the Filoviridae family.

This diagnosis is confirmed by the drug used to treat this patient, Inmazeb (atoltivimab, maftivimab, and odesivimab), a mixture of three monoclonal antibodies, which is the first Food and Drug Administration(FDA) approved treatment for Zaire ebolavirus infection in adult and pediatric patients.

Ebola virus is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa. They are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.

Fruit bats act as reservoir hosts of the virus and it is transmitted to humans only accidentally. Human-to-human transmission is through direct contact with blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person. It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.

The incubation period of the disease is 2 to 21 days. Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding. The current treatment is mainly supportive. Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after a complete cure.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a commonly used diagnostic method for Ebola disease because of its ability to detect low levels of an ebolavirus. 

Ebola virus is highly virulent and requires maximum containment facilities (Biosafety Level 4) for laboratory work and belongs to Category A (High risk) bioterrorism which poses a threat to national security and has the ability to cause social disruption.

Other options:

Option A: Flaviviridae family- Flaviviruses are enveloped viruses with a diameter of 40-60 nm and single-stranded, positive-sense RNA. Most members are transmitted by blood-sucking arthropods. They include yellow fever, dengue viruses, Japanese encephalitis virus and Hepatitis C virus.

Option B: Arenaviridae family-  Spherical or pleomorphic viruses, 50-300 nm in size. Only one genus, Arenavirus, has been recognised. Species include lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus(LCM) and Lassa virus.

Option D: Bunyaviridae family- Bunyaviruses are spherical or pleomorphic, 80- to 120-nm enveloped particles. The genome is made up of a triple-segmented, single-stranded RNA. The majority of these viruses are transmitted to vertebrates by arthropods (arboviruses). They include sandfly fever and hantaviruses.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is diagnosed to be sputum smear-positive for Tuberculosis. Based on further examination, a diagnosis of Right-sided tubercular pleural effusion is made. Which of the following clinical examination findings is not consistent with a diagnosis of right-sided pleural effusion?

choices.text: Stony dull percussion note on the right side
Mediastinal shift to the right side
Tracheal deviation to the left side
Increased vocal resonance above the level of effusion

questions.solution:
A mediastinal shift to the left side is expected in the case of a right-sided pleural effusion. 

Clinical findings in pleural effusion:

  • A mediastinal shift to the opposite side
  • Stony dull percussion note over the region of effusion
  • Diminished or absent breath sounds (tubular above level of effusion)
  • Reduced or absent vocal resonance (increased above level effusion)
  • Pleural rub may be heard above the level of effusion
  • Tracheal deviation to the opposite side in case of large effusions

A similar set of findings is seen in the case of empyema as well.

The tracheal shift to the same side in the presence of pleural effusion can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Mesothelioma
  • Empyema or effusion following pre-existing fibrosis
  • Mass with collapse and pleural effusion.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of progressive swelling in his left arm. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: Radiotherapy is mandatory as it is a highly radiosensitive tumor
Cisplatin  is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice
The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micro metastasis.
Hindquarter amputation is indicated in tumors involving upper end of tibia

questions.solution:
The X-ray showing periosteal lifting and sunburst appearance is suggestive of osteosarcoma and the goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy in osteosarcoma is to treat micro-metastasis.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal.

The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the common sites. 

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a "Codman's triangle" or it may have a "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on X-ray.

The image given in question shows the following features:

  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone
  • Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor centrifugally giving rise to "sunburst (sunray) appearance" on the radiograph.

Treatment:

Osteosarcoma is treated by neoadjuvant chemotherapy, wide excision or radical surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy. Since here safe margins are difficult to achieve limb ablation is done. 

Osteosarcoma is a radioresistant tumor

The goal of neoadjuvant and adjuvant chemotherapy is to treat micrometastasis.

T-10 protocol of chemotherapy is used in the management of osteosarcoma. It involves:

  • High dose methotrexate and Citrovorum factor rescue
  • Adriamycin
  • BCD (bleomycin, cyclophosphamide, dactinomycin/doxorubicin)

Note:

Levels of amputation in osteosarcoma:

Upper end of humerus Forequarter amputation
Upper end of tibia Midthigh amputation
Upper end of femur Hindquarter amputation and hip disarticulation
Lower end of femur Midthigh amputation and hip disarticulation
