questions.text: While assisting a thyroidectomy surgery, the thyroid ima artery is accidentally nicked. The lead surgeon asks you to ligate the artery with a knot which gives good security without allowing slippage. Which of the following knots will you use?
questions.solution:
The surgical knot portrayed in the third picture is preferred as it is used when added security is required along with a two-throw technique to prevent slippage.

In the given image:

1- Half-hitch knot

2- Extra half-hitch on square

3- Surgeon's knot

4- Granny's knot

Knotting techniques : 

  • The standard knot used is the reef knot. Three throws are used for added security. Reef knots made with monofilament sutures require six to eight throws for added security.
  • A granny knot is a slip knot which is two throws of the same type. It is used to achieve the right tension and is followed by the reef knot for security
  • Surgeon’s knot is used when added security is required. A two throw technique prevents slippage.
  • An Aberdeen knot is used for the final knot during continuous sutures.

Image showing standard knotting formations is given below.

questions.text: A 14-month-old baby was brought with complaints of continuous watering from the eyes,  present since birth. Antibiotic eye drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct did not show much improvement. Which of the following would be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic dacryocystitis and the next best step in the management of this patient is the probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia.

Dacryocystitis is the inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It generally affects infants and adults, most commonly females over 40 years of age. Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic, while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic.

Congenital dacryocystitis is due to incomplete canalization of the lacrimal system, most often at the valve of Hasner. In newborns, antibiotic drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct and sac clear out most infections. However, if the symptoms persist beyond a year without improvement, probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia is advised. Balloon dilatation of the duct or placement of a silicone tube can be done after localizing the level of obstruction.

Other options:

Option B: Antibiotic drops with repeated syringing is the first line of treatment in adults with chronic dacryocystitis.

Option C: In adults, if dacryocystitis persists after repeated syringing, anatomical assessment with digital subtraction macrodacryocystography localises the level of obstruction.

Option D: Dacryocystorhinostomy is the surgical management of chronic dacryocystitis and is advised in adults with blockage at the level of joining of the nasolacrimal duct and sac.

questions.text: During your labour postings, you notice the resident making a surgical incision on the perineum during the second stage of labour. Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the incision given?

choices.text: Given when 5-6 cms of the head is visible
Given at the height of uterine contraction
Given after the application of blades in forceps delivery

questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the surgical incision given on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour is called episiotomy. It is given when 3-4 cm of the head is visible, when the perineum is thinned out and bulging, at the peak of a uterine contraction. During forceps delivery, the incision is made after the application of blades.

Episiotomy is recommended in selective cases rather than as a routine. It is indicated in cases of shoulder dystocia, breech delivery, fetal macrosomia and operative vaginal deliveries.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Types of episiotomy include mediolateral, median, lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy.

Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears. The below image shows the episiotomy scissors.

Note: Option D has been corrected from "Given right before the application of blades in forceps delivery" -> "Given after the application of blades in forceps delivery" to ensure factual accuracy. 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: After delivering a baby, you notice the surgeon following the WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labour (AMTSL). Which of the following is considered the most important component?
questions.solution:
According to the AMTSL guidelines of WHO, the most important AMTSL component is the administration of a prophylactic uterotonic, preferably oxytocin.

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic preferably Oxytocin. Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV. Other injectable uterotonics and misoprostol are recommended as alternatives for the prevention of PPH in settings where oxytocin is unavailable.
  • Delayed cord clamping for at least 1-3 minutes. This reduces the rates of anaemia in infants.
  • Controlled cord traction by modified Brandt Andrews technique during placental delivery (in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women and is done every 15 mins for 2 hours.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum haemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor in decreasing PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, controlled cord traction is not as critical. But note that all 3 are still essential, and AMTSL includes them. 

Continuous uterine massage is not recommended as an intervention to prevent PPH in women who have received prophylactic oxytocin

questions.text: A 56-year-old male is brought with complaints of crushing chest pain. On auscultation, crackles are heard on respiration and ST elevation is seen on ECG. He was told 2 days ago that he had terminal pancreatic cancer. Imaging findings are shown below. What is the likely mechanism of his current disease?
questions.solution:
The given ventriculogram shows apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart. This coupled with sudden chest pain with pulmonary edema(crackles on respiration) with ECG changes mimicking a myocardial infarction in the setting of recent stressful news indicates Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It is characterized by a transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spasms due to a catecholamine surge during stress. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients may present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

Echocardiography reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a takotsubo (pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic those of myocardial infarction. Therefore, coronary angiography may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a self-limiting disorder, resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

The image below shows left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning, resembling the takotsubo pot.

questions.text: A 13 year old boy is prescribed a budesonide inhaler for his asthma. However, he returns 2 weeks later with no improvement in symptoms. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Increase the dosage of the drug that is delivered
Add salbutamol in addition to the budesonide
Start the patient on oral steroids
Evaluate his technique of usage of the inhaler

questions.solution:
This patient with asthma who has returned with no improvement in symptoms should be evaluated for his technique of usage of inhalers. Improper technique use should be excluded before changing the drug dosage.

Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are given through MDI, nebulizer, or dry powder inhaler forms. Hoarseness of voice, sore throat, dysphonia, and oropharyngeal candidiasis are a few of the side effects that can be prevented by the use of a spacer to reduce drug deposition from the mucosa. Spacers also help pediatric populations use the inhalers better as it gives them more time to synchronize the time between drug delivery and inhalation. Physicians must always demonstrate the correct technique and ask the patient to demonstrate it once to ensure adequate usage. 

Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are glucocorticoids that have high topical and low systemic action. The commonly used ICS are:

  • Beclomethasone dipropionate
  • Budesonide
  • Fluticasone
  • Ciclesonide

They act by suppressing bronchial inflammation, increasing PEFR (peak expiratory flow rate) thereby reducing the use of inhalational beta2-agonist. They prevent acute attacks of asthma but are not effective during acute asthma or in status asthmaticus. 

Regular low-dose ICS can be started as part of Step-2 management of asthma and continued along with other add-ons according to the type of asthma. In seasonal asthma, regular low-dose ICS is given 3-4 weeks before an anticipated attack. ICS is indicated in patients with persistent asthma requiring a daily dose of beta 2 agonists and those who taper oral steroids require additional inhalational steroids to prevent withdrawal symptoms. High-dose ICS is useful in severe COPD with exacerbations.

Other options:

Increasing the dosage of drug delivered and adding any other drugs should be done only after confirming that the patient is using the inhaler properly.

Starting oral steroids in a growing child should be done only after it is confirmed that the local drug delivery systems are not efficacious as it can lead to closure of the growth plate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed with a heart condition which has gradually progressed over the last 10 months. On examination, painful nodular lesions are present on the pads of the fingers as shown below. He also gives a history of repeated tooth extraction procedures for dental caries in the last 3 years. Which of the following laboratory results accurately describes the organism involved?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of painful erythematous nodular lesions on the pads of the fingers(Osler nodes) in a patient with a heart condition that has gradually progressed over months is suggestive of subacute infective endocarditis (SABE).

Viridans streptocooci are most commonly associated with SABE in patients who have undergone tooth extraction procedures for dental caries. They are resistant to optochin, bile insoluble, show alpha hemolysis on blood agar and the inulin fermentation test is negative.

Viridans group of streptococci include:

  • Streptococci mitis 
  • Streptococci mutans
  • Streptococci salvarius
  • Streptococci sanguis (causes sub-acute bacterial endocarditis)

Viridans streptococci are normal commensals of the upper respiratory tract. Following tooth extraction or other dental procedures, they are introduced into the bloodstream and implanted on damaged or prosthetic valves causing sub-acute bacterial endocarditis (SABE).

Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium that leads to the formation of vegetations composed of thrombotic debris and organisms, often associated with the destruction of the underlying cardiac tissue. It is classified as

  • Acute - infection of a previously normal heart valve by a highly virulent organism that progresses rapidly.
  • Subacute - infection in previously deformed valves by organisms of lower virulence like  S.viridans, S. epidermidis, HACEK(Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, and Kingella) group that progresses gradually over weeks to months. 

Microscopically, the vegetations of subacute IE typically exhibit granulation tissue at their bases indicative of healing

Clinical features include subungual splinter haemorrhages, Osler nodes, Janeway lesions, and Roth spots. 

The image below shows Osler nodes which are painful raised violaceous lesions commonly affecting the fingers, toes, and feet. It is immunologically mediated.

The image below depicts Roth's spots which are exudative lesions in the retina. This is an immunological phenomenon.

The image given below shows Janeway lesions which are faint, red, painless macules on palms and soles. They occur as a result of septic embolization and are not immunologically mediated.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with fever, lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge. On bimanual examination, cervical motion tenderness is noted, following which you start her on antibiotics as per the outpatient treatment protocols under the CDC guidelines. After how many days should you re-evaluate her case to see if she is responding well to the antibiotics?

CDC- Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge associated with cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). Within 72 hours, all patients treated under the outpatient protocol are evaluated to see if they have responded adequately to antibiotics; if not, they are hospitalised.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a group of infections and inflammations that affect the organs of the upper genital tract, typically involving the uterus (endometrium), fallopian tubes, ovaries, pelvic peritoneum and surrounding structures (parametrium).

As per CDC 2015 criteria: Any one of the minimum criteria + 1 or more additional criteria are required for the clinical diagnosis of PID.

Minimum criteria:

  • Lower abdominal tenderness
  • Adnexal tenderness
  • Cervical motion tenderness

Additional criteria:

  • Oral temperature>38°C
  • Mucopurulent cervical or vaginal discharge and cervical friability
  • Raised ESR or CRP
  • Laboratory documentation of positive cervical infection with Gonorrhea or Chlamydia

Definitive criteria:

  • Histopathologic evidence of endometritis on biopsy
  • Imaging studies (TVS/MRI) evidence of thickened fluid-filled tubes (tubo-ovarian abscess)
  • Laparoscopic evidence of PID

Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current CDC- 2015):

  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days
  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks.

Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:

  • Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV  for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days
  • Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.
  • Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.

Indications for hospitalization:

  • Unresponsiveness to outpatient therapy for 48-72 hours
  • Surgical emergencies like appendicitis, generalized peritonitis, etc. 
  • Tubo-ovarian abscess
  • Pregnancy
  • Oral temperature >38.5°C, severe nausea and vomiting

questions.text: A patient presents with a high-grade fever with spikes, headache, and double vision. There is no loss of vision. On examination, he had bilateral periorbital edema and proptosis. Further examinations reveal paralysis of extraocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex, and loss of corneal reflex. However, the visual acuity is preserved. What is the most likely site of location of the structure that is involved in the disease?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario, the patient has paralysis of extraocular muscles, loss of pupillary reflex, and loss of corneal reflex. There is no loss of vision. This means that there is paralysis of the oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, abducens nerve, and ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. The optic nerve is spared. The most likely site of involvement is the cavernous sinus which is marked as B. 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is usually caused due to an infection. The source of infection can be from facial veins, sinuses, middle ear, pharynx, or tonsils. This will lead to impaired drainage of the blood from the eye and inflammation of the nerves present in the sinus leading to ophthalmoplegia. 

The patients present with high-grade fever with spikes. This is called picket fence fever. They might also have periorbital edema, eyelid erythema, chemosis, ptosis, and proptosis that occurs due to impaired drainage of the orbit.

Multiple cranial nerves are related to this sinus. They are:

  • Oculomotor nerve- It supplies superior, inferior, and medial recti muscles, and inferior oblique. It also supplies parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion. Therefore paralysis of this nerve leads to paralysis of extraocular muscles with loss of pupillary reflex.
  • Trochlear nerve- Damage to this nerve leads to superior oblique paralysis.
  • Ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve- It supplies, cornea, ciliary body, iris, lacrimal gland conjunctiva, etc. Damage to this nerve will lead to loss of corneal reflex
  • Abducens nerve-Damage to this nerve leads to lateral rectus palsy.

 Cavernous sinus

The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone, extending from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are

  • Oculomotor nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve

Within the cavernous sinus are the 

  • Abducens nerve
  • Cavernous part of the internal carotid artery

The structure marked as A is the orbital apex. In orbital apex syndrome structures passing through superior orbital fissure and optic canal are affected. Therefore disease affecting this area will have a combination of multiple cranial nerve palsy and visual loss.

The structure marked as C is foramen rotundum. It transmits the maxillary nerve. Injury at this area will lead to loss of sensation over the cheek and philtrum.

The structure marked as D is the foramen ovale. It transmits the mandibular nerve, accessory meningeal artery, and the lesser petrosal nerve.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought for evaluation of weakness, vomiting, difficulty walking, and pallor. The family recently moved to an old house with peeling paint and were still planning renovations. The peripheral smear is shown below. What would you advise for the patient?
questions.solution:
The slide shows basophilic stippling (punctate basophilia), seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism). The history of moving to an old home with peeling paint hints at the usage of lead-based paints in old houses. The next step in diagnosis would be to obtain to peripheral venous blood sample for blood lead level evaluation.

Sideroblastic anemia occurs in lead poisoning as lead inhibits the enzymes ferrochelatase and δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase which are responsible for the heme synthesis pathway. This leads to the accumulation of the heme precursors in the cell. They can be stained by Prussian blue staining and can be visualized in the RBCs on a peripheral smear. 

The hematological findings that are associated with lead poisoning are anemia, ringed sideroblasts, and basophilic stippling of the RBCs.

Diagnosis involves screening tests such as measurement of:

  • Coproporphyrin levels in urine. It is less than 150 mcg/100 mL in non-exposed individuals.
  • Aminolevulinic acid levels in urine: A reading greater than 50 mg/L indicates lead absorption
  • Blood and urine levels of lead: A reading greater than 0.8 mg/L in urine indicates lead absorption. A reading greater than 70 mcg/L in blood indicates lead absorption.

Other Options:

MRI brain and Skin biopsy are not used in the evaluation of lead poisoning. 

Bone marrow biopsy is used to evaluate for myelodysplastic syndrome which can also cause sideroblastic anemia. However, there is also presence of signs of other cell line deficits like recurrent infections or bleeding diathesis, which is lacking in this patient. 

Prevention of lead poisoning includes incorporating personal protective measures, regular screening of workers, good housekeeping practices, and health education.

Lead poisoning is a notifiable and compensatable disease in India.

questions.text: While on rounds in the post-operative ward,  you observe your senior teaching a patient who has undergone an open cholecystectomy two days ago, to use this device. What is the main purpose of using this device?
questions.solution:
The purpose of incentive spirometry in a post-operative patient is to prevent pulmonary atelectasis.

Atelectasis, especially of the lower lobes, is the most common respiratory complication in a post-operative patient and can be prevented by sitting the patient or inclining the bed, early mobilization, deep breathing exercises with incentive spirometry, and chest physiotherapy. Patients who are not fully awake may require non-invasive mechanical ventilation with PEEP. Correct manner of performing incentive spirometry is by taking sequential deep breaths so that all the balls or marker in the tube rise to the top, holding the breath for 5-6 seconds, and then exhaling. 

The primary pathophysiology of is inadequate expansion of the alveoli leading to their collapse. The factors predisposing to atelectasis are general anesthesia, upper abdominal and thoracic surgery. In the post-operative period, inadequate pain control may lead to poor inspiratory effort and and reduced diaphragm contraction in the patient's attempt to avoid experiencing pain,  may also contribute to the development of atelectasis. On the other hand, overuse of opioid analgesics or sedatives may also favour development of atelectasis due to respiratory depression causing collection of secretions. Other causes include lack of mobilization (bed-bound patients) or positional change.

Patients present with tachypnoea and decreased oxygen saturation and on examination, the breath sounds are bronchial in nature and reduced in intensity. Chest X-ray may show diminished lung volume, linear opacities, and elevation of the diaphragm on the affected side.

questions.text: A 48-year-old diabetic woman presents with excessive fatigue. On examination, she appears pale and has a smooth tongue. Peripheral smear shows the following finding. Which of the following tests would be the most suitable for assessing her blood glucose levels?
questions.solution:
This patient with excessive fatigue and a concomitant and peripheral smear displaying a hypochromic picture is typical of a case of iron-deficiency anemia in whom we need to perform a serum fructosamine test. Serum HbA1C if performed would provide a falsely elevated value in patients with iron deficiency anemia.

Glycation of hemoglobin is an irreversible process and when it occurs in patients with iron deficiency anemia who have a lower counts of red blood cells , the values are higher in patients with anemias the average lifespan of the red blood cell is found to be higher thus causing a higher value of HbA1C. Serum Fructosamine is simply glycated albumin, and its levels do not differ between patients with or without iron deficiency anemia.

Fructosamine is obtained by the glycation of albumin. Fructosamine is a measure of non-enzymatic glycation of circulating proteins including albumin, globulins, and lipoproteins. It is now used as a  reasonable alternative to HbA1c measurement as it is not reliable. Since albumin is the most abundant of the serum proteins, fructosamine is predominantly a measure of glycated albumin.

Fructosamine is used as a short-term marker of glucose control. It reflects the average glycemia over the preceding 2 to 3 weeks. HbA1c reflects glucose control over a period of the preceding 8 to 12 weeks.

Other options :

Option C : Random blood sugar >200 mg/dL can be used for diagnosis only if the patient presents with symptoms of diabetes, hence it is not a useful screening test.

Option D : Fasting blood sugar >126 mg/dL and 2-hour postprandial blood sugar >200 mg/dl can be used as screening tests for diabetes in a primary health center (PHC). FBS has been replaced by HbA1C as the best screening test for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus in appropriate settings, where available.

questions.text: Staphylococcus aureus was isolated from the sputum culture of an elderly male suspected to have hospital-acquired pneumonia. You perform the Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method to check if the S.aureus strain is methicillin resistant. Which is the culture medium used in this test?
questions.solution:
Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar is used in Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method of antibiotic sensitivity testing. 

To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E–test (Epsilometer)

 The image below shows Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method.

Other options:

Option A: Potassium Tellurite Agar is an indicator medium where potassium tellurite is reduced to metallic tellurium by Corynebacterium diphtheriae to produce black colonies.

Option C: Wilson and Blair's medium is selective for Salmonella species. Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S.

An image of Wilson and Blair's medium is given below-

Option D: Skirrow’s medium is selective for Campylobacter species. It contains vancomycin, polymyxin B, and trimethoprim to inhibit the growth of other bacteria.

questions.text: A patient with familial hypertriglyceridemia comes with complaints of episodic right upper quadrant pain a few weeks after starting a drug for his condition. Which of the following was the likely drug started?
questions.solution:
This patient with Familial hypertriglyceridemia on therapy has now developed right upper quadrant pain. A fibrate like gemfibrozil was the likely drug he was started in; fibrates have been associated with an increased risk of gallstone formation. 

Familial hypertriglyceridemia occurs due to a defect in the lipolysis of the triglyceride-rich lipoproteins (TRLs). As a result of this, the levels of fasting triglyceride levels are elevated. Plasma LDL levels are reduced due to the defective conversion of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins to LDL. Identification of hypertriglyceridemia in first-degree relatives helps in the diagnosis.

Hypertriglyceridemia can also be secondary due to intake of simple carbohydrates, obesity, insulin resistance, alcohol use, and estrogen treatment.

Initial management involves exercise and dietary management (restriction of fatty food, avoidance of alcohol, estrogen-containing medications, etc)

If the levels of the triglycerides are >500 mg/dL despite lifestyle changes, then fibrates and fish oil can be used to reduce the levels and decrease the risk of pancreatitis. If the patient has risk factors for coronary heart disease, then statin therapy will be beneficial.

questions.text: An employee working in a multinational company was found guilty of manipulating the details of financial transactions and forging new cheques in his name. He can be punished under which of the following sections of IPC?
questions.solution:
In the case given above, the employee can be charged with forgery. Section 336 BNS (463 IPC) deals with forgery.

According to this, one who makes any false documents or false electronic record or part of a document or electronic record, with an intention to cause damage to the public or to any person, commits forgery.

Other options:

Option A- Section 229 BNS (193 IPC) deals with punishment for perjury.

Option B- Section 106(1) BNS (304A IPC) deals with causing death by negligence.

Option D- Section 271 BNS (270 IPC) deals with malignant acts likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life.

questions.text: You see a patient started on an IV drug for endocarditis develop redness over his face and back. Which of the following could have prevented this?

choices.text: Giving it via a central line

questions.solution:
The given scenario most likely describes a patient with endocarditis recieving a vancomycin infusion.  The cutaneous symptoms described is the red man syndrome.

This is a common adverse effect of the rapid administration of vancomycin. The redness is due to the release of histamine in the body. This should always be anticipated while giving vancomycin infusion and can be prevented by prior administration of antihistamines and prolonging the infusion period to 1 to 2 hours.

Other such syndromes associated with drugs are:

  • Blue man syndrome - Amiodarone
  • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

Other options:

Prior saline boluses, giving the drug via a central line, and premedication with epinephrine are not the steps of management of Red Man syndrome.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college-going student presents to you with a rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. She has a history of persistent eye rubbing. You noticed Munson's sign when the patient was asked to look with a downward gaze. What is this type of refractive error called?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and Munson's sign on downward gaze  is suggestive of keratoconus and the form of myopia associated with it is pathological curvature myopia.

Etiological classfication of myopia

  • excessive accommodation

  • refractive change that appears in childhood and progresses to adulthood

Keratoconus

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Keratoconus is a progressive bilateral corneal ectatic disorder. It manifests as characteristic cone-like steepening of the cornea associated with irregular stromal thinning, resulting in a cone-like bulge (protrusion) and significant loss of vision.

It is a non-inflammatory disease. With the exception of the significant loss of vision, other classic signs of inflammation are not usually present. The asymmetrical thinning and the highly irregular corneal topography often cause significant myopia and irregular astigmatism.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby with recurrent infections was brought with complaints of diaper rash. On examination, it is found that he has no tonsils. A swab of the rash shows candidal growth. What is the likely etiology ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with absent tonsils(B cell dysfunction) and recurrent diaper rash positive for candida(T cell dysfunction) is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Usually, the defect lies in the T-cell compartment with secondary impairment in humoral immunity.

Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

There are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance:

1. X-linked SCID is the most common form and hence it is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect is the mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. T-cell numbers are greatly reduced, and although B cells may be normal in number, antibody synthesis is impaired because of the lack of T-cell help. The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

2. Autosomal recessive is most commonly caused due to deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA). The deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes.

In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells. In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

Note: X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Other Options:
Option A Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in phagocytes oxidase which is required for the generation of superoxide. Its defect results in recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Option B Transient hypogammaglobulinemia can be seen in children less than 6 months old and is characterized by a low IgG level. This condition resolves after 6 months after birth.

Option D Reduced immunoglobulin titres is the defect in Bruton's agammaglobulinemia. Patients usually have no infection till 6 months as they're protected by their mother's antibodies.

questions.text: A biochemist is working on a study of enzyme activation in the fed and fasting state. He gives a dose of insulin to the study animal. Which of the following enzymes will be activated in response to this dose?
questions.solution:
Pyruvate dehydrogenase is highly active in the high insulin/well-fed/dephosphorylated state.

The rest of the enzymes are active in the phosphorylated state/low insulin/fasting state.

Fasting state / low insulin state :

Liver :

With a fall in the blood glucose levels, there is a fall in insulin levels with less uptake of glucose by muscle and adipose tissues. α-cells of the pancreas secrete glucagon which inhibits glycogen synthetase and in turn activates glycogen phosphorylase. This eventually releases glucose into the bloodstream intended for the use of the brain and RBCs. Glucagon stimulates the production of cAMP, activating cAMP-dependent protein kinase. This in turn inactivates phosphofructokinase-2 and activates fructose 2,6-bisphosphatase by phosphorylation.

Muscle: 

Acetyl-CoA formed by oxidation of fatty acids causes inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase consequently leading to an accumulation of pyruvate. It is then converted to alanine which is then transaminated back to pyruvate in the liver. This is used as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Adipose tissue:

A fall in insulin and an increase in glucagon leads to inhibition of lipogenesis and activation of hormone-sensitive lipase. This leads to a massive release of glycerol which serves as a substrate for gluconeogenesis in the liver. It is also utilised by the liver, heart, and skeletal muscle as metabolic fuel.

As fasting progresses, acetyl-CoA is used for the synthesis of ketone bodies which are utilised by skeletal and heart muscles and up to 20% of the brain's energy source. After 18 hours of fasting, amino acids from protein catabolism are utilized by the liver and kidneys for gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old presents to the casualty with a history of blunt trauma to the head. MRI shows injury to the cranial nerve present in the dorsal aspect of the brainstem. Which of the following eye movements will be compromised in this patient?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve is the only nerve that exits the brainstem on the dorsal surface and thus can be injured in this patient. It supplies the superior oblique muscle whose actions are intorsion(medial rotation), depression, and abduction. Therefore intorsion will be compromised in this patient.

Trochlear nerve:

  • Thinnest/smallest cranial nerve
  • Only cranial nerve with dorsal exit. All other cranial nerves exit the brainstem from the ventral surface.
  • Emerges from the midbrain and passes onto the crus of the cerebral peduncle on its lateral surface.
  • Longest intracranial course.
  • Only nerve with internal decussation.

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except, the lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve and the superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve.

In 4th nerve palsy, the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • Weakness of depression: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of the Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction.
  • Failure of intorsion- Patient presents with contralateral face turn and head tilt with chin slightly depressed to avoid diplopia.
  • Normal abduction and elevation.

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. If the conjunctival scrapings of this patient are stained with Giemsa, which of the following inclusion bodies will be seen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits.This finding is seen in trachoma, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC) serovars A, B, Ba, C. Halberstaedter-Prowazek (HP) bodies are demonstrated in conjunctival scrapings of patients with trachoma.

Due to their glycogen matrix, they may be stained with Lugol's iodine, which has been used as a rapid and simple screening method for trachoma. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage. The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children. They present with conjunctival follicles containing Leber cells and corneal Herbert's follicles.

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. The patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia and finally loss of vision. Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed Herbert follicles)
  • Corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Other options:

Option B: Levinthal-Cole-Lillie (LCL) bodies are inclusion bodies of Chlamydia psittaci seen in patients suffering from psittacosis. Distinguishing features from inclusion bodies of C. trachomatis are that they are more diffuse and irregular and are not stained by iodine.

Option C: Miyagawa granulocorpuscles/ elementary bodies are inclusion bodies seen in lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). They are intracytoplasmic microcolonies of Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes L1, L2, and L3, seen on microscopy of the aspirated material from the buboes. 

Option D: Henderson-Patterson bodies- Molluscum contagiosum shows the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies (Shown in the image below).

questions.text:
A patient in the ICU, who was in a comatose condition, was shifted onto the ventilator for assisted ventilation. Which of the following circuits will be used in this condition?

Fresh gas flow - Blue 

Adjustable pressure-limiting (APL) valve - Red
questions.solution:
The patient in the given case scenario would be put on controlled ventilation. The most appropriate circuit to be used in this case is the Mapleson D circuit which is depicted in image 2, since it is one of the most efficacious circuits for controlled ventilation. Modification of Mapleson D is known as the Bain circuit.

The order of efficiency for controlled ventilation amongst Mapleson circuits is DFE>BC>A.

Image 2 is identified as the Mapleson D circuit due to the following observations:

  • Fresh gas flow (blue) is near the patient's mouth
  • APL valve(red) is away from the patient's mouth
  • Presence of a reservoir bag distal to APL valve.

The Mapleson D circuit is efficient during controlled ventilation since it has a very low requirement of fresh gas flow in terms of minute ventilation (only 1-2 times the minute ventilation). In this circuit, the fresh gas flow forces alveolar air away from the patient and toward the APL valve. 

The Bain circuit is a coaxial version of the Mapleson D system that incorporates the fresh gas inlet tubing inside the breathing tube. This modification decreases the circuit’s bulk and retains heat and humidity better than a conventional Mapleson D circuit as a result of partial warming of the inspiratory gas by countercurrent exchange with the warmer expired gases.

The order of efficiency for spontaneous ventilation amongst Mapleson circuits is A>DFE> CB.

Other options: 

Option B - Image 1 is identified as Mapleson A. It is the most efficacious for use in spontaneous ventilation.

Option C - Image 4 is identified as Mapleson B. This circuit is less efficacious than Mapleson D in controlled ventilation.

Option D - Image 3 is identified as Mapleson F. This circuit is less efficacious than Mapleson D in controlled ventilation.

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

questions.text: Which of the following is false about RB as the governor of cell cycle?

choices.text: The function of RB protein is to regulate at the G1-S checkpoint
Hypophosphorylated state of the RB promote cell cycle progression
Active RB binds and inhibits the E2F family of transcription factors preventing transcription of cyclin E

questions.solution:
Hyperphosphorylated state (inactive) of RB protein promotes cell cycle progression.

RB, called the Governor of Proliferation is a key negative regulator of the G1/S cell cycle transition and is directly or indirectly inactivated in most human cancers.

  • The normal RB gene is present on chromosome 13q14.
  • RB -  active hypophosphorylated state in quiescent cells and an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells passing through the G1/S cell cycle transition.
  • Cyclin D/CDK-4 phosphorylates RB inactivating the protein, and releases E2F to induce target genes such as cyclin E.
  • RB -  antiproliferative effects by binding and inhibiting E2F transcription factors, thereby preventing transcription of cyclin E, required for cells to pass through the G1-S phase cell cycle checkpoint.
  • The antiproliferative effect of RB is abrogated in cancers through a variety of mechanisms, including:
    • Loss-of-function mutations affecting RB
    • Gene amplification of CDK4 and cyclin D genes
    • Loss of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors (p16/INK4a)
    • Viral oncoproteins that bind and inhibit RB (E7 protein of HPV)

Loss-of-function mutations of the RB gene are associated with retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma, a subset of glioblastomas, small-cell carcinomas of the lung, breast cancers, and bladder carcinomas.

questions.text: As a paramedic, you examine a G2P1 lady in the ambulance, who is in labour. Her vitals are stable, her uterus is term-sized, and the fetus is in cephalic presentation. On further evaluation, you discover an unusual finding, which prompts you to change her position to the exaggerated Sim's position and insert a Foley's catheter to fill her bladder with 500 mL of saline before clamping it. However, on reaching the hospital, the baby was found dead. What is the most likely cause of death in this baby?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a G2P1 lady in labour, the sudden postural change to the exaggerated Sim's position and the insertion of a foley catheter to fill her bladder with 500 mL of saline before clamping it (Vago's method) is highly suggestive of cord prolapse. The fetus is at a high risk of developing anoxia from the moment the cord is prolapsed due to vasospasm of the umbilical vessels on exposure to cold or irritation. 

The management algorithm of cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

  • Living or dead baby
  • Maturity of the baby
  • Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

First aid management of cord prolapse where vaginal delivery is not possible, aims at minimizing the pressure on the cord till the patient is transferred to an equipped hospital. It includes:

  • Vago's method, also known as the bladder filling method is done to alleviate pressure on the cord. It is. Here, the bladder is distended with  400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.
  • Postural treatment includes exaggerated and elevated Sims’ position, Trendelenburg or knee-chest position
  • To lift the presenting part of the cord.

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is given below: 

Given below are the images of Trendelenburg's position, exaggerated Sim’s position, and knee-chest position, respectively:

Other options:

Option B: Umbilical cord entanglement occurs when either one or more loops of the umbilical cord encircle any part of the fetal body. The condition may produce sufficient compression on the cord vessels so as to produce fetal distress or rarely death but Vago's method as mentioned in the above scenario is not associated with the management of cord entanglement.

Option C: False knot is a bulge in the cord caused by excessive Wharton's jelly or looping of the cord vessels, not associated with the death of the fetus.

Option D: True knot forms when the umbilical cord loops or interweaves around itself. However, the fetal vessels are protected from compression, by the Wharton’s jelly and are unlikely to cause death.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old baby was brought with complaints of pink morbilliform rashes on the trunk as shown below. The child had a history of high fever for 3 days following which these rashes appeared. On oral examination, ulcers are present at the uvulopalatoglossal junction. Which of the following herpes viruses is most likely to be implicated in the pathogenesis of this disease?

HHV- Human herpesvirus
questions.solution:
The history of fever and ulcers at the uvulopalatoglossal junction (Nagayama spots) along with the image showing pink morbilliform rashes on the trunk of an infant makes the likely diagnosis roseola infantum. It is caused by a human Herpesvirus (HHV)- 6B, and 7.

Roseola infantum is also called as sixth disease or exanthema subitum. HHV-6B is responsible for the majority of cases of roseola infantum and only a small percentage of children with roseola have a primary infection with HHV-7.

Primary HHV-6B infection peaks between the ages of 6 and 9 months.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodrome of high-grade fever
  • Non-pruritic, morbilliform rash, which appears as the fever comes down.
  • Leucopenia and relative lymphocytosis
  • Nagayama spots: ulcers at uvulo-palatoglossal junction

Diagnosis includes polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for detecting the viral DNA.

This is a self-limiting disease and treatment is done as supportive care in the form of maintaining hydration and using antipyretics if the child has a fever.

HHV-2 Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) Oral and/ or genital herpes (Mainly genital)
HHV-3 Varicella zoster virus (VZV) Chickenpox and shingles
HHV-4 Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) Infectious mononucleosis, Burkitt's lymphoma, Post-transplant lymphoproliferative disease, Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, CNS lymphoma in AIDS patients, and HIV-associated hairy leukoplakia
HHV-5 Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient is scheduled to undergo an elective septoplasty for DNS. What is the preferred position of the patient for this procedure?
questions.solution:
In both septoplasty and SMR, the patient is placed in reclining position with the head end raised.

Septoplasty is a conservative technique in the surgical correction of septal deformity. The key advantage is that it can be carried out as a daycare procedure, most of the bone and cartilage are retained, and complications are less. The deformed septum may corrected by various techniques like scoring the concave side, shaving, wedge excision. Sometimes realignment by joining straight pieces of the septum outside the nose and replacing them can be done which is called extra-corporeal septoplasty.

Indications include:

  • Symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches
  • Recurrent sinusitis and otitis media
  • Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur
  • Septal deviation causing sleep apnea or hypopnoea syndrome
  • As a part of septorhinoplasty in cosmetic surgery

Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of cartilage Conservative procedure
Not done in < 18 yrs Done in children and adults
Killian’s incision is used Freer’s incision is used
Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised on both sides of the septum Flaps raised on only one side
More complications Fewer complications

Other Options:

Option A: Supine position may be used in diagnostic nasal endoscopy or in FESS. In ear surgery, patient is supine with the head turned so the affected ear faces upwards.

Option B: Supine position with neck extension is also known as Rose position and is used in tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy. 

Option D: Trendelenburg position refers to the supine position with the foot end of the operating table raised. It is rarely used in ENT procedures but is commonly used in lower GI and urological procedures.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with the following lesions on the back and similar multiple, nodulocystic lesions on the face. She has tried various remedies for this condition like chemical peeling, topical and oral antibiotics, but there was no respite. She requests you to prescribe the most effective drug for this condition. You decide to start her on oral isotretinoin after performing a baseline evaluation of serum lipids, serum transaminases, and CBC. You would be correct to do all of the following except:

choices.text: Inform the patient to do monthly pregnancy tests while on the drug
Inform the patient to repeat testing of serum lipids, serum transaminases, and CBC again in 6 months
Ask the patient to take the drug along with high-fat meals
Ask the patient to delay pregnancy as this is a teratogenic drug

questions.solution:
Baseline evaluation of serum lipids, transaminases, and CBC should be done before starting any systemic retinoids. These values should be checked monthly for the first 3–6 months and once every 3 months thereafter.

Systemic absorption of isotretinoin is improved when taken with a fatty meal. Patients on isotretinoin should be asked to delay pregnancy as this is a teratogenic drug. Monthly pregnancy tests should be done while on the drug.

 Acne is a multifactorial condition characterized by excess sebum production, epithelial hyperkeratinization, cutibacterium acnes colonization in the pilosebaceous unit, and inflammation. Isotretinoin is an oral-systemic retinoid that has been approved for the treatment of recalcitrant and nodular acne vulgaris and is remarkably effective in severe acne. It can induce prolonged remissions after a single course of therapy. Clinical effects are seen within 1–3 months of starting therapy. Systemic absorption is improved when taken with a high-fat meal.

Mucocutaneous side effects like cheilitis, xerosis, blepharoconjunctivitis, cutaneous photosensitivity, photophobia, myalgia, arthralgia, headaches, alopecia, nail fragility, and increased susceptibility to staphylococcal infections can be seen with use. Retinoid dermatitis can develop which is characterized by erythema, pruritus, and scaling. Very rarely, patients can also develop pseudotumor cerebri, especially when systemic retinoids are taken with antibiotics like tetracyclines.

Systemic retinoids are highly teratogenic and no dose is safe during pregnancy. Absolute contraindications include pregnant women, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding mothers. Two negative pregnancy tests (on separate occasions) are required for females of childbearing age before starting acitretin or isotretinoin.

Serum lipid elevation is the most common laboratory abnormality. Elevated transaminases, decreased thyroid hormone, and leukopenia is less common.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy was brought with complaints of repeatedly twitching his mouth, raising his eyebrows, and grunting since he was 6 years old. There is a new-onset habit of throat clearing multiple times a day. Which of the following is associated with the child's condition?

ADHD - Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

choices.text: Autism spectrum disorder, Major depressive disorder

questions.solution:
The child has symptoms of Tourette's syndrome, which is associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics.  Vocal tics can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting, barking noises, or shouted words. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to shouting or speaking socially unacceptable or obscene words.

Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for OCD and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

The DSM-V criteria for the diagnosis of Tourette syndrome include:

  • Presence of both multiple motor and one or more vocal tics, at some time during the illness. Although both need not occur simultaneously.
  • The tics may wax and wane in frequency but have persisted for more than 1 year since the onset of the first tic.
  • Onset is before the age of 18 years.
  • The disorder is not attributable to the physiological effects of substance abuse (e.g. cocaine) or underlying medical condition (e.g., Huntington’s disease, postviral encephalitis). 

Behavioral interventions like habit reversal, comprehensive behavioral intervention, and exposure and response prevention are the first line of treatment where the academic performance or social life is not affected.

Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. 
First-line agents are antipsychotics like aripiprazole or noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine, clonidine, and guanfacine can be used as adjunctive for comorbid ADHD. Alternative treatments are tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol

questions.text: The occurrence of dengue infection in Bangladesh has been documented as illustrated below. This epidemiological pattern represents which of the following types of trends?
questions.solution:
The increase in incidence of dengue during months September through November each year during this 2 year time frame is described as a seasonal trend.

Seasonal trends reflect seasonal changes in disease occurrence following changes in environmental conditions that enhance the ability of the agent to replicate or be transmitted. For example, measles (usually occurs in early spring), varicella, etc. Non-infectious conditions like hay fever and snake bites may also show seasonal variations.

 

Other options:

Option A: The secular trend describes the occurrence of disease over a prolonged period, usually years. Even though it may have short-term fluctuations, there is a tendency of the disease occurrence to change consistently in a particular direction or a definite movement in one direction.

Examples of the secular trend include coronary heart disease, lung cancer, and diabetes, which have shown a consistent upward trend in incidence as well as prevalence, in developed countries. Similarly, there has been a consistent decline in the diseases such as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria, and polio.

Option B: Cyclic trend is shown by some diseases that occur in cycles spread over short periods of time which may be, days, weeks, months, or years.  Examples include the influenza pandemic, which is known to occur at intervals of every 7–10 years due to antigenic variations.

Option C: Propagative epidemics are most likely infectious in origin. They gradually rise and tapers over a long period of time. Examples include polio, hepatitis A.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with changes over the skin of the nose as seen in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image above shows an exophytic, pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation suggesting a diagnosis of phymatous rosacea or rhinophyma.

Acne rosacea is a type of acne that is present in white, middle-aged patients. It is characterized by facial erythema.

The various subtypes of acne rosacea-

  • Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea is the stage where there are multiple telangiectasias and facial erythema present. Facial vascular hyperreactivity is often seen.
  • Papulopustular rosacea is characterized by small dome-shaped papules with tiny areas of pustulation and perilesional erythema. 
  • Phymatous rosacea is characterized by thickened skin and prominent follicular openings. Rhinophyma is the commonest type of phymatous rosacea. There is marked nasal distortion with an increase in size and a bulbous tip.
  • Ocular rosacea presents with eye involvement. Patients have dryness, slight itching, and grittiness early in the disease.

The diagnosis is clinical. General guidelines in the management of acne rosacea:

  • Use sunscreens with both UVA and UVB protection.
  • Use soap‐free, pH‐balanced detergents and lukewarm water to wash the face.
  • Avoid astringents, abrasive exfoliators, and procedures such as dermabrasion.
  • Avoid environments that may overheat and/or dry the skin

Treatment for various subtypes of acne rosacea:

Erythema in erythematotelangiectatic rosacea is treated with topical α‐receptor agonists such as brimonidine or oxymetazoline.

In papulopustular rosacea, active inflammatory lesions are treated using topical agents such as metronidazole 0.75% gel, azelaic acid 15% gel, and sulfur 5% preparations.

Phytomatous rosacea is treated by the nasal application of a skin‐peeling agent for treating large occluded follicles and oily skin. Perinasal telangiectatic vessels are ablated with electrocautery or laser. Isotretinoin therapy can be considered if the condition is progressive.

Ocular rosacea is managed by maintaining daily lid hygiene, using warm compresses to aid the removal of secretions, and lubricating eye drops.

questions.text: A radiologist performs the following scan on a female patient with a suspected breast mass. Which of the following is considered a standard view of this radiological test?
questions.solution:
The radiological test shown above is a mediolateral oblique (MLO) view in 2D digital mammography. The two standard views used in mammography are the craniocaudal (CC) view and the mediolateral oblique (MLO) view.

The mammogram is an X-ray picture of the breast. The anode in the X-ray tube is made up of molybdenum. There are numerous mammography views that can broadly be split into two groups

  1. Standard views 
  2. Supplementary views- taken to solve specific diagnostic problems.

The 2 standard views include:

  1. Mediolateral oblique (MLO) view- covers a greater volume of breast tissue. The x-ray beam is directed from the superomedial to inferolateral at a 30 to 60-degree angle, with compression applied obliquely across the chest wall.
  2. Craniocaudal (CC) view- provides better visualization of the medial aspect of the breast. The X-ray beam travels from superior to inferior, with compression applied from above. It demonstrates the nipple, all of the medial tissue, and most of the lateral tissue except the axillary tail of the breast. 

Supplementary views include true lateral view, paddle view, and Eklund technique.

A true lateral view may be obtained as a mediolateral view (ML) or lateromedial view (LM) view depending on where the imaging tube and detector are located. Localized compression or ‘paddle views’ involves the application of more vigorous compression to a localized area using a compression paddle. In breast implant patients, the Eklund procedure can be used to move the implant posteriorly, behind the compression plate, increasing the volume of breast tissue compressed and imaged.

The radiation dose for a standard two-view examination of the breast is approximately 3 mGy.
