questions.text:
The mean level of CRP in patients with myocardial infarction was determined in a study. The study included 1000 patients, and one of the purposes was to compare the mean CRP in both male and female MI patients. Which of the following tests should be used to establish whether there is a difference in mean CRP levels between the two groups?

CRP - C - reactive protein
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the Unpaired student t-test would be performed to compare the results obtained as it is used for comparing two groups of patients i.e. male and female patients for a quantitative variable (CRP level).

Tests of significance are used to check for significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student t-test, Paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fischer-exact test.

An unpaired t-test is a parametric statistical test determining whether a statistically significant difference exists between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups. 

Other options:

Option A: Paired t-test is used for a single sample to test the difference between two paired results. 

Option B: Chi-square test is used to differentiate proportions in two or more groups and assess the significance. 

Option D: A correlation analysis employs the correlation coefficient to characterize the linear association between two quantitative variables, such as in a research investigation assessing the linear relationship between cigarette usage and squamous cell carcinoma of the lung incidence.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: You are posted in a CHC as a part of your postings. The region has experienced a notable increase in cases of urban malaria. Which of the following approaches would you recommend as the most effective method for arthropod control?

choices.text: Filling and draining of breeding places
Paris green mixed in the water
Provide the entire community with mosquito nets

questions.solution:
Environmental control is the best approach to control arthropods such as Anopheles which is a cause of Urban Malaria. (specifically Anopheles stephensi ).

Urban malaria refers to malaria transmission occurring in urban or metropolitan areas, typically in regions that were previously not associated with malaria. This form of malaria can be caused by the introduction or re-emergence of Anopheles mosquitoes that transmit the disease, despite urbanization efforts like better infrastructure and sanitation.

Environmental control of Anopheles includes: 

  • Filling and draining of breeding places.
  • Levelling: prevents water collection in depressions, which can act as breeding grounds.
  • Intermittent irrigation: Mosquitoes are discouraged from breeding by not allowing water to remain stagnant for long periods.
  • Changing the salinity of water: prevent mosquito larvae from developing 

Mosquito-specific measures of source reduction :

Anopheles Filling and draining of breeding places
Aedes Elimination of artificial collections of water (e.g., tins, coconut shells)
Mansonia Herbicides sprayed on aquatic plants
Culex

Elimination of breeding sources such as cesspools and open ditches and the disposal of sewage and wastewater.

The principles of arthropod control include:

  • Environmental control - The best approach is to manage water sources, drainage, and sanitation.
  • Vector control:
    • Anti-adult measures: Residual spraying, Space application of pesticides in the form of mist, individual protection
    • Anti-larval measures: Larvicides (temephos), Biological control - Use of larvivorous fish like Gambusia
    • Integrated Approach
  • Genetic control - Genetic modification of mosquitoes to reduce their ability to transmit diseases.
  • Newer methods -
    • Chemosterilants
    • Insect growth regulators
    • Sex attractants
  • Integrated approach combines multiple methods for effective arthropod control.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes with complaints of severe headaches for 3 weeks that are unresponsive to analgesia. MRI Brain is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis and the cell involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests the presence of an intracranial space occupying the lesion. The MRI shows a growth that is crossing the corpus callosum with areas of necrosis. This is most likely Glioblastoma multiforme, which is an aggressive tumor of astrocytes. 

Glioblastoma falls under WHO grade IV brain tumors

According to the WHO Classification of CNS Diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:

Glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype:

  • About 90% of cases
  • Primary or de novo glioblastoma
  • Over 55 years of age
  • Mutations: EGFR, PTEN
  • Carries poor prognosis

Glioblastoma, IDH-mutant:

  • About 10% of cases
  • Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
  • Arises in younger patients
  • Mutations:p53
  • Better prognosis

Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma multiforme. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

The histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudopalisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which is characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme).

MRI of a glioblastoma shows a necrotic hemorrhagic mass that usually crosses the corpus callosum. 

Other Options: 

Meningiomas are primary extra-axial neoplasms arising from the meningothelial arachnoidal cells. It is seen as a well-defined, hyperdense mass close to the midline, situated extra-axially.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the ER with a history of colicky abdominal pain that has worsened over the past few hours. On examination, the following clinical finding is noted. All of the following are true about this condition except?

choices.text: Empty left iliac fossa indicates positive Sign of Dance
The patient may have bilious vomiting
Ileocolic junction is the most common site of involvement
Meckel's diverticulum is a possible lead point

questions.solution:
An acute abdomen with a sausage-shaped mass with its concavity towards the umbilicus is one of the characteristic findings in a patient with intussusception. An empty right-iliac fossa in this condition is called the Sign of Dance.

Intussusception occurs when a portion of the bowel is telescoped into an adjacent segment. Patients present with cramping abdominal pain, palpable sausage-shaped abdominal mass, and passage of red currant jelly stools. Vomiting may not begin later and with time, may be bile-stained (Option B).

Intussusception is one of the common causes of intestinal obstruction in a paediatric patient. Ileo-colic junction is the most common site of involvement (Option C). The condition may arise due to the presence of lead points as seen in enlarged submucosal Payer's patch, Meckel's diverticulum (Option D), intestinal polyp, inflamed appendix, submucosal hemorrhage seen in Henoch-Schonlein purpura, and intestinal duplication cysts.

Diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound which shows the pathognomonic target sign/bull's eye sign (shown below). 

Treatment of intussusception includes hydrostatic reduction by enema using contrast material or air. Surgical reduction is only done in the presence of refractory shock, suspected bowel necrosis or perforation, peritonitis, and multiple recurrences after hydrostatic reduction.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida complains of severe abdominal pain. On examination, she is exhausted and dehydrated.  Obstructed labor is suspected and cesarean section is advocated. Which national program could potentially alleviate the financial burden for the family with regard to the recommended procedure?
questions.solution:
The Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) has provisions for free cesaren section for pregnant women.

The provisions of JSSK include:

  • Free transport
  • Free treatment
  • Free drugs and consumables
  • Free diagnostics and diet
  • Free and cashless delivery
  • Free C-Section
  • Free provision of blood

Note: Previously under JSSK, the free entitlements were provided only for sick newborns till 30 days after birth. Now it is expanded to cover infants also.

Assured 18 service guarantees are provided to all pregnant women under Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN). It is a new initiative to provide assured, dignified, respectful, and quality healthcare at no cost and zero tolerance for denial of services for every woman and newborn visiting the public health facility. It aims to end all preventable maternal and newborn deaths, and morbidities and provide a positive birthing experience. 

Other options :

Option A: Janani Suraksha Yojana aims to reduce maternal mortality by encouraging delivery in government health facilities. Under the scheme, a financial incentive is also provided for giving birth in a government health facility. 

Option B: The Laqshya initiative plans to conduct quality certification of labour rooms and also incentivize facilities to achieve the targets outlined. The goal of this initiative is to reduce preventable maternal and newborn mortality, morbidity, and stillbirths associated with the care around delivery in the labour room and maternity OT and ensure respectful maternity care.

Option D: Under the Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (PMSMA), quality antenatal care (including investigations and drugs) is provided free of cost on the 9th of every month.

questions.text: Which of the following radiological imaging modalities are used to examine the fibres seen in the structure marked below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the given image of the sagittal section of the brain is the corpus callosum which contains white matter fibres called commissural fibres. The technique used to map white matter fibres is called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).

Diffusion tensor imaging is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid, is assessed in six or more directions. It helps to identify the location, orientation, and anisotropy of the white matter tracts and their connections (tractography). It is used in preoperative planning to visualize the relations between intrinsic brain tumours and surrounding neural connections.

and identify any disease process that affects it. White matter fibres include:

  • Association fibres
  • Commissural fibres
  • Projection fibres
  • Subcortical fibres.

The technique is based on the principle that the diffusion in the brain is directionally dependent (anisotropic), which is more in the compacted white matter tracts, and least evident in grey matter. 

The image below shows diffusion tensor tractography:

Arcuate fasciculus (AF), the superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF), the inferior longitudinal fasciculus (ILF), the uncinate fasciculus (UF), and inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus (IFOF). (Arrows at bottom right. A: Anterior, L: Lateral).

Commissural fibres originate in one hemisphere, cross the midline and project to the contralateral hemisphere.

The locations of the commissural fibres are:

  • Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain
  • Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix  

Other options:

Option A: Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI refers to the serial MRI acquisitions following IV contrast agent.

Option B: Dynamic susceptibility contrast MRI measures induced alterations in the transverse relaxation times (T2 and T2*). This results in signal loss causing transient darkening of the tissues.

Option D: Functional magnetic resonance imaging detects changes in the regional cerebral blood flow during various brain activities. It is used to study the eloquent (e.g., motor) cortical activation.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of altered sensorium and abdominal pain. She appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed pH - 7.00, blood sugar level- 500 mg/dL, and ketonuria. She is started on IV insulin with Potassium infusion. Which of the following parameters can be used to assess the recovery of the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with severe dehydration, hyperglycemia, ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis(pH-7.00) suggests a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) likely due to undiagnosed Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus. The serum anion gap is a test that can be used to measure the recovery of the patient.

In DKA, due to the absence of insulin, there is a decrease in glucose uptake in cells in the body leading to a state of starvation. This leads to an increase in levels of glucagon and ketone bodies to provide a constant source of energy to the cells including the myocardial and neural tissue. Increased serum ketones widen the anion gap which is why DKA is an Anion gap metabolic acidosis.  Serum anion gap can be used to measure the response to treatment and also helps in planning further management. As the patient receives insulin, there is a cessation of production of ketoacids and this in turn leads to the normalisation of the serum anion gap.

In DKA, the insulin-to-glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiologic pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to acidosis.

The diagnostic biochemical criteria for DKA include:

  • Hyperglycemia (>200 mg/dL)
  • Venous pH <7.3 or plasma/serum bicarbonate <15 mmol/L 
  • Ketonemia (beta-hydroxybutyrate [BOHB] >3 mmol/L) and ketonuria

Signs of ketoacidosis: 

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, heavy, non-labored rapid breathing)
  • Fruity breath odor (acetone)
  • Prolonged Q-T interval
  • Diminished neurocognitive function
  • Coma

Management: Based on the ISPAD guidelines, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation and fluid replacement with an IV bolus of 10 mL/kg normal saline over 1 hour. This is followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.1 U/kg/hour.

questions.text: Given below is a transverse B mode doppler ultrasound image done at the saphenofemoral junction in a 40-year-old male patient.  All of the following structures are responsible for this USG appearance except _________
questions.solution:
The given transverse B mode doppler ultrasound image of the saphenofemoral junction shows the Mickey Mouse sign and the internal iliac artery is not responsible for Mickey mouse sign.

Mickey mouse sign is formed by:

  • Common Femoral Vein (CFV)
  • Common Femoral Artery (CFA)
  • Greater Saphenous Vein (GSV) at the Saphenofemoral junction (SFJ).

It represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels as seen in a duplex ultrasound.

questions.text: In the assessment of a patient with diminished hearing, the function of which of the following structures is tested when the tuning fork is struck and placed on the mastoid?
questions.solution:
When the tuning fork is struck and placed on the mastoid to assess bone conduction, the cochlea is stimulated directly by vibrations conducted through the bones of the skull. Therefore, it is a measure of cochlear function only.

Tuning fork tests are used to assess air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC) in the hearing apparatus. To test AC, the tuning fork is struck and placed in front of the external auditory canal. The sound is conducted through the tympanic membrane, middle ear and ear ossicles to the inner ear. Hence, the conducting mechanism, as well as the cochlea, are assessed. However, to test BC, when the tuning fork is struck and placed on the mastoid or at the vertex, as is done in Weber's Test, the vibrations are conducted through skull bones and not through the ossicles, thereby directly stimulating the cochlea.

Therefore, although it is called the 'bone conduction' test, it is not an assessment of the function of the ossicles but of the cochlea.

For routine clinical practice, a tuning fork of 512 Hz is ideal. The clinically relevant tuning fork tests performed include:

  • Rinne's Test
  • Weber's Test
  • Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) Test
  • Gelle's Test
  • Schwabach's Test
  • Bing Test

questions.text: A patient with a history of Crohn's disease presents with the lesion in the picture below. What is the likely cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient with Crohn's disease who has developed reddish lesions on his lower limbs most likely has erythema nodosum. The most common triggers for erythema nodosum are bacterial infections, sarcoidosis, and inflammatory bowel disease.

The most common infectious cause of erythema nodosum is group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

Aetiological factors in erythema nodosum:

  • Infections: Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, tuberculosis, leprosy, brucella, toxoplasmosis, mycoplasma pneumonia, CMV, E.coli, yersinia, tuberculosis
  • Idiopathic, pregnancy
  • Drugs including oral contraceptives, hormonal replacement therapy, sulphonamides, and penicillin
  • Sarcoidosis, Sweet syndrome, SLE, RA, Reiter's syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease, Behcet's disease
  • Malignancy

Pathophysiology:

Erythema nodosum is the result of a non-specific cutaneous reaction to various antigens. It is postulated to be a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction to various antigens. 

Histopathologically, erythema nodosum predominantly shows septal panniculitis without vasculitis.

Clinical features:

The prodromal phase includes fever, joint, and muscle pains, and an alteration in general health. It is followed by the development of painful, tender, nodules on the extensor surfaces of the legs, knees, and forearms. It usually resolves spontaneously in about 10 days. Treatment is mostly supportive.

questions.text:
A patient presented with features shown in the image. Genetic testing reveals an ABCA1 mutation. Which of the following would most likely be seen in his lab report?

HDL - High density lipoprotein

VLDL - Very low density lipoprotein

LDL - low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The presence of orange tonsils in conjunction with an ABCA1 mutation indicates a potential diagnosis of Tangier's disease, characterized by significantly reduced levels of apo A1 in the patient's lipid profile. Normal or low cholesterol may be seen in patients with Tangiers but is not specific to the disease.

In the human body, apo A1 increases the levels of ABCA1 and ABCA1 in turn helps in the stabilization of the Apo A1. Apo A1 functions to activate LCAT which helps in the incorporation of cholesterol into the HDL. A mutation in ABCA1 would lead to increased catabolism of Apo A1 (low levels) which would lead to low incorporation of cholesterol into HDL. The various manifestations of the disease is due to the accumulation of cholesterol in the cells ie. defective clearance by HDL.

The lipid profile of a patient with Tangier's is most likely going to be :

HDL (Option C) ↓ ↓ 
VLDL (Option D) ↓ 
LDL ↓ 
TAG ↑ 
Total Cholesterol (Option B) Normal/Low
Apo A1 ↓ ↓ 

ABCA1 plays a role in the efflux of cholesterol from peripheral cells to HDL. Lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase (LCAT) converts cholesterol to cholesterol esters, which accumulate in the core of HDL. Thus defective ABCA1 will lead to almost nil HDL in the blood. ABCA1 is a protein belonging to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family. ABC proteins utilize the energy derived from the breakdown of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) to facilitate the transportation of various substances, such as lipids, across cellular membranes and intracellular compartments.

Tangier disease is a rare autosomal recessive  disease that can present as one of the following:

  • Asymmetric multiple neuropathies
  • A slowly progressive symmetric polyneuropathy
  • A pseudo-syringomyelia pattern with dissociated sensory loss
  • Corneal opacities
  • Premature atherosclerosis 
  • Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia
  • Skin ulcers, scalds and burns 

In this condition, the tonsils may appear yellowish-orange and there may be a splenomegaly with lymphadenopathy.

Differential Diagnosis of Tangier Disease : 

  • Apo A-I deficiency
  • LCAT deficiency
  • Fish eye disease

Tangier disease management involves low-fat diet changes, injury prevention, and management of cardiac problems. The utilization of Dalctrapid, a Cholesterol ester transfer protein (CETP) inhibitor, in conjunction with reconstituted HDL, could be considered as an interim therapeutic approach until more advanced treatments are produced.

questions.text: An obstetrician elicits a reflex by performing a procedure for labour induction on a patient as depicted in the image below. What type of homeostatic feedback mechanism is associated with this reflex?
questions.solution:
The procedure done in the image above to induce labour is the stripping of membranes which elicits the Ferguson reflex. Ferguson's reflex is associated with a positive feedback mechanism.

Stripping/Sweeping of membranes refers to the digital separation of the chorioamniotic membranes from the lower uterine segment and cervix wall. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost. 

Positive feedback is a type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state.

The fetal ejection reflex (Ferguson reflex) is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Oxytocin is released as the fetal head presses on the uterine cervix, which further enhances uterine contraction. This finally helps in the delivery of the fetus by facilitating fetal head descent. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.

Other options:

Option A: Negative feedback mechanism- If the activity of a particular system is increased, the controller system initiates the negative feedback mechanism, which prevents overactivity and ensures normal homeostasis (e.g., baroreceptor reflex). 

Option B: Feedforward control also called anticipatory control (option C), is that which makes an anticipatory or adaptive response without a specific stimulus. This is seen in body temperature regulation where thermoregulatory responses are initiated by the hypothalamus before the changes in environmental temperature change the core body temperature. Thus, shivering in response to a cold environment is an example of feedforward control.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with nausea, watery diarrhea and bloating following the consumption of skimmed milk. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with crampy abdominal pain, bloating and water diarrhea following the consumption of skimmed milk is most likely lactose intolerant with a brush border enzyme deficiency (ie. Lactase). 

Lactase is a brush border enzyme that hydrolyzes lactose into glucose and galactose. In lactase deficiency, patients have great variability in clinical symptoms, depending on both the severity of lactase deficiency and the amount of lactose ingested.

Lactose intolerance is a common cause of adult-onset diarrhea caused by malabsorption that affects individuals aged 20 to 40.  It has been described throughout the world, with significant variations amongst groups.

Lactose is converted to glucose and galactose by intestinal lactase on the brush border of the duodenum. As the osmotic burden of undigested lactose moves through the intestines, it draws water into the lumen and shortens transit time.  Colonic bacteria also ferment lactose, producing short-chain fatty acids and hydrogen gas (bloating).

Foods that are high in lactose include milk (12 g/cup), ice cream (9 g/cup), and cottage cheese (8 g/cup). Aged cheese has lower lactose content. Most people can tolerate up to 12g of lactose a day without significant symptoms.

Yogurt is the least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance. It contains lactobacillus that produces lactase and is generally well tolerated.

For patients with inconclusive diagnosis, a lactose breath hydrogen test can be performed.

The goal of treatment in patients with isolated lactase deficiency is achieving patient comfort through the elimination of dietary lactose or supplementation with lactase.

Other options :

Option A : Patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency have defective digestion of fat and protein with symptoms of steatorrhea. Patients with pancreatic insufficiency have risk factors such as cystic fibrosis, chronic pancreatitis or a history of bowel or pancreatic resection.

Option D : Luminal bacterial overgrowth is seen in small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) which occurs when colonic bacteria migrate into the small intestine. Diarrhea in SIBO is most likely oily/greasy. It is usually associated with patients with fistulas or a motility disorder. This patient did not present with symptoms of greasy stool nor did he have any underlying disorder making this diagnosis unlikely. 

Option C : Immune mediated damage to the enterocytes are seen in autoimmune conditions such as Celiac disease which leads to damage to the enterocytes as well as villous atrophy. Patients with this disease usually have foul smelling stools or greasy stools which is not seen in this patient making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with splenomegaly and pancytopenia.  The bone marrow tap was dry. You prepare a peripheral blood smear, which reveals the findings shown in the given image.   What is the most likely feature and a drug used in managing the condition?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows abnormal B cells with fine hair-like cytoplasmic projections characteristic of hairy cell leukemia. This leukemia is Annexin A1 positive and cladribine is the treatment of choice. 

Hairy cell leukemia:

  • It is associated with BRAF mutations.
  • It mainly occurs in older males.
  • Splenomegaly is the most common physical finding. 
  • It is extremely sensitive to chemotherapeutic agents.
  • Overall prognosis is excellent.
  • Pathology:
    • Hairy cell leukemia is limited to the red pulp of the spleen, which is heavily infiltrated. This leads to the obliteration of white pulp and a beefy red gross appearance.
    • Hairy cells can be identified in the peripheral blood smear.
    • Pancytopenia results from marrow infiltration and splenic sequestration.
    • A "dry tap" is common on aspiration.
    • Detection of annexin A1 in bone marrow specimens has been shown to have 100% sensitivity and specificity in differentiating hairy cell leukemia from other B-cell malignancies.
    • Trephine biopsy: Leukemic cells have a nucleus surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo giving them a fried-egg appearance.
    • CD11c, CD25, and CD103 are the characteristic immunophenotype diagnostic markers.
    • Cells test positive for pan-B-cell markers such as CD19, CD20, and CD22.
    • Cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).

The image given below shows small cells with clear cytoplasm and a round central nucleus—fried-egg appearance.

Other options:

Options A and B: Synaptophysin positivity is seen in neuroendocrine tumours. 

Option C: Dacarbazine is used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient comes with complaints of recurrent palpitations. On physical examination, he has small gonads and a receding hairline. When the physician shakes hands with him, he has difficulty releasing the hand. What is the likely etiology of his disease?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features of palpitations with small gonads, a receding hairline and difficulty in releasing hands make a diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy likely.  This occurs due to a CTG trinucleotide repeat on chromosome 19.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused by CTG trinucleotide repeat in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

It is associated with weakness in the distal muscles of the wrist, fingers, and foot. Involvement of the palatal, pharyngeal, and tongue muscles causes dysarthria and dysphagia. Involvement of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leads to respiratory insufficiency. Proximal muscles remain unaffected.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. ECG shows conduction abnormalities in the form of first-degree heart block or other conduction anomalies. Electromyography may show myotonia in DM1. However, it is patchy in DM2. Creatine kinase levels in the serum may be normal or mildly elevated.

The histopathological finding of muscle biopsy in both DM1 and DM2 shows internalised nuclei seen in individual muscle fibres and the presence of several atrophic fibres with pyknotic nuclear clumps.

Treatment is mainly symptomatic. However, mexiletine is indicated for both DM1 and DM2 to help in reducing myotonia.

Other Options:

Option B: Motor neuron atrophy can be seen in conditions like Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Option C: Neuromuscular junction dysfunctions are affected in myasthenia gravis and Lambert-Eaton syndrome. 

Option D: Mitochondrial DNA defect is seen in Hereditary Leber's optic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the cardiologist with a history of breathlessness when playing, which is relieved by squatting following which he is able to resume playing.  His mother says that as an infant, he would sometimes turn blue when crying vigorously. On examination, an ejection systolic murmur is audible, which becomes louder when the child squats. Which of the following X-ray images is most consistent with the suspected diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
A child with a history of cyanosis on crying during early childhood and later having symptoms of exertional dyspnea which is relieved by squatting, associated with an ejection systolic murmur that is increased by squatting, is likely to have Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Image A represents the characteristic 'coeur-en-sabot' or boot-shaped heart seen in the Tetralogy of Fallot.

Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart disease characterized by four anatomical anomalies:

  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding the VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

Patients suffer exertional dyspnea due to decreased blood flow across the stenosed pulmonic valve. The dyspnea is relieved on squatting or lying down as this increases the peripheral vascular resistance and causes a reversal of flow across the VSD and into the pulmonary artery. As a result this maneuver also causes the intensity of the systolic ejection murmur to be increased. 

Infant patients may also present with anoxic or 'tet' spells wherein following exertion or waking up, vigorous crying leads to worsening of dyspnea and cyanosis followed by syncope due to the same reason, i.e., decreased pulmonary blood flow.

Due to pulmonic stenosis causing concavity of the left heart border and a hypertrophied RV causing the cardiac apex to be lifted, the characteristic boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen on x-ray.

Image B shows a globular (like an egg) heart with an egg-on-a-string appearance, classically present in the Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA). This appearance occurs as a result of the narrow base of the heart and atrial enlargement due to the position of the aorta and the pulmonary arteries. 

 

Image C shows a box-shaped heart as is classically seen in Ebstein's anomaly, that occurs due to lithium toxicity during pregnancy. This appearance is due to right atrial and right ventricular enlargement with prominent pulmonary artery and a small aortic knuckle.

Image D shows a snowman or a figure of 8 appearance, seen in Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) after the age of 2 years. This X-ray finding is due to the drainage of the supracardiac pulmonary vein into the left nominate vein.

questions.text: A 2 years old male child is brought with pellagra like symptoms and cutaneous photosensitivity. Elder sister has similar symptoms. Two siblings are normal. The child most likely has__________

choices.text: Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra like symptoms, photosensitivity in a 2 year old child with autosomal inheritance is suggestive of Hartnup disease. Hartnup disease (pellagra like dermatosis) is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan and other monoamino monocarboxylic amino acids (neutral amino acids). This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra like symptoms.

Clinical features:

  • Most of the children are asymptomatic
  • However, major clinical manifestation in the rare symptomatic patient is, cutaneous photosensitivity
  • The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop. The rash maybe pruritic and chronic eczema may also appear.
  • Some patients may also have an intermittent ataxia, manifested as an unsteady wide based gait, which usually lasts for few days, and recovers spontaneously.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine testing for amino acids.
  • Diagnosis of Hartnup disease is made by showing the characteristic amino acid excretion pattern in urine. Indoles and other tryptophan degradation products in urine provide supplementary evidence of the disease.

Treatment:

  • Niacin or niacinamide supplements
  • Nicotinamide for attacks

questions.text: Which of the following type of interactions is responsible for the stability of the following structure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image represents a beta-sheet which is a secondary structure of proteins. They owe their stability to hydrogen bonds formed between two adjacent beta-sheets.

Proteins are arranged in the following four structures:

  • Primary
    • The sequence of amino acids in a protein is called a primary structure.
  • Secondary
    • The folding of short contiguous polypeptide sequences into geometrically ordered units.
    • Alpha helix and beta sheets are examples of secondary structure.
      • Alpha helix - It is the most common and stable secondary structure as a result of hydrogen bonds, supplemented by Van der Waal interactions.
      • Beta-sheets - They derive their stability from hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygens and amide hydrogens of peptide bonds between adjacent sheets.
    • Hydrogen bonds play an important role in the maintenance of the secondary structure.
    • Of this, beta sheets are represented as broad arrows, with the carboxy-terminal of the polypeptide chain at the tip of the arrow.
  •  Tertiary
    • This refers to the folding and final arrangement of domains in a polypeptide structure. In this, hydrophobic side chains are buried in the core whereas hydrophilic side chains are freely exposed.
    • An example of a tertiary structure is domain. These are the areas/structures of a protein that are capable of performing a particular chemical or physical task, for example, binding to a molecule, acting as a receptor, etc. 
    • Disulfide bonds, hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, and ionic interactions account for the stability of the structure.
  •  Quaternary
    • It is the arrangement of different polypeptide subunits in a protein

questions.text: A 2-week-old boy is brought by the mother with complaints of jaundice. She further gives a history of dark-colored urine and pale-colored stool. HIDA scan shows a good hepatic uptake but an absence of excretion into the duodenum. Which of the following anomalies are associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the imaging are suggestive of biliary atresia. The anomalies associated with it are:

  • Polysplenia
  • Situs inversus
  • Absent vena cava
  • Preduodenal portal vein

Biliary atresia is the progressive narrowing of the bile ducts. Affected children present with jaundice in the first week of life. The laboratory investigation will show an obstructive pattern with elevated direct bilirubin levels and alkaline phosphatase.

Biliary atresia may also be termed noncystic obliterative cholangiopathy. It is a disease of the intra and extrahepatic bile ducts of unknown etiology. 

The disease is classified according to the level of the most proximal biliary obstruction:

  • Type 1 biliary atresia- has patency to the level of the common bile duct (CBD)
  • Type 2 biliary atresia- has patency to the level of the common hepatic duct
  • Type 3 biliary atresia- occurs when the left and right hepatic ducts, at the level of the porta hepatis, are involved. 

Clinical features include persistent jaundice, clay-colored stools, and hepatomegaly. Untreated newborns will show signs of liver cirrhosis and failure (ascites, portal hypertension, and failure to thrive). 

Laboratory evaluation will show features of obstructive jaundice like elevated direct and indirect bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase. The meconium may be a little bile stained, but later the stools are pale and the urine is dark. Ultrasound will show hypoplastic or absent gall bladder and triangular cord sign. 

Hepatobiliary scintigraphy can also be performed. HIDA scan is useful in making the diagnosis. There is good hepatic uptake, but since there is atresia of the biliary tree, there is an absence of excretion of the dye into the intestine. However, the gold standard investigation is the intraoperative cholangiogram.

If biliary atresia is confirmed by cholangiogram, a Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy) should be performed. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old hypertensive man presented with a 2-day history of continuous gnawing pain in the hypogastric region. An ultrasound revealed a pulsatile intra-abdominal mass. CT image is given below. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Follow up with serial abdominal ultrasound

questions.solution:
The image shows an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The next best in management in this case is operative repair as the patient is symptomatic.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms are mostly asymptomatic and are detected as incidental findings on investigations for other complaints. Sometimes, they present with pain and pulsatile abdominal mass. Rupture of aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension.

Management of abdominal aortic aneurysms:

  • Statins- Atherosclerosis is the most common pathology associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Hence, statins are prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
  • Asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5 cm in diameter- serial abdominal ultrasound to monitor the rate of expansion of the aneurysm.
  • Operative repair is indicated for:
    • Aneurysm of any size associated with symptoms
    • Rapidly growing aneurysms
    • Aneurysms ≥5.5 cm in diameter

Note: Medical management with beta-blockers is not effective in reducing the rate of growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: You suspect genital infection in a patient with complaints of infertility after the hysterosalpingography showed the following finding. You plan to do an endometrial biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. When is the right time to do the biopsy if she has a regular 28-day menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingography image shows the typical "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube, which is highly suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Endometrial biopsy is done on day 26 of the cycle as the tubercle bacilli are present in the deeper layers of the endometrium and come to the surface just before menstruation. Hence, an endometrial biopsy is done 1 or 2 days before menstruation.

Genital tuberculosis: The leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. It mostly spreads via the haematogenous route. Lymphatic spread is also seen sometimes. It can rarely spread by direct contact with the affected intraabdominal organs or peritoneum. 

The fallopian tubes are the most common site to be affected. The disease subsequently spreads to other genital organs and the peritoneum. The endometrium is involved in 60% of cases. The infection is from the tubes either by lymphatics or by direct spread through continuity. Cornual ends are commonly affected due to their dual blood supply, as well as their anatomical proximity to tubes. 

Investigations:

1. Complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) tests - lgG and IgM, and Mantoux tests are done to evaluate the case of genital tuberculosis. The nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) can detect tuberculosis within a few hours compared to culture.

2. Hysterosalpingography- If genital tuberculosis is suspected, it should not be performed because of the risk of spread of infection.

If performed in an asymptomatic woman, the following patterns may be seen:

  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx with blocked fimbrial end
  • Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead-pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • The jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube

3. The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. Endometrium tissue is obtained by D&C/hystroscopy-directed biopsy. The endometrial scrapings are used for histopathology, PCR testing, and AFB smear and culture. 

4. Laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is widely used to establish the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis/ abdominal pelvic tuberculosis. Tuberculous lesions can be seen on the parietal peritoneum, intestinal serosa, omentum, surface of the uterus, and fallopian tubes.

The image below shows the "pipe stem" or "lead pipe" appearance. There is an absence of normal tortuosity and a curved or straight pipe-like appearance shows the fibrotic stage of tuberculous salpingitis. 

The image below shows multiple constrictions along the fallopian tube, giving rise to a "beaded" appearance.

Image below shows sacculation of both tubes in distal portion with an associated hydrosalpinx giving a Golf club-like appearance.

Image below shows " Tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient who has type 2 diabetes comes with complaints of nausea, bloating, and early satiety. She also has had an 8 kg weight loss over 2 months. What test is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and complaints of nausea, early satiety, weight loss and bloating most likely has developed diabetic gastroparesis, a form of diabetic autonomic neuropathy. The best test to confirm the diagnosis is a gastric emptying study also known as gastric scintigraphy.

Diabetic gastroparesis occurs due to autonomic neuropathy caused by chronic high blood glucose levels. This affects gastric motility and decreases the number of contractions, leading to food retention in the stomach over extended periods of time. 

Any mechanical obstructions should be ruled out while evaluating a patient with such symptoms. Initially, an upper GI endoscopy is done. This can show retained food in the stomach without any mechanical obstruction. 

The confirmatory test is a radiolabeled four-hour gastric emptying study. 

Treatment:

  • The first step is lifestyle modifications including strict glycemic control. 
  • Patients should be encouraged to have smaller frequent meals. 
  • Carbonated beverages and fat and fibre-containing foods have to be avoided. 
  • Pharmacotherapy is with drugs that increase gastrointestinal motility like erythromycin, metoclopramide, ondansetron and promethazine. 

Other Options:

Options A and B: USG abdomen and CT Abdomen are done in cases of suspected mechanical obstruction and malignancies. This patient with her history of Diabetes mellitus most likely has diabetic gastroparesis.

Option C: D Xylose absorption test is done to check for normal intestinal function. It is used in the evaluation of celiac disease.

questions.text: A term newborn infant is diagnosed with neonatal meningitis on Day 3 of life and requires IV antibiotics, for which the pediatric resident is called to perform the procedure depicted below. Which of the following statements about this procedure is true?

choices.text: It can be perfomed till the age of 1 month
Air embolism is a possible complication

questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of umbilical vessel cannulation. Air embolism is one of the possible complications of this procedure.

Umbilical vessel cannulation provides an alternative and safe IV access route for fluid and medication delivery in newborns in the first 7-10 days of life before the umbilical stump gets detached. Commonly it is the umbilical vein that is cannulated. Umbilical artery cannulation is useful for arterial pressure monitoring or arterial blood sampling. 

Indications:

  • Neonatal resuscitation
  • Blood pressure monitoring
  • Exchange transfusion
  • IV fluids and IV medications such as antibiotics.

Contraindications:

  • Omphalitis
  • Peritonitis
  • Necrotizing Enterocolitis 
  • Gastrochisis. 

Umbilical catheterization is performed with the neonate placed in the radiant warmer with continuous vital signs monitoring. Anesthesia is not required for the procedure. Following sterile precautions, parts are painted and draped. The umbilical stump is held with non-tooth forceps and a transverse cut is made using a scalpel. Umbilical arteries and vein are identified based on the position (vein at 12 o'clock) and wall thickness.

An umbilical tape is applied around the base and tightened to prevent bleeding. An iris forceps is used to dilate the vessel following which the umbilical vein catheter is gently introduced with the forceps held in the dominant hand, while the base is held with the non-dominant hand. The catheter should advance without resistance, and if encountered, it should be withdrawn and gently re-introduced. Once in place, it is flushed with heparinized saline and then fixed with purse string sutures and the position confirmed by x-ray.

The ideal position for a venous line is above the diaphragm but below the right atrium.

The ideal position for an arterial line is above the diaphragm but below the heart, between T6-T9 vertebrae (high position) or above the aortic bifurcation between L3-L4 vertebrae (low position).

Complications:

  • Incorrect placement into the ductus venosus
  • Vascular spasm
  • Air embolism
  • Thrombosis
  • Infection.

 

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: CD markers are specific surface antigens found on lymphocytes and other leukocytes. What does CD stand for?
questions.solution:
Cluster of differentiation (CD) markers are surface antigens or markers identified on lymphocytes and other leukocytes by means of monoclonal antibodies. They reflect the stage of differentiation and functional properties of those cells. 

Over 150 CD markers have been identified so far. Some important CD markers for leukocyte differentiation are given below:

  • CD 1: Thymocytes
  • CD 3: T-cell antigen receptor complex 
  • CD 19:  B cell 
  • CD 4:  Helper T-cells  
  • CD 8: Cytotoxic T-cells

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient who has previously undergone a Hartmann's procedure visits the OPD with complaints of pain at the stoma site, associated with decreased output. On examination, the stoma appears completely retracted and muco-cutaneous separation is noted. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Complete stomal retraction with mucocutaneous separation requires immediate laparotomy and stoma revision due to risk of subfascial contamination, peritonitis, and sepsis.

A stoma is an artificial opening made to divert the contents from a tubular structure to where they can be collected in an external appliance. Depending on the purpose for which they are created, stomas may be temporary or permanent. A colostomy formed during the Hartmann procedure is an example of end-colostomy, which is a permanent stoma.

Stomal complications are common surgical problems. They are classified as early, if they arise within 1 month, or late. Retraction is one of the complications that may occur even as a delayed complication. Early and incomplete stomal retraction with a viable bowel may be managed by excising the unhealthy tissue and resuturing the mucosa to the skin after relieving tension. However, complete retraction brings the risk of necrosis and intraperitoneal infection and hence is an indication for laparotomy and revision.

 

Early Stomal Complications Late Stomal Complications

  • Retraction
  • Detachment
  • Ischemic necrosis
  • Abscess formation
  • Diarrhoea/leakage
  • Prolapse

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient presents with a history of chronic fatigue. He has no significant past medical or surgical history and he is on a strict vegan diet. His peripheral smear is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The scenario along with the image is highly suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. In the given image, the peripheral smear shows cabot rings and basophilic stippling.

Megaloblastic anemia is a type of macrocytic anemia with impaired nucleic acid metabolism. Nuclear maturation lags behind cytoplasmic maturation. The causes include

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Folate deficiency
  • Drugs (Methotrexate)

In this stem, the likely cause is vitamin B12 deficiency as the patient is a strict vegan. Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Other causes of B12 deficiency includes

  • Malabsorption (Pernicious anemia)
  • Total or partial gastrectomy
  • Ileal resection
  • Tropical sprue

Clinical features of cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency (megaloblastic anemia) include:

  • Anorexia, weight loss, diarrhea, or constipation
  • Oral manifestations: glossitis, angular cheilosis
  • Mild fever in more severely anemic patients
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Bruising (thrombocytopenia) and infections (low leucocyte count)
  • Complications in pregnancy: recurrent fetal loss and neural tube defects
  • Cardiovascular disease: cerebrovascular, peripheral vascular, and coronary heart disease with deep vein thrombosis
  • Neurologic manifestations: Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord (SACDSC). Seen in only B12 deficiency.
  • Psychiatric disturbances

The peripheral smear shows oval macrocytes, anisocytosis, and hypersegmented neutrophils (more than 5 nuclear lobes).

Other features of ineffective erythropoiesis seen in megaloblastic anemias include:

  • Howell-Jolly bodies: Nuclear remnants within red cells that are usually single, round, dark purple-red in color, and peripheral in location.

 

  • Basophilic stippling: Blue granules of various sizes dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell, they represent ribosomal precipitates.
  • Cabot rings: Red cell inclusions appearing as fine, purple filamentous loops or figures of eight forms, presumed to be remnants of mitotic spindles.

questions.text: What type of gland produces the secretions removed by this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows syringing which is a procedure done for impacted wax. Wax-producing ceruminous glands of the external auditory meatus are modified apocrine glands.

Wax is composed of secretion of sebaceous glands, ceruminous glands, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin and dirt.

The thick subcutaneous tissue of the cartilaginous part of the external auditory meatus contains numerous ceruminous glands that secrete wax, or cerumen. The medial bony part of EAC and the auricle are normally devoid of these glands, although they can be seen rarely as an incidental finding. 

Their coiled tubular structure resembles that of sweat glands. The secretory cells are columnar when active but cuboidal when quiescent; they are covered externally by myoepithelial cells. Ducts open either onto the epithelial surface or into the nearby sebaceous gland of a hair follicle.

Syringing is a procedure where the pinna is pulled upwards and backwards and a stream of water from the ear syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus. The pressure of water, built up deeper into the wax, expels the wax out.

Types of glands:

Apocrine Holocrine Eccrine(Merocrine)
Apical part of cell sheds off during discharge Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis

Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland

Found everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal and lips

questions.text: A researcher conducts a study among smokers. He finds that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking. This is indicative of:
questions.solution:
The study where the researcher finds that 80% of lung cancer cases are due to cigarette smoking is indicative of attributable risk.

Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease between an exposed group and an unexposed group.

It is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure. It also refers to the amount of disease that could be eliminated if the exposure is controlled or eliminated. It reflects the impact of public health programs in the prevention of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Incidence of a disease refers to the number of new cases occurring in a population in a given period of time.

Option B: Relative risk refers to the ratio of incidence of the disease among the exposed and the incidence of disease among the unexposed population. It establishes the strength of association between the disease and the suspected causative factor.

Option D: Population attributable risk refers to the incidence of the disease in the total population minus the incidence of disease among the population unexposed to the causative factor. It indicates the incidence of disease that could be prevented in the total population if the suspected causative factor was eliminated. 

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where,

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: A 65-year-old  female patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision. She has had type 2 diabetes mellitus for 12 years. Ophthalmoscopy shows evidence of loss of fundal features, floating debris and a dark red glow. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with sudden, painless vision loss, floating debris and a dark red glow on fundoscopic examination is most likely suffering from vitreous hemorrhage. Image below shows an example depicting the same.

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which can arise in people with long-term diabetes mellitus, is a common risk factor for vitrous hemorrhage caused by the breakage of the fragile blood vessels on the retina's surface. Intravitreal blood blocks light from reaching the retina, resulting in patients experiencing sudden onset cloudy vision, sometimes with a red tint, or vision loss.In the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) classification diabetics with advanced eye disease are likely to manifest with tractional retinal detachment, neovascular glaucoma or persistent vitreous hemorrhage. 

Patients with vitreous hemorrhage can be adequately managed with bed rest to prevent additional bleeding and elevation of the head to promote blood settling away from the vsual axis. Treatment must also be targeted to the underlying cause of the bleed.(eg.photocoagulation for proliferative retinopathy). Vitreoretinal surgery with photocoagulation is indicated in patients with persistent vitreal hemorrhage. Alternatively, pars plana vitrectomy may be deemed necessary in patients with persistent vitreal hemorrhage. 

Vitreous hemorrhage has a variable presentation depending on the severity of the hemorrhage. The mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision.

Causes

  • Acute posterior vitreous detachment associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vessel
  • Proliferative retinopathy
    • Diabetic
    • Retinal vein occlusion
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Eales disease
    • Vasculitis
  • Miscellaneous retinal disorders
    • Macroaneurysm
    • Telangiectasia
    • Capillary hemangioma
  • Trauma
  • Systemic
    • Bleeding disorders
    • Terson syndrome

Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.

Terson syndrome
Terson syndrome refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.

The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is an ultrasound B-scan.

Other options 

Option A - Patients with retinal detachment can develop floaters and have acute vision loss. However, photpsia is common and fundoscopy reveals an elevated retina with folds or tears.

An image showing retinal detachment at the fovea and the macula is shown below.

Option C - Patients with macular degeneration typically have painless central blurring of vision which is progressive as opposed to vitreous hemorrhage which is acute in its presentation. Age related macular degeneration is the most common cause of blindness in developed nations with a preponderance among women. Smoking is an independent risk factor. Hormone replacement therapy, estrogen therapy as well as supplementation of antioxidants and zinc have proven efficacy is retarding its progression.

Image depicting age related macular degeneration with the presence of drusens is as shown below.

Option D - Patients with central retinal vein occlusion can also present with sudden, painless loss of vision but would have scattered, diffuse hemorrhages, disc swelling and cotton wool spots.

Image showing central retinal vein occlusion is as follows.

questions.text:
Individuals diagnosed with which of the following medical conditions are most prone to developing nyctalopia?
  1. Patient with myopia of -7D
  2. Patient with Cirrhosis of liver
  3. Patient with myopia of -3D
  4. Patient with aniridia
  5. Patient with fundus showing bony corpuscles
questions.solution:
Patients with conditions 1,2 and 5 are likely to develop nyctalopia (night blindness).

Causes of nyctalopia are :

  • Retinitis pigmentosa - Bony spicules seen on fundoscopy
  • Pathological myopia - >/=6D
  • Xerophthalmia - Vitamin A deficiency

Nyctalopia is defined as the inability to see in low light conditions because of interference in the functioning of the retinal rods.

Retinitis pigmentosa is a pigmental retinal dystrophy where the photoreceptors, especially rods are affected. Around 50 - 60% of the cases have a familial inheritance. Out of these cases, most are inherited by autosomal dominant mode. These have the best prognosis. Other cases can be either autosomal recessive or X-linked recessive. Night blindness is a characteristic feature. Tubular vision is seen in advanced cases. 

Retinal pigmentary changes on fundus examination reveal perivascular and jet black spots resembling bone corpuscles. Initially identified only in the equatorial area which gradually expand both anteriorly and posteriorly as shown in the image below.

Myopia (shortsightedness) is a refractive error in which the light rays from infinity are focused in front of the retina. It is proven to have familial inheritance. Features include defective vision, impaired night vision, and muscae volitantes. Pathological myopia is rapid progressive form with myopia >/= 6D. Inherited by autosomal dominant mode and has been linked to genes 18p and 12q.

Xerophthalmia is caused due to vitamin A deficiency and occurs in

  • fat soluble vitamin deficiency in patients with cirrhosis of liver
  • Patients on phenothiazine group of drugs for mental illnesses
  • Nutrient intake deficiency

Hemarlopia is defined as the inability to see in bright light as a result of poor light adaptation. 

Causes include :

  • Central nuclear or polar cataracts
  • Central corneal opacity
  • Central vitreous opacity
  • Albinism
  • Aniridia
  • Use of trimethadione
  • Cone dystrophy or achromatopsia (rare)

questions.text: Which of the following events favours the process of voluntary defecation?

choices.text: Contraction of the external anal sphincter

questions.solution:
Straightening of the anorectal angle favours the process of voluntary defecation that can be initiated by straining. 

Normally, the angle between the anus and the rectum is around 90-100°. This, together with the contraction of the puborectalis muscle, inhibits defecation.

During voluntary defecation, the pelvic floor is lowered by 1–3 cm, the anorectal angle is straightened and the external anal sphincter and puborectalis muscle relaxes. 

The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to 18 mm Hg. When this pressure reaches 55 mm Hg, the external and the internal sphinc­ter relax, and there is reflex expulsion of the contents of the rectum.

Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon stimulates stretch receptors in the rectal wall. Then, the defecation reflexes travel from the colon and rectum to the spinal cord and back again to produce the powerful colonic, rectal, and abdominal contractions required for defecation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy comes to the emergency department after a fall. On physical examination, there is pain and swelling in the left wrist region. The X-ray of his wrist joint is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the X-ray showing compression on one side of the radius causing the other side to bend/ buckle suggests a torus fracture.

Torus fracture is also called a buckle fracture. It is caused due to an axial loading force acting along the long axis of a long bone. This results in compression on one side and bending of the other side of the trabecular part of the long bone.

It most commonly occurs at the transition between the metaphysis and diaphysis of the cortex. It is commonly seen occurring at the distal radius in young children. Management includes immobilization and splinting for 3-4 weeks.

The given image indicates the site of the torus fracture:

Greenstick fractures are commonly seen in children. These are incomplete fractures where one side of the cortex is broken but the other side remains intact.

The image given below shows a greenstick fracture:

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy comes to the clinic with pain and swelling in his right chest for 2 months. The pain progressively worsens day by day and it is worse at night and disturbs his sleep. Further examination reveals a mass that is biopsied and shown below. Mutations in CDKN2A are present in this patient. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of chondrosarcoma. The histopathological image shown has sheets of malignant chondrocytes that have abundant cytoplasm with the intralesional bone formation which is characteristic of the clear cell subtype of this bone tumor

Chondrosarcoma are malignant tumors that produce cartilage. They are subclassified histologically as conventional (hyaline cartilage producing), clear cell, dedifferentiated, and mesenchymal variants.

Conventional central tumors constitute 90% of chondrosarcoma. Individuals with chondrosarcoma are usually in their 40s or older. The clear cell and especially the mesenchymal variants occur in younger patients, in their teens or 20s.

Chondrosarcomas commonly arise in the axial skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs. A slow-growing, low-grade tumor causes reactive thickening of the cortex but a more aggressive neoplasm destroys the cortex and forms a soft tissue mass. About 15% of these tumors are secondary, arising from preexisting enchondromas and osteosarcoma.

Chondrosarcomas arising in multiple osteochondroma syndromes carry mutations in the EXT genes and sporadic cases have mutations in IDH1 and IDH2. Silencing of the CDKN2A tumor suppressor gene is seen in these cases.

Histopathology:

  • They are large bulky tumors made up of nodules of glistening gray-white, translucent cartilage. The matrix is often gelatinous or myxoid. Spotty calcifications are present and central necrosis may create cystic spaces.
  • The cartilage infiltrates the marrow space and surrounds pre-existing bony trabeculae. The tumors have three grades based on cellularity, cytological atypia, and the mitotic activity
  • Clear cell chondrosarcoma has sheets of large, malignant chondrocytes that have clear cytoplasm, numerous osteoclast-type giant cells, and intralesional reactive bone formation.
  • Mesenchymal chondrosarcoma is composed of islands of well-differentiated hyaline cartilage surrounded by small cells that mimic Ewing's sarcoma.

The image below shows the histopathology of chondrosarcoma with the red arrow showing the large malignant cells with prominent nuclei and the black arrow pointing to the intralesional bone formation.

Other options:

Option A- Osteoclastoma is characterized by giant cells (osteoclasts) and expresses RANKL. They have sheets of uniform mononuclear cells and giant cells. It is usually seen in individuals between 20 to 40 years of age. They mainly arise from the epiphysis but may extend to metaphysics. The majority of them arise from the distal femur and proximal tibia. 

The below image shows sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast type giant cells.

Option C- Enchondromas are the most common intraosseous cartilage tumor. These tumors generally have IDH1 and IDH2 mutations. They are usually seen in individuals between the ages of 20 to 50 years. They are predominantly seen as solitary metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones in hands and feet. They are well-circumscribed and contain cytomorphologically benign chondrocytes. Enchondroma op large bones are asymptomatic and are detected incidentally. 

The below image shows the cells of the gray-blue transplant suggestive of enchondroma. 

Option D- Ewing's tumor is a malignant bone tumor characterized by primitive round cells without differentiation. Most lesions contain a translocation 11: 22. It is the second most common tumor in children. They are predominantly seen in boys younger than 20 years of age. They mainly arise in the diaphysis of long bones, like the femur and flat bones of the pelvis. The cells are uniform and round with scant cytoplasm. Homer-Wright rosettes with a grouping of cells and a central fibrillary core may be present. 

The below image shows sheets of small round cells with a small amount of clear cytoplasm suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
