questions.text:
A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye. Which of the following measures can be utilized in this patient's management?
  1. Prescribe artificial tear drops
  2. Prescribe cromolyn sodium 6 hourly 
  3. Removal of contact lens
  4. Cryoablation of the papillae
questions.solution:
The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis and must be managed first by removal of the contact lens ie the offending agent. Artificial tears and Cromolyn sodium can be prescribed but only after the removal of the offending agent first.  Cromolyn sodium a mast cell stabilizer is to be consumed 4 times a day (6th hourly). Cryoablation of the papillae is done in cases of refractory giant papillary conjunctivitis, but not in this patient because this is the first time the patient has presented for therapy.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wear. It can also be associated with ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles. Primary management includes removal of the offending agent ie contact lens or suture, replacement of prosthesis with a Biocoat. 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a peculiar type of allergic conjunctivitis involving the superior tarsal conjuctiva whose pathogenesis is mediated by type I or IV hypersensitivity. 

Patients usually present with redness, foreign body sensation, increased mucus production, itching, blurring, and loss of contact lens tolerance. On examination, giant papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae.

Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva. These are caused by the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system, with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.

The image below shows papillae in the tarsal conjunctiva.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A drug having a half-life of 10 hours is administered orally thrice daily. How much time will it take for the drug bioavailability to be equal to drug elimination?
questions.solution:
The time taken for the bioavailability of the drug to be equal to the drug elimination(clearance x concentration) rate is the steady-state concentration of the drug. The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives. As the half-life of the given drug is 10 hours, so it will take 40-50 hours to reach a steady state. Hence, 45 hours will be the most appropriate answer.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

In the case of intravenous infusion,

Steady-state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion/ CL

Pharmacokinetics of repeated drug dosing:

Plasma concentration of the drug will increase, reach a maximum, and decline after the first dose. A second dose will be administered before the first dose is completely eliminated. Consequently, the plasma concentration resulting from the second dose will be higher than from the first dose.

This increase in plasma concentration of the drug will occur continuously on repeated dosing (drug accumulation occurs) until a steady state at which drug elimination is equal to drug administration is reached. This is known as the plateau principle of drug accumulation.

A graph is plotted between plasma drug concentration and time as shown below. The given graph depicts the plateau principle of drug accumulation on repeated oral dosing.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of swelling and restriction of movement at the left elbow joint. Physical therapy was used to treat his supracondylar fracture. Radiographs performed is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This boy following physical therapy for supracondylar fracture humerus now presenting with pain and restriction of movement at the elbow has developed heterotopic calcification. 

Myositis ossificans is characterized by formation of lamellar bone in the extaskeletal tissues. Patients usually present with a painful, firm, mobile mass. Develeopment of which is caused by the increased expression of bone morphogenic proteins leading to migration of stem cells into the lesion which then mature into fibroblasts, chondrocytes and osteocytes , resulting in metaplastic bone formation.

It is a highly inflammatory, rapidly growing, and painful muscular mass, which is seen following muscular trauma, orthopedic surgery. It can also be seen in patients with stroke or neurological injury. The late stage is characterized by a typical zonal pattern (zonal phenomenon). It consists of three zones:

  • Innermost zone: made of proliferating fibroblasts and myofibroblasts with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis
  • Intermediate zone: contains osteoblasts with the immature osteoid formation
  • Peripheral zone: the mature bone
 
Other options 
 
Option A : Tear in the brachialis tendon would likely present with pain on flexion of the forearm. Also, radiograph suggestive of tear is not seen in this case.
 
Option B : Necrotizing myositis is an infection caused by group A Streptococcus. Patients would present with severe pain, erythema and edema of the limb which is not seen in this patient.
 
Option C : Patients with neoplastic bone disorders presents with severe pain during the night with stretch of the muscle overlying the bone not likely to cause pain. Also, this patient's recent supracondylar fracture makes myositis ossificans the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old lady who underwent suction evacuation for molar pregnancy visits you on postoperative week 8 for her follow-up. Which of the following is not done during the follow-up of this patient?
  1. Ask her for a history of any irregular vaginal bleeding, cough, or breathlessness.
  2. Perform an abdominal examination to look for the size of the uterus and the ovaries.
  3. Perform a pelvic examination to look for sub-urethral nodules
  4. Request for a serum hCG value, a pelvic ultrasound, and chest X-ray PA view 
  5. Insert a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy
questions.solution:
Insertion of a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy is not done during follow-up of this patient.

Intrauterine devices are contraindicated post-evacuation of molar pregnancy due to the increased risk of perforation. Intrauterine devices and progestogen-only pills cause irregular bleeding and are best avoided as they lead to suspicion of malignancy. Safer contraceptive choices for such patients include combined oral pills, injectable DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate), progestin implant, barrier methods, and sterilization.

Contraception has to be adopted by all patients who underwent suction curettage until HCG levels become undetectable and remain the same for a period of 6 months. This serves to avoid pregnancy and confusion regarding the source of HCG if there is a subsequent rise. After beta HCG levels have become normal, subsequent conception must be avoided for one year(preferably 2 years). Pregnancy should also be avoided for 1 year after the stoppage of chemotherapy because of the teratogenic effect of drugs.

All patients should be followed-up for 2 years because choriocarcinoma if it occurs, develops within this period of the evacuation of the mole. Commonly, the circulating levels of βhCG decrease or becomes negative within 4 to 8 weeks post evacuation. Once negative, the patient is usually followed up monthly for 6 months, then 3 monthly in the first year, and 6 monthly in the second year.

During follow-up visits, history should be taken about symptoms like irregular bleeding (choriocarcinoma), presence of nodules, cough, breathlessness, and hemoptysis (metastasis). An abdominal examination should be done to check for involution of the uterus and ovarian size. A pelvic examination is done to look for sub-urethral nodules (anterior vaginal wall).

Lab investigations must include routine investigations like haemogram, renal function, liver function test, and urine routine. Specific investigations include thyroid function tests and serum βhCG (by radio-immunoassay). Persistently high values indicate pregnancy or invasive mole.

Radiological investigations should include a chest X-ray PA view to look for lung metastases (classic cannon-ball appearance can be seen). Pelvic ultrasound is also done for surveillance. Myometrial or suburethral nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. 

The given image shows the classical cannon-ball appearance on the chest X-ray.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man was brought to the emergency department with violent shaking of arms and legs for the past 15 minutes. He was administered IV lorazepam and phenytoin in intervals, followed by an additional dose of lorazepam. Even beyond 30 minutes, the seizures did not stop. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of violent shaking of arms and legs for 15 minutes is suggestive of status epilepticus. Intravenous midazolam infusion is the next step of management in this patient as he is refractory to treatment with two doses of lorazepam and an anti-seizure drug (phenytoin). 

Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, status epilepticus is defined as any one of the following:

  • Continuing seizures >5 minutes or
  • No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures.

The initial choice of therapy is a benzodiazepine, which includes either of the following:

  • Intravenous lorazepam
  • Intravenous diazepam 
  • Intramuscular midazolam- If IV access is not available

If the seizure still continues, we can repeat the above dose once again. If there is no response even after repeat doses, then a single dose of either of the antiepileptics can be given,

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin 
  • Intravenous valproic acid 
  • Intravenous levetiracetam 

If the seizure activity continues for 30 minutes even after administration of two doses of a benzodiazepine and an antiseizure drug, it is known as refractory status epilepticus. This patient requires endotracheal intubation for ventilatory support. General anesthesia is induced using continuous infusion of midazolam, propofol, or phenobarbital.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fever, hypotension, and skin rash. She had a tampon in situ for 24 hours. A bacterial cause is suspected. The toxin responsible for this condition binds to which of the following regions on the T-cell receptor?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, hypotension, and skin rash after retaining a tampon for 24 hours is likely to be staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome. The toxin involved in this condition is the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which is a superantigen that binds to the variable beta (Vβ) region on the T-cell receptor (TCR). 

The TCR is a transmembrane heterodimeric protein containing two disulfide-linked chains. It is made up of two distinct TCR classes known as alpha-beta (α and β) and gamma-delta (γ and δ). The majority of the T cells contain the αβ TCR phenotype.

There are two extracellular domains on each TCR chain: a variable region and a constant region, where the variable region binds the peptide-MHC complex, whereas the constant region is closer to the cell membrane.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity, i.e., they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

TSST-1 binds to MHC class II molecules and causes T-cell stimulation by bypassing the normal activation pathway. This leads to the overactivation of cytokines particularly, IFN-γ.  IFN-γ in turn activates macrophages to produce IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, all of which may contribute to a “cytokine storm” causing severe symptoms of shock and multiple organ failure.

Toxic shock syndrome generally occurs in menstruating women who use superabsorbent tampons and do not change them often. However, it can also occur in post-surgical infections, burns, soft tissue infections and retained foreign bodies like nasal packing, and catheters. 

Clinical features of toxic shock syndrome include fever, desquamative skin rash, hypotension, and multisystem organ involvement.

Treatment involves prompt removal of the source of infection such as tampons, nasal packing or debridement. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered after culture samples have been taken. The patient should also receive aggressive hydration with crystalloids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a breast lump for which she has undergone a tru-cut biopsy which revealed a mixed neoplasm with both epithelial and mesenchymal components and leaflike architecture with a low mitotic index. What is the preferred next step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image is suggestive of Phyllodes tumor of the breast, for which the preferred treatment is wide local excision with a 2cm margin, along with overlying skin and underlying pectoralis major muscle, which are excised due to high recurrence rate.

Phyllodes tumor is a type of breast neoplasm commonly seen in women above the age of 30 years. They present as large, freely mobile tumors with an unevenly bosselated surface. This tumor does not infiltrate the skin though the overlying skin becomes thin and may undergo pressure necrosis. 

Histology of the tumor is characterised by mixed neoplasm with both epithelial and mesenchymal components with a typical leaflike architecture as shown below. Most of these tumors have a low malignant potential but based on the the mitotic rate, they may be histologically classified as benign, borderline and malignant.  

Treatment of phyllodes tumor is by wide local excision.

Mastectomy is indicated for massive or recurrent tumors, and for malignant tumors (high mitotic index on histology) for which postoperative radiotherapy or chemotherapy may also be offered. Sentinel lymph node biopsy or axillary nodal clearance are not done as they do not spread via lymphatics, but may show hematogenous spread in malignant cases.

questions.text: A patient with CA endometrium presents with sudden breathlessness and chest pain. SpO2 is 90%. What is the etiology of the lesion given below and the reason for the same?
questions.solution:
This patient with breathlessness and chest pain with decreased oxygen saturation with a hypercoaguable state(Ca Endometrium) most likely has a pulmonary infarction. The image shows a wedge-shaped infarction of a pulmonary infarction. In the lungs, the pattern of infarction seen is red infarction. This is due to the lung being loose and spongy and it having a dual circulation, thus allowing the blood to accumulate. 

Red infarcts occur in the following conditions:

  • Venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • Loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • Tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
  • Tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
  • When flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)

 The below image shows a hemorrhagic, roughly wedge-shaped pulmonary red infarct.

White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

The below image shows a sharply demarcated white infarct in the spleen.

Septic infarctions occur when infected cardiac valve vegetations embolize or when microbes seed necrotic tissue. In these cases, the infarct is converted into an abscess, with a correspondingly greater inflammatory response.

questions.text: Therapeutic Hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic Hypothermia is indicated in the treatment of Hypoxic Ischaemic Encephalopathy (HIE)

HIE is a form of brain injury that occurs due to inadequate blood flow to the infant’s brain occurring as a result of a hypoxic-ischemic event during the prenatal, intrapartum, or postnatal period. This causes the accumulation of toxic metabolites and depletion of intra-cellular energy that further leads to neuronal injury and death.

Therapeutic Hypothermia involves systemic cooling to achieve a core temperature of 33.5°C within the first 6 hours after birth, for a period of 72 hours. This causes a reduction in the rate of production of toxic compounds and reduces seizure activity, thereby favoring cerebro-protection, especially in HIE due to intrapartum insult. It has been shown to reduce mortality and neuro-development impairment. In adults, therapeutic hypothermia also has a role in the treatment of cardiac arrest to prevent global cerebral ischemia.

The clinical grading is based on Sarnat & Sarnat Staging and HIE is described in three stages as shown below.

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hours if progress; otherwise, may remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits    

Infants at >36 weeks of gestation with one out of the following four criteria, and in Sarnat Stage 2 or 3 encephalopathy, may be started on therapeutic hypothermia

  • APGAR scores <5 at 10 minutes.
  • Positive pressure ventilation is required at ten minutes
  • Umbilical cord pH or any arterial pH <7, within 1 hour of life
  • Base deficit of more than 16 mmol/L in cord blood or arterial blood within 1 hour of life

Other Options:

Option B) Febrile seizures are managed with anticonvulsants like lorazepam and midazolam. Antipyretics may be used to decrease the discomfort of the child but do not treat the seizures.

Option C) Malignant Hyperthermia is an anaesthetic complication and is managed using IV Dantrolene Sodium in sterile water. The use of ice packs for lowering the body temperature is indicated but only up to normal body temperature, and not to induce hypothermia.

Option D) Neonatal Hyperthermia may occur when an infant is exposed to high temperatures (radiant warmer, phototherapy) for prolonged periods and is managed by removing the infant from the source of heat, followed by cooling in a bath to the normal body temperature. Hypothermia or cooling devices are not indicated.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. The enzyme most likely deficient belongs to which class of enzymes ?
questions.solution:
The most likely enzyme deficiency in a child with fatigue, excessive hunger between meals, and absent liver glycogen is glycogen synthase deficiency which belongs to the transferase group of enzymes.

Glycogen synthase belongs to the class of enzymes known as transferases as it transfers glucose from UDP - glucose to glycogenin. 

Transferases are group of enzymes that basically transfer a group from one substrate to another. 

Example - X-Y + Z ---> X + Z-Y

Examples of enzymes belonging to the transferase class of enzymes are:

  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT)
  • Alanine transaminase
  • Glucokinase
  • Aspartate transaminase

Other options:

Option A: Oxidoreductases are a class of enzymes that either add hydrogen or remove oxygen. Examples - Glucose 6 - phosphate dehydrogenase, Succinyl CoA dehydrogenase.

Option C: Lyases are a class of enzymes that make a cleavage without the addition of water. Examples - Citrate lyase, Aldolase B, HMG CoA lyase.

Option D: Ligases are a class of enzymes that combine two molecules with the utilisation of ATP. Examples - Glutamine synthetase, Arginosuccinate synthetase, Acetyl CoA carboxylase.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following renal injuries from least severe to most severe -
  1. Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction 
  2. Subcapsular, non-expanding hematoma 
  3. Laceration up to renal medulla
  4. Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  5. Avulsion of renal hilum
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of renal injuries from least to most severe is 2-4-3-1-5.

  • Subcapsul, non-expanding hematoma (Least severe)
  • Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  • Laceration up to renal medulla
  • Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction
  • Avulsion of the renal hilum (Most severe)

Renal injuries are mostly seen as a result of blunt trauma. Kidneys are the second most common visceral organ to be injured due to blunt trauma after the spleen. 

The examination includes findings related to the location of impact, flank ecchymosis, and gross or microscopic hematuria. Close attention to the entry and exit points in penetrating injuries is also important to estimate the trajectory of the missile. 

Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock and microscopic haematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding haemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour. 

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are:

  • Massive haemorrhage
  • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury)
  • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma

Relative indications are:

  • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction
  • Bowel or pancreatic injuries
  • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess 
  • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys 
  • Renal hypertension
The five grade-classification of renal injuries by "The Organ Injury Scaling system of the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST)" is explained in the pearl given below.

questions.text: A patient with chronic hepatitis C presents with skin rash and joint pains for the past 10 days. He also gives a history of hematuria. Serum studies reveal an elevation of cryoglobulins. What is the first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of skin rash and joint pain, along with chronic hepatitis C, point to a diagnosis of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The first line in the management of this condition is to treat the underlying Hepatitis C infection in patients who are seropositive. 

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in colder temperatures which leads to a vasculitis syndrome called cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. It is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection. It occurs due to an aberrant immune response to hepatitis C antigens. Patients present with cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, neuropathies, and glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings show circulating cryoprecipitates. Rheumatoid factor is found to be positive in most patients, and complement levels are low.  

Treatment:

  • In patients who are positive for hepatitis C, anti-virologic treatment should be started. Usually, this results in improvement of the vasculitis symptoms. 
  • IV glucocorticoids aren't very effective in managing the condition but have been associated with improvements in a few patients. However anti Hep C treatment should be attempted first in this patient. (Option B)
  • Plasmapheresis and Rituximab only have anecdotal evidence and are not the first line. (Option C and D)

Note:
The organs involved in Cryoglobulinemia can be remembered with the mnemonic SKIN

S skin
K kidneys
I intrarticular
N neurologic

questions.text: During a labor posting, you happen to witness the management of a patient with shoulder dystocia for which the senior resident performs the maneuver shown in the image below. The maneuver is ____.
questions.solution:
The image depicts rotation of the posterior shoulder to 180º in a corkscrew manner, this is Woods corkscrew maneuver for shoulder dystocia.

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or the posterior (rare) fetal shoulder impacts on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively.

Risk factors for the development of shoulder dystocia include maternal diabetes mellitus, obesity, postdatism, and prior history, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, etc.

Turtle Sign is positive: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. The baby's cheeks bulge out, resembling a turtle pulling its head back into its shell. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.

Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

Mc.Roberts maneuver - flexion and abduction of the thigh

Woods corkscrew maneuver - rotate the posterior shoulder to 180o in a corkscrew fashion

Zavanelli maneuver - push the head back and do cesarean

Cleidotomy - fracture clavicle of the baby

Symphysiotomy - divide pubic symphysis of the mother

Other manoeuvres: Rubin, Gaskin (All Four's Position), Hubbard, Barnum maneuver.

Note:

  • In a case of bilateral shoulder dystocia, directly proceed to perform cesarean section after doing Zavanelli manouvre.
  • Never give fundal pressure in shoulder dystocia (suprapubic pressure can be given).

The above-given image illustrates Mc.Roberts maneuver.

The image above illustrates cleidotomy being performed

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels between 10g/dl and 11.5g/dl ?
questions.solution:
In the given population, X women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels between 10g/dl and 11.5g/dl .

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean. 
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean. 
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

In a normal distribution,

2 SD from the mean will have 95% of the participants.

95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels of 10.5±2*0.5 = 10.5±1 =  9.5-11.5 g/dL.

Therefore, 95% of individuals will have Hb levels between 9.5-11.5 g/dL , 95/100 x 200 = 190

1 SD from the mean will have 68% of the participants.

68% of individuals will have Hb levels between 10 - 11g/dl

Therefore, 68%  of individuals will have Hb levels between 10 - 11g/dl , 68/100 x 200 = 136

We need to calculate the number of individuals between 10 - 11.5g/dl,

This can be done by subtracting the difference between the halves of 190(95% of pregnant women) and 136 (68% of pregnant women)

190/2 - 136/2 = 95 - 68 = 27

Therefore, the number of pregnant women lying between 10 and 11.5g/dl is  ---> 136 + 27 = 163.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A 7-year-old child was brought by his parents with complaints of profuse bloody diarrhea and rectal pain. Suspecting a helminthic infection, you perform a sigmoidoscopy which reveals a characteristic coconut cake rectum where the adult worm causing the infection is seen as white bodies hanging from the inflamed rectal mucosa. Infection with which of the following helminths is most likely?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of profuse bloody diarrhea and rectal pain along with sigmoidoscopy revealing a characteristic coconut cake rectum are suggestive of Trichuriasis caused by Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) infection. 

In heavy infection of 200 adult worms or more, sigmoidoscopy may show white bodies of worms hanging from the inflamed mucosa, the so-called coconut cake rectum. 

The mode of transmission in humans is when the mature embryonated eggs containing the infective larvae are swallowed in contaminated food or water. The eggs hatch in the small intestine. The larva, which emerges through the pole of the egg, passes down into the cecum where it develops into the adult worm.

Here the male and female mate and the female worm lays the unembryonated eggs which are passed in the stool.

The illustration given below shows the life cycle of Trichuris trichiura.

Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colourless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhoea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Some patients, particularly young children, may develop rectal prolapse.

Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm. Treatment includes mebendazole or albendazole.

Other options:

Option B: Trichinella spiralis is sometimes also known as pork worm since the infection is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The larvae more commonly infect active muscles like the diaphragm, tongue, intercostals, extraocular muscles,

Option C: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, lives in the cecum and appendix. Infection is by ingestion of eggs or autoinfection. Detection of eggs by NIH swabs and cellophane scotch tape method. 

Option D: Ascaris lumbricoides is the largest nematode infecting humans. The infective form is the embryonated egg containing rhabditiform larva. Demonstration of egg in stool or adult worm in stool or sputum is helpful in diagnosis.

questions.text:
A patient who is diagnosed with Grave's disease is posted for subtotal thyroidectomy. Identify the image which corresponds to the procedure.

Note: White portion enclosed in the dotted line corresponds to the surgically removed portion, while the colored region of the image denotes the portion left behind in the body after surgery.
questions.solution:
Image B indicates subtotal thyroidectomy. This procedure involves subtotal lobectomy of both the lobes and isthmusectomy. Subtotal and total thyroidectomies are usually done in Grave's disease.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: Which of the following statements makes it likely that a patient has pauci immune glomerulonephritis?
questions.solution:
Pauci immune glomerulonephritides are associated with Circulatory antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies. 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity with features of nephritic syndrome and rapid loss of renal function. It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents, but it does not denote a specific etiologic form of glomerulonephritis.

In most cases, RPGN is immune-mediated. Circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are detected in the pauci-immune type of RPGN. Serum analyses for anti-GBM antibodies, antinuclear antibodies, and ANCAs are helpful in the diagnosis of specific subtypes

Based on immunologic findings, RPGN is classified as:

Anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease (Type I) is characterized by linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence and includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. Here, the antibodies are produced against a peptide present in the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM. This serves as the antigen which is common to the alveoli and the glomerulus.

Immune complex deposition (Type II) is characterized by granular deposits of antibodies and complement on immunofluorescence and can be a complication of any of the immune complex nephritides which include:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • Lupus nephritis
  • IgA nephropathy
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura

Pauci-immune (Type III) exhibits no characteristic immunoglobulin or complement deposits on immunofluorescence. It includes

  • ANCA-associated
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Microscopic polyangiitis

Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease affecting men more than women, with simultaneous hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis and rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis. The GBM antigen is a component of the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of type IV collagen, which is common to both alveoli and glomeruli.

On microscopy, the renal biopsy shows show linear GBM fluorescence for Ig and complement. Electron microscopy (EM) shows the wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.
